Speaker: NA
Text: Friday, 23 May 1986

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took

Speaker: NA
Text: the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: ADJOURNMENT OF THE HOUSE: DAIRY

Speaker: NA
Text: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr Young) proposed:

Speaker: NA
Text: That-

Speaker: NA
Text: (I) standing order 48A (adjournment of House), as

Speaker: NA
Text: amended by sessional order, be suspended for

Speaker: NA
Text: this sitting, and

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) in relation to the proceedings on the following

Speaker: NA
Text: Bills, so much of the standing and sessional

Speaker: NA
Text: ders be suspended as would prevent the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House making one declaration of urgency

Speaker: NA
Text: and moving one motion for the allotment of time

Speaker: NA
Text: in respect of all the Bills:

Speaker: NA
Text: Dairy Produce Bill 1986;

Speaker: NA
Text: Dairy Produce Levy (No.1) Bill 1986;

Speaker: NA
Text: Dairy Produce Levy (No.2) Bill 1986;

Speaker: NA
Text: Dairying Industry Research and Promotion Levy

Speaker: NA
Text: (Termination of Levy) Bill 1986;

Speaker: NA
Text: Dairying Industry Stabilization Levy (Termina-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of Levy) Bill 1986; and

Speaker: NA
Text: Dairy Legislation (Transitional Provisions and

Speaker: NA
Text: Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: New England-Manager of

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition Business) (1O.02)-This is yet an-

Speaker: NA
Text: other illustration of a country which has run

Speaker: NA
Text: amok, with a Government that does not know

Speaker: NA
Text: where it is going or what it is up to. We began

Speaker: NA
Text: the week with the country in disaster, with the

Speaker: NA
Text: banana republic syndrome alive and well. The

Speaker: NA
Text: bull had well and truly grabbed the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Keating) by the tail. This motion today is

Speaker: NA
Text: designed yet again to restrict the opportunities

Speaker: NA
Text: for members to debate issues that are of funda-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental importance. Today we have a package of

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy legislation-not one Bill but six. We will

Speaker: NA
Text: be allowed only a restricted amount of time to

Speaker: NA
Text: debate them. There will be no opportunity for

Speaker: NA
Text: members who are affected electorally by this

Speaker: NA
Text: measure to give the matter adequate

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration.

Speaker: NA
Text: We well understand that the only reason the

Speaker: NA
Text: motion has been moved is that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has not been able to get its act together. For

Speaker: NA
Text: example, it is really quite incredible that, over

Speaker: NA
Text: this past week, having had nine months to intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce the legislation on capital gains tax, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government did not have the explanatory mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: orandum ready to present to the House. Today

Speaker: NA
Text: we will be expected, in the course of a few

Speaker: NA
Text: hours, to deliberate on measures that will affect

Speaker: NA
Text: the lives and livelihoods of thousands of dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers around this nation. The Opposition does

Speaker: NA
Text: not accept that it is necessary to have a guillo-

Speaker: NA
Text: tine affecting these measures.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of all the measures that have been before the

Speaker: NA
Text: LEGISLATION Parliament, the changes introduced in this area

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrate as much as anything that the Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment does not know where it is going. We

Speaker: NA
Text: should understand that this is about the third

Speaker: NA
Text: separate package that has been presented to us

Speaker: NA
Text: in this area. The industry is still far from happy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many people in various States see the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's intrusion as preventing altogether their

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to carryon their business as they

Speaker: NA
Text: orwould wish. We are concerned that all the issues

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to the measure should be adequately

Speaker: NA
Text: debated, but with a guillotine it is impossible to

Speaker: NA
Text: do so. On that basis the Opposition does not

Speaker: NA
Text: support the motion and will vote against it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question put:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the motion ( Mr Young's) be agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: The House divided.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Madam Speaker-Hon. Joan Child)

Speaker: NA
Text: Ayes 69

Speaker: NA
Text: Noes 52

Speaker: NA
Text: Majority 17

Speaker: NA
Text: Question so resolved in the affirmative,

Speaker: NA
Text: DAIRY LEGISLATION

Speaker: NA
Text: Declaration of Urgency

Speaker: Mr YOUNG
Text: Port Adelaide-Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House)-I declare that the following Bills are

Speaker: NA
Text: urgent Bills: Dairy Produce Bill 1986, Dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: Produce Levy (No, 1) Bill 1986, Dairy Produce

Speaker: NA
Text: Levy (No, 2) Bill 1986, Dairying Industry Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: search and Promotion Levy (Termination of

Speaker: NA
Text: Levy) Bill 1986, Dairy Industry Stabilization

Speaker: NA
Text: Levy (Termination of Levy) Bill 1986 and Dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: Legislation (Transitional Provisions and Conse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quential Amendments) Bill 1986.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: It is impossible to hear.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-Order! If honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members drop the level of conversation a bit,

Speaker: NA
Text: everybody will be able to hear.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Cowan-We are very interested in these

Speaker: NA
Text: Bills; we are very concerned about the dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: industry and we want to talk about it. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: not heard what the Leader of the House has

Speaker: NA
Text: said.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-Will the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member resume his seat? We will check about

Speaker: NA
Text: the microphones.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Donald Cameron-On a point of order,

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam Speaker: Honourable members have not

Speaker: NA
Text: heard what they are being asked to--

Speaker: NA
Text: NOES

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-Order! The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member will resume his seat. The question is:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bills be considered urgent Bills.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: Allotment of Time

Speaker: Mr YOUNG
Text: Port Adelaide-Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: MCVeigh, D. T.

Speaker: NA
Text: Miles, C. G.

Speaker: NA
Text: House) (10.13)-1 move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the time allotted in connection with the Bills be

Speaker: NA
Text: as follows-

Speaker: NA
Text: Would the honourable member for Moreton

Speaker: NA
Text: please listen?

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-If honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: stop speaking the House will be able to hear.

Speaker: NA
Text: Shipton, R. F.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sinclair, I. MCC.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members have just complained about

Speaker: NA
Text: not being able to hear.

Speaker: Mr YOUNG
Text: I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the time allotted in connection with the Bills be

Speaker: NA
Text: as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: PAIRS

Speaker: NA
Text: (I) Dairy Produce Bill 1986; For the remaining stages,

Speaker: NA
Text: until 4,00 p,m, this day,

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Dairy Produce Levy (No. I) Bill 1986; For the

Speaker: NA
Text: remaining stages, until 4.05 p.m. this day.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Dairy Produce Levy (No.2) Bill 1986; For the

Speaker: NA
Text: remaining stages, until 4.10 p.m. this day.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Dairying Industry Research and Promotion Levy

Speaker: NA
Text: (Termination of Levy) Bill 1986; For the remain-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing stages, until 4.15 p.m. this day.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) Dairy Industry Stabilization Levy (Termination

Speaker: NA
Text: of Levy) Bill 1986. For the remaining stages,

Speaker: NA
Text: until 4.20 p.m. this day.

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) Dairy Legislation (Transitional Provisions and

Speaker: NA
Text: Consequential Amendments) Bill 1966; For the

Speaker: NA
Text: remaining stages, until 4,25 p,m, this day.

Speaker: NA
Text: In so moving, I say that the Opposition and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government members are aware, of course, that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government has had an additional discipline

Speaker: NA
Text: placed on it in terms of getting the business

Speaker: NA
Text: through the House. We are not setting a partic-

Speaker: NA
Text: ularly onerous task in terms of legislation that is

Speaker: NA
Text: coming before the House. The business we have

Speaker: NA
Text: set down this week and next week is of partic-

Speaker: NA
Text: ular urgency because the coalition has decided

Speaker: NA
Text: that it will not deal with any legislation in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate which the Senate receives after next

Speaker: NA
Text: Thursday. That is the decision that the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion has to sit with. All the business set down

Speaker: NA
Text: for this week and all the business that is set

Speaker: NA
Text: down for next week will have to be completed

Speaker: NA
Text: by next Thursday night because the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion-the Liberal Party of Australia and the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Party of Australia-have decided to

Speaker: NA
Text: break another convention, and that is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate will not deal with legislation which passes

Speaker: NA
Text: through the House of Representatives after next

Speaker: NA
Text: Thursday night. It is a matter of urgency that

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government must deal with the legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: set down. It may be that in the next session the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition will decide that it will deal only with

Speaker: NA
Text: matters that go through the House of Represen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tatives in the first four weeks of the sitting, in

Speaker: NA
Text: which case we will have to compress all the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation into the first four weeks. The Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition should have realised what it was doing

Speaker: NA
Text: when it took the decision, which imposes a new

Speaker: NA
Text: restriction on the Government. It will just have

Speaker: NA
Text: to live with the consequences. The consequences

Speaker: NA
Text: of its decision are that members of the House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives will have less time to debate

Speaker: NA
Text: these Bills than they otherwise would have had.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: New England-Manager of

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition Business) (10.16) - It had not been

Speaker: NA
Text: my intention to respond, but the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House ( Mr Young) has stated an entirely incor-

Speaker: NA
Text: rect version of the facts. It should be understood

Speaker: NA
Text: that this G;)vernment cannot get its act together.

Speaker: NA
Text: All that babble and rabble on the other side who

Speaker: NA
Text: are temporarily sitting on the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: benches should understand that if those few

Speaker: NA
Text: sitting on the front bench cannot get their legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lative program right, if all those Caucus commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tees cannot conclude their deliberations

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficiently early for them to come into this

Speaker: NA
Text: place and be considered adequately so that they

Speaker: NA
Text: can be passed by the Senate in a reasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: time, they can expect that restraints such as

Speaker: NA
Text: those in the resolution to which the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House referred will continue to be imposed

Speaker: NA
Text: on them.

Speaker: NA
Text: The purpose of the Senate resolution is to tell

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government to pull its finger out and to get

Speaker: NA
Text: its work done. What the Government is doing is

Speaker: NA
Text: essentially sitting on its hands. It is not prepared

Speaker: NA
Text: to undertake a proper and correct basis for

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration of serious matters which affect the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Australia. The only way in which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate and this place can adequately consider

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation and get their work done is for mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of the Government, instead of tripping away

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas, to stay in Australia. We have the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister ( Mr Hawke) out in the boondocks of

Speaker: NA
Text: China; I am delighted to see the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Immigration and Ethnic Affairs ( Mr Hurford)

Speaker: NA
Text: here today, but he has been away; the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Foreign Affairs ( Mr Hayden) is away. If

Speaker: NA
Text: they do not want to have guillotines, Ministers

Speaker: NA
Text: should stay in Australia, conclude their work

Speaker: NA
Text: and give the Parliamentary Counsel instructions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nobody in this place would then be in the

Speaker: NA
Text: position of having to have such a ridiculous

Speaker: NA
Text: guillotine motion as this before them for consid-

Speaker: NA
Text: eration. The only reason for the guillotine is that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the House has not been able to

Speaker: NA
Text: marshal his troops. We know that the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister has lost control. We know that the

Speaker: NA
Text: telephone has taken over from the Cabinet table.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that no longer are matters of very

Speaker: NA
Text: significant public importance being considered in

Speaker: NA
Text: the way they should be. As far as this House is

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned, we are not prepared to take the

Speaker: NA
Text: consequences and have guillotines imposed on us

Speaker: NA
Text: simply because the Government is not doing its

Speaker: NA
Text: job adequately, quickly, or in time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The purpose of this motion is not in any way

Speaker: NA
Text: related to the suggestions the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House has put forward; it is entirely related to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government not getting its act together early

Speaker: NA
Text: enough, not getting the legislative instructions to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Parliamentary Counsel on time. We are here

Speaker: NA
Text: this morning just because the Government could

Speaker: NA
Text: not get its act together. Consequently, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: a motion which will give minimal time for de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bating a very serious package of Bills. We do

Speaker: NA
Text: not accept the admonition from the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House, and we commend the Senate for

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to bring the Government under some sort

Speaker: NA
Text: of disciplinary approach.

Speaker: Mr SCHOLES
Text: Corio-Minister for Territo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ries) (10.19)-Having listened to the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the National Party and Manager of Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: Business ( Mr Sinclair), we can understand why

Speaker: NA
Text: those opposite are in opposition. At least he had

Speaker: NA
Text: the common decency to laugh while he was

Speaker: NA
Text: making that stupid statement.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: O'Connor) (10.20)-Madam

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker--

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Wright-Are you cartoon time?

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-Order!

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: You will never make a car-

Speaker: NA
Text: toon, son; you are so irrelevant. Madam

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker--

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-Order! Is the honoura-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble member for O'Connor speaking to the mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion before the Chair?

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: Yes, certainly, Madam

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker. The Leader of the House ( Mr Young)

Speaker: NA
Text: has said that debate on these measures will be

Speaker: NA
Text: curtailed because of decisions taken in the Sen-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate. These measures are the result of an an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nouncement in this Parliament on 19 September

Speaker: NA
Text: 1985. Furthermore, you got your instructions

Speaker: NA
Text: from Bill Kelty on 3 February 1985 when he

Speaker: NA
Text: made his speech to the Socialist Forum and he

Speaker: NA
Text: spelt out the tax measures chapter and verse.

Speaker: NA
Text: You have known since 3 February 1985 what

Speaker: NA
Text: you were going to do, and you still have not got

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislation passed. That is a fact: You got

Speaker: NA
Text: your instructions on 3 February 1985. You can

Speaker: NA
Text: read in the Sydney Morning Herald that Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: Kelty spelt out his instructions to you at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Socialist Forum in Melbourne. Why are you

Speaker: NA
Text: wasting all that time getting your Bills together?

Speaker: NA
Text: The capital gains tax has been imposed on Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians--

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr O'Keefe-I take a point of order, Madam

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker. These comments are not only irrele-

Speaker: NA
Text: vant; they are mendacious.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-Order! The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member wiJJ resume his seat.

Speaker: NA
Text: Government members interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-Order! If honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members on my right will be quiet, they will

Speaker: NA
Text: save some time.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: Madam Speaker, the capital

Speaker: NA
Text: gains tax has been imposed on Australians since

Speaker: NA
Text: 19 September. This legislation has just seen the

Speaker: NA
Text: light of day, and you are going to use this sort

Speaker: NA
Text: of excuse. You could have brought it in on the

Speaker: NA
Text: first day of this sitting. You have had since 19

Speaker: NA
Text: September. In fact, I repeat that you have had

Speaker: NA
Text: since 3 February 1985, when Bill Kelty told you

Speaker: NA
Text: what you were going to do. That was five months

Speaker: NA
Text: before your tax summit, when your blooming

Speaker: NA
Text: arrogant Treasurer ( Mr Keating) told you he

Speaker: NA
Text: had his cart running on four wheels. That was

Speaker: NA
Text: the situation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Robert Brown-I take a point of order,

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam Speaker.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: Is it hurting, Robert? Is it

Speaker: NA
Text: hurting?

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-Order! If the House will

Speaker: NA
Text: be quiet, the Chair might hear the point of order

Speaker: NA
Text: from the honourable member for Charlton.

Speaker: NA
Text: Members on my right are not assisting the Chair.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Robert Brown-Madam Speaker, my point

Speaker: NA
Text: of order concerns the fact that the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for O'Connor is casting very serious

Speaker: NA
Text: aspersions against you as Speaker, because he is

Speaker: NA
Text: saying that 'you' received 'your' instructions from

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Kelty.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER -Order! The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member will resume his seat.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: Thank you, Madam Speaker.

Speaker: NA
Text: Might I repeat: So you did. BiJJ Kelty laid your

Speaker: NA
Text: instructions down on 3 February 1985.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-Order! The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for O'Connor should speak through the

Speaker: NA
Text: Chair.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Robert Brown-I take a point of order,

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam Speaker. My point of order is quite

Speaker: NA
Text: clear. Honourable members are required to speak

Speaker: NA
Text: to and through the Chair.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-I have just reminded the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for O'Connor to speak

Speaker: NA
Text: through the Chair.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Robert Brown-The honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: should be required to withdraw.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-The honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber will resume his seat.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: Madam Speaker, let me ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dress it to you-and I am sure that you did not

Speaker: NA
Text: get your instructions at that time. I am referring

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Ministers and others who have had all

Speaker: NA
Text: that time to bring this important legislation down.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Treasurer gave us his brown paper bag

Speaker: NA
Text: lecture again today. Where do they think their

Speaker: NA
Text: fringe benefit taxes are going to end up? They

Speaker: NA
Text: will end up right in that brown paper lunch bag.

Speaker: NA
Text: It will be the working people who pay them. Do

Speaker: NA
Text: they think the big companies are going to lower-

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-Order! Will the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for O'Connor speak to the motion

Speaker: NA
Text: before the Chair?

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: Yes, Madam Speaker. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have suddenly been put under all this pressure

Speaker: NA
Text: to try to carry out the business of the Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. We have only been here for the last three

Speaker: NA
Text: months! During all that time we have been given

Speaker: NA
Text: very little legislation. All of a sudden, all these

Speaker: NA
Text: very difficult things have hit the people of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. We would like to explain to Labor mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers that their fringe benefits tax will end up in

Speaker: NA
Text: those brown paper lunch bags, because the big

Speaker: NA
Text: companies will increase their prices. They will

Speaker: NA
Text: not reduce their dividends; they cannot afford to

Speaker: NA
Text: with the company takeover situation that Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: members now tolerate. They will do that. The

Speaker: NA
Text: point I am making is--

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-Will the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member stick to the matter before the Chair?

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: The point I am making is that

Speaker: NA
Text: it is in Labor members' own interests to give us

Speaker: NA
Text: the time to debate these matters. They first

Speaker: NA
Text: knew on 3 February 1985 that they were going

Speaker: NA
Text: to enact this legislation. As I am worried that

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Charlton is going to

Speaker: NA
Text: get tired jumping up and down, I will give him

Speaker: NA
Text: a break and sit down.

Speaker: Mr YOUNG
Text: Port Adelaide-Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House) (10.25)-in reply-It is interesting to

Speaker: NA
Text: see how the Manager of Opposition Business,

Speaker: NA
Text: the right honourable member for New England

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Sinclair), and the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: O'Connor ( Mr Tuckey) have done everything

Speaker: NA
Text: possible to stop their colleagues from the Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional Party of Australia talking about this

Speaker: NA
Text: ying legislation. We could have been debating it

Speaker: NA
Text: 20 minutes ago. The Opposition has used up all

Speaker: NA
Text: this time because it knows that the essence of

Speaker: NA
Text: this debate will be a vote of congratulations for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Primary Industry ( Mr Kerin),

Speaker: NA
Text: who has done such an excellent job in the dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, the sugar industry and the beef indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try. He is the best Minister for Primary Industry

Speaker: NA
Text: that this country has ever seen.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me tell honourable members something

Speaker: NA
Text: else. When members of the coalition in the Sen-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate decided not to deal with new legislation after

Speaker: NA
Text: next Thursday night they did not tell this mob

Speaker: NA
Text: here; they just voted on it in the Senate and told

Speaker: NA
Text: them the result. So when the Manager of Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position Business said that he supports his col-

Speaker: NA
Text: leagues in the Senate, he supports them de facto,

Speaker: NA
Text: because he was not asked for his views. He was

Speaker: NA
Text: told what they would do. This is the role the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition gave the Senate in 1975: It placed

Speaker: NA
Text: the Senate on a pedestal by saying that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate is more important than the House of

Speaker: NA
Text: government, the House of Representatives.

Speaker: NA
Text: This session of Parliament has been a far

Speaker: NA
Text: busier session than the Fraser Government ever

Speaker: NA
Text: had. It will sit for 11 weeks and it will deal with

Speaker: NA
Text: a multiplicity of legislation, something which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Fraser Government never did. I will tell honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members something else. I can recommend

Speaker: NA
Text: some reading to honourable members over the

Speaker: NA
Text: weekend. I am reading Patrick O'Brien's book

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Liberal Party of Australia and I recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mend it to everybody. I have just got to the

Speaker: NA
Text: stage when, after the 1983 election, Malcolm

Speaker: NA
Text: wrote to Reg Withers apologising for sacking

Speaker: NA
Text: him. Reg said: Too bloody late, mate'. I suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: that honourable members opposite read that book

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Liberal Party so that they can see how it

Speaker: NA
Text: carried out its policies as promised by the gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernments of 1975-77 and 1977-80.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition has deliberately taken up the

Speaker: NA
Text: time of the House. This matter could have been

Speaker: NA
Text: dealt with by three minutes past 10 but the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition decided that it did not want to put

Speaker: NA
Text: up all its donkeys from cockies corner to argue

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Minister for Primary Industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Cowan-Madam Speaker, I raise a point

Speaker: NA
Text: of order. We do not mind being called the don-

Speaker: NA
Text: keys from cockies corner but we do want to be

Speaker: NA
Text: recognised as people who look after the farmers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-Order! There is no point

Speaker: NA
Text: of order.

Speaker: Mr YOUNG
Text: I was out on farms for only

Speaker: NA
Text: six years; I did more work then than all of those

Speaker: NA
Text: dair- blokes put together. At least I was working;

Speaker: NA
Text: those blokes were sitting on the bales watching

Speaker: NA
Text: me. I am sure that we can accommodate all

Speaker: NA
Text: those who want to speak on the dairying legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation; we have until twenty-five minutes past

Speaker: NA
Text: four to debate it. As for the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for O'Connor, as Arfur would say to Terry,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'He's a bit radio rental'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: DAIRY PRODUCE BILL 1986

Speaker: NA
Text: [COGNATE BILLS:

Speaker: NA
Text: DAIRY PRODUCE LEVY (No.1) BILL

Speaker: NA
Text: DAIRY PRODUCE LEVY (No.2) BILL

Speaker: NA
Text: DAIRYING INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND

Speaker: NA
Text: PROMOTION LEVY (TERMINATION OF

Speaker: NA
Text: LEVY) BILL 1986

Speaker: NA
Text: DAIRY INDUSTRY STABILIZATION

Speaker: NA
Text: LEVY (TERMINATION OF LEVY) BILL

Speaker: NA
Text: DAIRY LEGISLATION (TRANSITIONAL

Speaker: NA
Text: PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL

Speaker: NA
Text: AMENDMENTS) BILL 1986J

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 7 May, on motion by

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Kerin:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-I understand that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: the wish of the House to debate order of the

Speaker: NA
Text: day No.1, the Dairy Produce Bill 1986, concur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rently with orders of the day Nos 2 to 6, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Dairy Produce Levy (No.1) Bill 1986, the Dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: Produce Levy (No.2) Bill 1986, the Dairying

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry Research and Promotion Levy (Termi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nation of Levy) Bill 1986, the Dairy Industry

Speaker: NA
Text: Stabilization Levy (Termination of Levy) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 1986 and the Dairy Legislation (Transitional

Speaker: NA
Text: Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 1986. There being no objection, the Chair will

Speaker: NA
Text: allow that course to be followed.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: Gwydir) (10.30)-The Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion does not oppose the Dairy Produce Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 1986, the Dairy Produce Levy (No.1) Bill 1986,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Dairy Produce Levy (No.2) Bill 1986, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Dairying Industry Research and Promotion Levy

Speaker: NA
Text: (Termination of Levy) Bill 1986, the Dairy In-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry Stabilization Levy (Termination of Levy)

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill 1986 and the Dairy Legislation (Transitional

Speaker: NA
Text: Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 1986. Last May the Opposition took a strong

Speaker: NA
Text: stand in defence of the Australian dairy industry,

Speaker: NA
Text: a stand which is fully vindicated by these revised

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy marketing Bills. The return of these Bills

Speaker: NA
Text: in a form more acceptable to the dairying indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try is a salutary political lesson for the Hawke

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Government. Honourable members will

Speaker: NA
Text: recall that the faked breakthrough in the talks

Speaker: NA
Text: on a national marketing plan two days before

Speaker: NA
Text: the Victorian election dissolved into thin air

Speaker: NA
Text: after the Cain Government was re-elected by a

Speaker: NA
Text: bare margin.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Tim Fischer-It was a sham.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: It was a sham.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hawker-It was a con, a real con.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: It was a disgrace. It was the

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest political con trick ever played upon

Speaker: NA
Text: people in that State. In its place came a dracon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ian set of Bills which threatened to decimate the

Speaker: NA
Text: $340m export sector of our dairy industry and

Speaker: NA
Text: send hundreds, if not thousands, of producers to

Speaker: NA
Text: the wall. No wonder this country is in such

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulty with balance of trade

Speaker: NA
Text: der the Treasurer ( Mr Keating) is talking about

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia being likely to become a banana re-

Speaker: NA
Text: public unless it improves its performance. When

Speaker: NA
Text: a government pays such scant regard to an ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: port industry and treats the seventh largest ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: port industry of this country in the way in which

Speaker: NA
Text: it attempted to treat it last year with its dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation, there is no doubt that it has no real

Speaker: NA
Text: concern about the export sector of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: If that legislation had passed the Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: it would have gravely impaired the efficiency of

Speaker: NA
Text: an important domestic and export industry which

Speaker: NA
Text: has already rationalised from 49,000 to 19,000

Speaker: NA
Text: farms in 30 years. It would have created untold

Speaker: NA
Text: social hardship to thousands of dairy farming

Speaker: NA
Text: families, but clearly this Government could not

Speaker: NA
Text: have cared less because they were only farmers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition sought the removal of anti-in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry provisions in the Bills last May, and with

Speaker: NA
Text: the support of the Australian Democrats in an-

Speaker: NA
Text: other place we stopped the so-called Kerin plan

Speaker: NA
Text: in its tracks.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Cunningham-Ha, hal What a joke!

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: That is true. The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member laughs. The chairman of a parliamen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary committee of the Australian Labor Party is

Speaker: NA
Text: running around the countryside trying to shore

Speaker: NA
Text: up some confidence in a Party that has kicked

Speaker: NA
Text: in the teeth the farm industries of Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: causing so much hardship and heartbreak

Speaker: NA
Text: amongst the familIes that are struggling to make

Speaker: NA
Text: ends meet. Our action gave the industry two

Speaker: NA
Text: vital breaks. It gave some breathing space to the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. The industry also had a far stronger

Speaker: NA
Text: hand with which to go back to the negotiating

Speaker: NA
Text: table with the Hawke Labor Government. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition and the Democrats saved producers

Speaker: NA
Text: tens of millions of dollars through its actions in

Speaker: NA
Text: this Parliament. This could not have come at a

Speaker: NA
Text: more important time for the industry. This year

Speaker: NA
Text: soon dairy farmers will each earn an average net

Speaker: NA
Text: income of $4,400 for their 12 months' work-a

Speaker: NA
Text: quarter of average weekly earnings.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Nehl-Not enough.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: As the honourable member says,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is not enough. Dairy farmers' incomes will be

Speaker: NA
Text: at levels that the Australian Council of Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: Unions would not accept in a fit. Both the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition and the industry have every reason

Speaker: NA
Text: to be pleased with our achievement on behalf of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian dairy industry, the manufacturers

Speaker: NA
Text: and the employees that work within the indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try. In a letter to me this week the President of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: deficits. No won- Pat Rowley, told me:

Speaker: NA
Text: In summary, the legislation now before the Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is not perfect but is vastly superior to that which

Speaker: NA
Text: was before us this time last year.

Speaker: NA
Text: In money terms, it will be worth tens of millions of

Speaker: NA
Text: dollars more to the industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: On behalf of the Australian Dairy Farmers Federa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion I would like to thank you for the part you played

Speaker: NA
Text: in bringing this about.

Speaker: NA
Text: At this point, it is appropriate that I pay

Speaker: NA
Text: strong tribute to the untiring efforts of Mr Row-

Speaker: NA
Text: ley, his predecessor, Mr Bennett, and the count-

Speaker: NA
Text: less other industry leaders and executive officers

Speaker: NA
Text: who have given so much of their time and re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sources to negotiate a more acceptable market-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing plan on the industry's behalf. Their job has

Speaker: NA
Text: not been easy. They have had to marry the

Speaker: NA
Text: vastly different interests of producers in various

Speaker: NA
Text: States-a job which was made ever so much

Speaker: NA
Text: harder by the antagonistic attitudes of some La-

Speaker: NA
Text: bor State governments. The efforts of these in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry chiefs have been, simply, quite outstanding.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, the Hawke Labor Government

Speaker: NA
Text: can take little credit. It has played the dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers as political pawns and fools. The farm-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers were led to believe that they had won their

Speaker: NA
Text: long-awaited agreement between the State gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernments when Premier Cain intervened in a

Speaker: NA
Text: blaze of publicity, two days before his election.

Speaker: NA
Text: Once again, primary producers have found that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Labor Party cannot be trusted.

Speaker: NA
Text: Less than three weeks after the Victorian elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, the farmers were dumped.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Federal Minister for Primary Industry

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Kerin) claimed in a stroke of blinding en-

Speaker: NA
Text: lightenment that the plan settled three weeks

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier on the eve of the Victorian election had

Speaker: NA
Text: some 'internal inconsistencies'. That plan had

Speaker: NA
Text: been under negotiation for two years! This Hawke

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Government stands condemned for its

Speaker: NA
Text: blatant expediency at the cost of the producers.

Speaker: NA
Text: No sooner was the industry dumped than the

Speaker: NA
Text: Kerin plan hit the Parliament. I cannot recall a

Speaker: NA
Text: more savage, anti-industry piece of legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: than the Kerin plan in its original form. Produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers were given no time to adjust to the sudden

Speaker: NA
Text: abandonment of mechanisms which had been in

Speaker: NA
Text: place for many years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hawker-Less than two months.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: Exactly. The stated aim was to

Speaker: NA
Text: cut production, but the real thrust was to dampen

Speaker: NA
Text: an inflation rate now running at three times the

Speaker: NA
Text: Western world average by reducing the domestic

Speaker: NA
Text: price of dairy products.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: That is what it is-a consumers'

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill to satisfy the provisions of the accord. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is what it is all about.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Cunningham-Ha, hal

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: The honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: MCMillan can smile; he can laugh. He is a

Speaker: NA
Text: decent fellow, but how can he live with people

Speaker: NA
Text: who are ripping the insides out of those good

Speaker: NA
Text: people he represents down in the MCMillan elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate? Let me remind him and the House that

Speaker: NA
Text: a bottle of fresh milk, delivered daily to the

Speaker: NA
Text: home if required, still costs less than 50c.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1970 as a base of 100, the price of milk has

Speaker: NA
Text: risen to 341 and butter to 260 in 15 years. The

Speaker: NA
Text: consumer price index over that time has risen to

Speaker: NA
Text: 389. In other words, the dairy industry has taken

Speaker: NA
Text: a real price cut over the past 15 years.

Speaker: NA
Text: I refuse to accept that the efficient farm in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustries should be attacked in order to cut La-

Speaker: NA
Text: bor's inflation rate. We will fight such moves

Speaker: NA
Text: the way. Last year, in an act of conciliation,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Dairy Farmers Federation agreed to

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiate on the Minister's plan. It is pleasing

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Opposition's stand on the three major

Speaker: NA
Text: areas of contention with the original Kerin plan

Speaker: NA
Text: has borne fruit. Two of our amendments sought

Speaker: NA
Text: an orderly phase-out of product levies. This has

Speaker: NA
Text: been achieved. We also sought to delay the

Speaker: NA
Text: abolition of export pooling for two years.

Speaker: NA
Text: By deferring the Bills we have achieved 15

Speaker: NA
Text: months, which has at least given producers some

Speaker: NA
Text: time to anticipate the changes and adjust their

Speaker: NA
Text: on-farm planning. Equally, manufacturers and

Speaker: NA
Text: exporters have had the chance to study the

Speaker: NA
Text: changes and adjust their decisions accordingly.

Speaker: NA
Text: This may be seen in part in recent co-operative

Speaker: NA
Text: mergers, notably in Victoria. Since moving those

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments, the Opposition has consistently

Speaker: NA
Text: supported the industry on other remaining mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters, including an increase in the domestic value

Speaker: NA
Text: of leviable products and the insertion of a safety

Speaker: NA
Text: clause governing the all milk levy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under this Government domestic product

Speaker: NA
Text: prices have remained frozen for four years. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think the last rise was in December 1982. Yet

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government, with its policy of indexation

Speaker: NA
Text: of wages, with what it says is its concern for the

Speaker: NA
Text: working people of Australia, was prepared to let

Speaker: NA
Text: prices in the dairy industry stay pegged for a

Speaker: NA
Text: four-year period. No wonder there has been so

Speaker: NA
Text: much antagonism and anger. When the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister ( Mr Hawke) went to Echuca and met

Speaker: NA
Text: a dairy farming family, no wonder he came back

Speaker: NA
Text: emotionally distressed. He was in the home of

Speaker: NA
Text: that Echuca family. He could see the difficulties

Speaker: NA
Text: under which they were struggling. The Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister was moved--

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Nehl-But only while the cameras were

Speaker: NA
Text: on him.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: I would give him more credit

Speaker: NA
Text: than that, because he came back and made some

Speaker: NA
Text: rather irrational decisions. In a state of emotion,

Speaker: NA
Text: he sacked the Secretary to the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Primary Industry. If he had sacked the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Primary Industry he might have done justice,

Speaker: NA
Text: but he sacked the Secretary-he got rid of him.

Speaker: NA
Text: He did that to try to salve his conscience. I

Speaker: NA
Text: Using think his conscience was moved after he had

Speaker: NA
Text: spoken to the family and seen the distress in

Speaker: NA
Text: their eyes and the rather sad circumstances of

Speaker: NA
Text: their lives.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under this Government domestic product

Speaker: NA
Text: prices have remained frozen for four years. The

Speaker: NA
Text: industry will not forget that. In this legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: modest price rises have been achieved of about

Speaker: NA
Text: all 5 per cent for butter and 8 per cent for cheese.

Speaker: NA
Text: the Big deal! That is the only increase over a four-

Speaker: NA
Text: year period. But the industry is thankful for

Speaker: NA
Text: small mercies from this lot. The comfort or

Speaker: NA
Text: safety clause was fought all the way by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. The clause is designed to protect

Speaker: NA
Text: those States which will be net payers into an all-

Speaker: NA
Text: milk levy fund should sections of the industry

Speaker: NA
Text: attempt to trade manufacturing milk interstate

Speaker: NA
Text: on to liquid milk markets. As late as 25 Febru-

Speaker: NA
Text: ary, the date of the Minister's so-called settle-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of negotiations on these Bills, he was still

Speaker: NA
Text: kicking and squirming, although he refused to

Speaker: NA
Text: go personally into print. I quote from the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Financial Review of the following

Speaker: NA
Text: morning:

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Kerin's spokesman-

Speaker: NA
Text: whoever that was-

Speaker: NA
Text: said that there were technical problems associated with

Speaker: NA
Text: writing market protection into the legislation, because

Speaker: NA
Text: infringements of markets are hard to define legally.

Speaker: NA
Text: To that I say: What rot! All States support the

Speaker: NA
Text: inclusion of clause 6 in the Dairy Produce Levy

Speaker: NA
Text: (No. I) Bill. We can only speculate as to why

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister reacted in such a negative manner

Speaker: NA
Text: to this request for a levy safeguard. This legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation has not obtained the full approval of the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry but, under the circumstances, it has

Speaker: NA
Text: been accepted by the Dairy Farmers Federation

Speaker: NA
Text: as a compromise. The Opposition is not dissat-

Speaker: NA
Text: isfied with the final outcome. Clearly, the Bills

Speaker: NA
Text: are preferable to the Minister's threat at one

Speaker: NA
Text: point to abandon all the legislation and let the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry crash. The benefit of the Opposition's

Speaker: NA
Text: actions can be summarised in these words: Some

Speaker: NA
Text: measure of stability and predictability.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Beddall-Unnecessarily delayed.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: I think I covered that. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: said that if the Government's legislation had

Speaker: NA
Text: gone through both Houses last year the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for MCMillan ( Mr Cunningham)

Speaker: NA
Text: would certainly not have been back in this Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament after the next election. There would

Speaker: NA
Text: have been a wholesale crisis in the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy industry. Farmers would have walked off

Speaker: NA
Text: their farms and workers would have walked out

Speaker: NA
Text: of the dairy factories. Jobs would have been lost

Speaker: NA
Text: and the sixth or seventh largest export industry

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia would have been decimated. That

Speaker: NA
Text: was the way the Government would have treated

Speaker: NA
Text: them, because they were farmers-because they

Speaker: NA
Text: were farmers and not members of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Council of Trade Unions. The industry will now

Speaker: NA
Text: be better exposed to world markets. Producers

Speaker: NA
Text: will maintain a self-help arrangement to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that the oversupplied world product markets

Speaker: NA
Text: and corrupted world prices do not undermine

Speaker: NA
Text: the manufacturing or the product sector. Stabil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity is likely to come through a levy on all milk

Speaker: NA
Text: which cannot exceed 45c per kilogram butter-

Speaker: NA
Text: fat. This will replace current stabilisation levies.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would expect that the operative levy rate,

Speaker: NA
Text: to be struck next month by the Australian Dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporation with advice from the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Dairy Industry Advisory Council, to be in the

Speaker: NA
Text: vicinity of 1.5 to 1.7c per litre, depending on the

Speaker: NA
Text: butterfat content. These levy proceeds are paid

Speaker: NA
Text: into a market support fund that will be distrib-

Speaker: NA
Text: uted by the Corporation on the basis of an

Speaker: NA
Text: assessed 30 per cent of the average export price

Speaker: NA
Text: for declared dairy produce over the coming year.

Speaker: NA
Text: While this will give stability to the export sector,

Speaker: NA
Text: it also will introduce a new reward for initiative.

Speaker: NA
Text: The exporter will receive the 30 per cent pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: mium-say, $750 a tonne of butter-on top of

Speaker: NA
Text: the world price. This is eminently sensible at a

Speaker: NA
Text: time when export markets have been saturated

Speaker: NA
Text: with dairy produce from other suppliers-pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce which, in some cases, enjoys subsidies ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceeding 100 per cent. Europe alone holds some

Speaker: NA
Text: 100 million tonnes of butter in store, some of

Speaker: NA
Text: which is more than two years old.

Speaker: NA
Text: That brings me to the next point that I want

Speaker: NA
Text: to raise, because I think that this legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: needs to be put in the context of what has

Speaker: NA
Text: happened in the last day. This morning I have

Speaker: NA
Text: been informed that there has been a sudden

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in the level of European payments for

Speaker: NA
Text: the export of cheese into the Japanese market.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Japanese market is Australia's most impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant export market. The increase in European

Speaker: NA
Text: payments will drop the price of cheese into the

Speaker: NA
Text: Japanese market by at least $100 a tonne. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: a change which will be of great concern to the

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing side of the dairy industry and, I

Speaker: NA
Text: am sure, of great concern to those manufactur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing industries in Victoria. We are told that this

Speaker: NA
Text: has been done to compensate the Europeans for

Speaker: NA
Text: the exchange rate movements between European

Speaker: NA
Text: currencies and the Japanese yen that have oc-

Speaker: NA
Text: curred in recent months.

Speaker: NA
Text: Prior to this week the European subsidy on

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 lines of cheese-danbo, edam, fontal, fontina,

Speaker: NA
Text: gouda and a whole list of others-was running

Speaker: NA
Text: at 326 European currency units per tonne. This

Speaker: NA
Text: week the subsidy has leapt through the roof. For

Speaker: NA
Text: those 10 lines of cheese, the export refund is

Speaker: NA
Text: now 774 ECUs per tonne. This represents an

Speaker: NA
Text: increase this week of 448 ECUs or 137 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Australian dollars the subsidy to the Europe-

Speaker: NA
Text: ans has increased from $440 a tonne to $1,043

Speaker: NA
Text: a tonne. For the crucial cheddar cheese line,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is the most important export line to Ja-

Speaker: NA
Text: pan, the news is still worse. From Monday the

Speaker: NA
Text: refund to the Europeans has rocketed from 332

Speaker: NA
Text: to 905 ECUs per tonne. In Australian dollars

Speaker: NA
Text: that is an increase from $435 a tonne to $1,221

Speaker: NA
Text: a tonne.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr [an Robinson-Is that the success of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister's visit?

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: It could well be. This is an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease in the restitution of 180 per cent. We

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot hope to compete against the devastating

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidies of other nations unless this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment acts immediately to get off the farmers'

Speaker: NA
Text: backs. It seems extraordinary, after the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's recent visit to Europe and his meeting

Speaker: NA
Text: with the European Economic Community, that

Speaker: NA
Text: we sho-ld have this devastating news that will

Speaker: NA
Text: have a very serious effect on the returns likely

Speaker: NA
Text: to be received by the manufacturing sector in

Speaker: NA
Text: this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Cunningham-How much has our cheese

Speaker: NA
Text: gone up in Japan in the past six months?

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: It will drop by at least $100 a

Speaker: NA
Text: tonne and that will have a very serious effect on

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member's industry in Victoria.

Speaker: NA
Text: So it is no laughing matter. If the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member thinks it is a laughing matter, I suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: that he get in touch with the Australian Dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporation and find out for himself how con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned it is. This week's news of the European

Speaker: NA
Text: attitude pours further cold water on suggestions

Speaker: NA
Text: of a breakthrough from the recent ministerial

Speaker: NA
Text: talks of the Prime Minister. The Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has made little progress in its negotiations with

Speaker: NA
Text: our trading partners.

Speaker: NA
Text: Instead of the Minister trying to be a smart

Speaker: NA
Text: ass and releasing the Opposition's discussion

Speaker: NA
Text: per, as he did at the New South Wales Dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: Farmers' Association conference in Sydney the

Speaker: NA
Text: day before yesterday, he would be wise to qui-

Speaker: NA
Text: etly read the policy points in that paper and to

Speaker: NA
Text: help the farmers by reducing the costs that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is imposing upon the inputs being

Speaker: NA
Text: used by farmers. I think it has backfired on him.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not think I could ever have attracted the

Speaker: NA
Text: sort of publicity for the policy that he has,

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the way in which he released it. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister said that the primary industry policy

Speaker: NA
Text: fell off the back of a truck, but he launched it

Speaker: NA
Text: off the back of a truck to the media in Sydney.

Speaker: NA
Text: He should not only launch it, but also read it

Speaker: NA
Text: and take from it to try to overcome some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: very serious problems confronting the farm sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor, to reduce their costs of production, at least

Speaker: NA
Text: to help them become more competitive against

Speaker: NA
Text: the actions of the European Economic Commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity such as I have mentioned this morning. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is time that his Government took meaningful

Speaker: NA
Text: action to restore what it has taken away in

Speaker: NA
Text: Budgets and to alter the whole thrust of its

Speaker: NA
Text: monetary, wages and tax policies and the way

Speaker: NA
Text: in which those policies are bringing great bur-

Speaker: NA
Text: dens of cost upon the agricultural sector. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is no other answer at the moment. The time for

Speaker: NA
Text: a lot of talk and nonsense has passed. What is

Speaker: NA
Text: needed now is action.

Speaker: NA
Text: I mention also that under the new arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments that will be introduced under this legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion further assistance will be given to the

Speaker: NA
Text: exporting sector of the industry. A 30 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: premium will be paid over and above the world

Speaker: NA
Text: price, which is established by a formula spelt

Speaker: NA
Text: out in the legislation. I believe that a degree of

Speaker: NA
Text: stability will be given to the manufacturing or

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy produce end of the industry in this legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation, provided the Government takes the nec-

Speaker: NA
Text: essary decisions to help reduce the costs of the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry in the production area and, secondly,

Speaker: NA
Text: continues very strong negotiations to try to bring

Speaker: NA
Text: about more rationality in the international trade

Speaker: NA
Text: area.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am pleased that the Commonwealth under-

Speaker: NA
Text: writing is maintained, even if it is at 85 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: instead of 90 per cent of the long term average

Speaker: NA
Text: export price. A separate new potholing mecha-

Speaker: NA
Text: nism will be funded by the industry through its

Speaker: NA
Text: Market Support Fund. The potholing comple-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments underwriting in that, until now, the un-

Speaker: NA
Text: derwriting has been triggered only when the full

Speaker: NA
Text: year export returns have dropped below 90 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of a three-year average return. This has

Speaker: NA
Text: meant that severe but short term falls in export

Speaker: NA
Text: returns have not been compensated if the full

Speaker: NA
Text: pa- year average prices remained above the 90 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent level. The potholing mechanism will effec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tively counter short, sharp cuts to returns. Pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments from the Market Support Fund will be

Speaker: NA
Text: triggered if the export return temporarily falls

Speaker: NA
Text: below 85 per cent of the Bureau of Agricultural

Speaker: NA
Text: Economics' estimate of the long term average

Speaker: NA
Text: price.

Speaker: NA
Text: I note that the Minister has not specified

Speaker: NA
Text: operative rates for the four levies which will be

Speaker: NA
Text: struck under the new legislation. I understand

Speaker: NA
Text: that the operative rates will be struck early next

Speaker: NA
Text: month, within the maximum rates of 45c per

Speaker: NA
Text: kilogram butterfat for the market support fund,

Speaker: NA
Text: 5.5c for promotion, 2.5c for research and 2.5c

Speaker: NA
Text: towards the operation of the Australian Dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporation. Several complaints have been lodged

Speaker: NA
Text: with me over the industry's decision to use but-

Speaker: NA
Text: terfat content rather than volume as the levy

Speaker: NA
Text: base. Against these views, experience overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: has shown that milk can be de-watered in an

Speaker: NA
Text: effort to cut levy payments. As the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Dairy Farmers Federation points out, it is logical

Speaker: NA
Text: that the levy should be imposed on the same

Speaker: NA
Text: units in which farmers are paid. There is growing

Speaker: NA
Text: support at a national industry level for a shift

Speaker: NA
Text: towards a levy base which combines milk-fat and

Speaker: NA
Text: proteins and which may prove to be the most

Speaker: NA
Text: equitable solution. I will be watching progress

Speaker: NA
Text: on this matter with interest.

Speaker: NA
Text: In summary, these Bills are far better than

Speaker: NA
Text: those which the Minister sought to ram through

Speaker: NA
Text: the Parliament last year. It is both pleasing and

Speaker: NA
Text: gratifying that the actions taken by the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion have resulted in more equity for this impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant industry. There can be no doubt that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition has given dairy farmers new stability

Speaker: NA
Text: and predictability within their industry. This

Speaker: NA
Text: islation is a lesson to the Hawke Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: It cannot treat Australian farmers with con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tempt, as it has in the past, and expect to escape

Speaker: NA
Text: the consequences.

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn briefly to the other main aspect of

Speaker: NA
Text: Bills; that is, the changes to the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporation. In short, the ADC is to be restruc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tured in line with reforms to the statutory mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: keting authorities as announced by the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: on 29 January. On previous occasions in this

Speaker: NA
Text: place I have supported the general thrust of the

Speaker: NA
Text: reforms, and I indicate now that the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: accepts the proposed changes to the Corpora-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. The main question arising is whether the

Speaker: NA
Text: incoming Chairman should be a producer. Al-

Speaker: NA
Text: though I will not seek to move an amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: on this matter, it would be helpful if the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter could indicate in his response that he will

Speaker: NA
Text: listen closely to the wishes of the industry and

Speaker: NA
Text: act accordingly. I note that the new selection

Speaker: NA
Text: committee will have four producer representa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives out of five, and I commend the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for that. A major breakthrough is the consulta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive mechanism in the Bills whereby on impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant issues the Corporation will consult the

Speaker: NA
Text: Council of the Australian Dairy Industry Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ference. Again, this has been achieved largely

Speaker: NA
Text: through the strengthened hand of the industry

Speaker: NA
Text: as a result of the Opposition's actions.

Speaker: NA
Text: At this point it is appropriate that special

Speaker: NA
Text: tribute be paid to the efforts of ADC Chairman,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Malcolm Vawser. His contribution over the

Speaker: NA
Text: past seven years has been nothing short of out-

Speaker: NA
Text: standing. Mr Vawser has demonstrated leader-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship and an effectiveness in his post for which

Speaker: NA
Text: all people engaged in the industry can be very

Speaker: NA
Text: grateful.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is relevant to look ahead to the future of

Speaker: NA
Text: our industry. There is no doubt that we must

Speaker: NA
Text: retain a healthy, viable export component to

Speaker: NA
Text: take advantage of the inevitable growth in world

Speaker: NA
Text: markets. Many of our current problems have

Speaker: NA
Text: resulted from the subsidy policies of the EEC.

Speaker: NA
Text: There were. hopeful signs that the common

Speaker: NA
Text: agricultural policy was beginning to break down

Speaker: NA
Text: under its own weight and that world agriculture

Speaker: NA
Text: may come under the full provisions of the Gen-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Recent

Speaker: NA
Text: events make one wonder whether that will oc-

Speaker: NA
Text: cur, but if it does occur Australian farmers must

Speaker: NA
Text: be positioned to take advantage of any world

Speaker: NA
Text: market recovery and any. relaxation in the im-

Speaker: NA
Text: pediments to world trade at the present time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our best prospects in the immediate future lie

Speaker: NA
Text: with the markets in Asia and other regions out-

Speaker: NA
Text: legside Europe. Our products are of high quality

Speaker: NA
Text: and we are relatively close to half the world's

Speaker: NA
Text: population.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is important, however, to monitor this leg-

Speaker: NA
Text: islation closely. We will be doing that with the

Speaker: NA
Text: these industry to make sure that the new marketing

Speaker: NA
Text: Dairy arrangements perform as we expect that they

Speaker: NA
Text: should. Notwithstanding these words of caution,

Speaker: NA
Text: I am pleased to see a negotiated settlement to

Speaker: NA
Text: the dairy marketing issue after such a long and

Speaker: NA
Text: exhausting battle. I wish the Bills a speedy pas-

Speaker: NA
Text: sage and look forward to their enactment prior

Speaker: NA
Text: to the implementation date for many of the

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions, I July.

Speaker: Mr CUNNINGHAM
Text: MCMillan) (11.00)-1

Speaker: NA
Text: support the Dairy Produce Bill, the Dairy Pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce Levy (No. I) Bill, the Dairy Produce Levy

Speaker: NA
Text: (No.2) Bill, the Dairying Industry Research and

Speaker: NA
Text: Promotion Levy (Termination of Levy) Bill, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Dairy Industry Stabilization Levy (Termination

Speaker: NA
Text: of Levy) Bill and the Dairy Legislation (Tran-

Speaker: NA
Text: sitional Provisions and Consequential Amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments) Bill, which have been reintroduced by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government following efforts in the last 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months to have them passed and having had

Speaker: NA
Text: them blocked in the Senate by the Opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have just listened to the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Gwydir ( Mr Hunt) having a very long and

Speaker: NA
Text: drawn out speech on these Bills. He hardly

Speaker: NA
Text: touched on the real issues involved. The main

Speaker: NA
Text: and basic objective of the legislation is the de-

Speaker: NA
Text: velopment of a more efficient and profitable

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy industry, an industry able .to respond

Speaker: NA
Text: quickly to changing market conditions and tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: nology. Only by achieving this objective can we

Speaker: NA
Text: maintain the largest possible Australian dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: industry that would be viable at an acceptable

Speaker: NA
Text: level of industry assistance.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the domestic market, the industry must be

Speaker: NA
Text: able over time to defend its position on the basis

Speaker: NA
Text: of its competitiveness. Anyone who seeks to deny

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact of the closer economic relations agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment with New Zealand is putting his head in

Speaker: NA
Text: the sand. On the export market, the industry

Speaker: NA
Text: must strive to exploit the most profitable mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: kets and minimise sales that are a net loss to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. How do we meet those objectives?

Speaker: NA
Text: First, modification of present arrangements is

Speaker: NA
Text: sought so that producers and manufacturers can

Speaker: NA
Text: reap the benefits of their decisions. I refer to the

Speaker: NA
Text: replacement of current stabilisation arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments with a uniform level of assistance for all

Speaker: NA
Text: products, the financing of market support in the

Speaker: NA
Text: least distortionary way by a levy on all milk, the

Speaker: NA
Text: reform of the Australian Dairy Corporation to

Speaker: NA
Text: upgrade its effectiveness-I notice that the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable member for Gwydir touched on that

Speaker: NA
Text: matter for about one minute although it is pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibly one of the main areas of support for the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry-the protection of local industry against

Speaker: NA
Text: unfair import competition, the progressive re-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction in domestic price support to no higher

Speaker: NA
Text: than import parity with New Zealand and com-

Speaker: NA
Text: plementary measures which include increased

Speaker: NA
Text: government support for research marketing in-

Speaker: NA
Text: novation and adjustment.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to go back over a couple of those

Speaker: NA
Text: points. I believe, and the Government believes,

Speaker: NA
Text: that the modification of the present arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments so that producers and manufacturers can

Speaker: NA
Text: reap the benefits of their decisions is the main

Speaker: NA
Text: modification being sought by the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: for the industry, one that should have been put

Speaker: NA
Text: in place many years ago. The industry has been

Speaker: NA
Text: bogged down in regulation-we could call it

Speaker: NA
Text: National Party agrarian-type socialism-under

Speaker: NA
Text: which all sorts of pooling systems were operat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, levies were imposed for all sorts of reasons

Speaker: NA
Text: and there was cross-subsidisation to the point

Speaker: NA
Text: where the industry was completely stifled and

Speaker: NA
Text: factories had no initiative whatsoever to invest

Speaker: NA
Text: in new machinery. Conglomerates, co-operatives

Speaker: NA
Text: and private industry grew to the point where

Speaker: NA
Text: the total industry was in absolute chaos, produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing products that nobody wanted, with no mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: keting and no sales.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was incumbent upon a government-and it

Speaker: NA
Text: took a Labor government to take the initiative-

Speaker: NA
Text: to put these things right. It is not that we are

Speaker: NA
Text: introducing a lot of new legislation. In fact, we

Speaker: NA
Text: are pulling down a lot of the regulation that had

Speaker: NA
Text: been imposed by previous conservative govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments at the behest of the National Party. By

Speaker: NA
Text: pulling down those regulations we are able to

Speaker: NA
Text: institute into the industry a lot of initiatives,

Speaker: NA
Text: new development and new technology. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: been able to create a situation whereby the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry can really get behind the newly formed

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Dairy Corporation. It will be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: advise that Corporation because of its new struc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tures and go from strength to strength. Today,

Speaker: NA
Text: even 12 months after the announcement of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Kerin scheme, we do not have piles of unwanted

Speaker: NA
Text: products sitting in store houses. This legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: will only put in place what the industry has

Speaker: NA
Text: been doing since last July and will carry out the

Speaker: NA
Text: very things that this Government and the indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try believe should be done.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Gwydir in his

Speaker: NA
Text: speech was clearly talking from the past and in

Speaker: NA
Text: the dark. The Victorian dairy industry is proba-

Speaker: NA
Text: bly the most progressive and efficient in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. It is the most geared to the market-place.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is the biggest exporter, and the most efficient

Speaker: NA
Text: producer. The Victorian industry had to call a

Speaker: NA
Text: special conference last year to tell its leaders and

Speaker: NA
Text: the National Party that it wanted to support the

Speaker: NA
Text: Kerin-style proposals and to put them into op-

Speaker: NA
Text: eration. From that day we have seen the Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional Party and the Liberal Party decide that

Speaker: NA
Text: they had better come in behind what the Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment was doing and stop their procrastination.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us look at some of the issues. Let us look

Speaker: NA
Text: at the market support arrangements. The do-

Speaker: NA
Text: mestic price structure will be supported princi-

Speaker: NA
Text: pally through market support payments on

Speaker: NA
Text: exports of dairy produce. As we have said, these

Speaker: NA
Text: will be funded through the market support levy

Speaker: NA
Text: on fat in all milk. The rate of payment will

Speaker: NA
Text: normally be 30 per cent of the estimated average

Speaker: NA
Text: export price for prescribed products; that is, the

Speaker: NA
Text: major products. Also, a supplementary market

Speaker: NA
Text: support payment will be made on exports of

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy products. This will be funded by product

Speaker: NA
Text: levies on domestic sales of butter and cheese.

Speaker: NA
Text: These levies and consequent payments will de-

Speaker: NA
Text: cline in stages from I July 1987. The rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: supplementary payments for prescribed products

Speaker: NA
Text: will in most cases be a percentage of the esti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mated average export price. The Australian Dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporation will determine prescribed and non-

Speaker: NA
Text: prescribed products and the rate of market sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port payments for non-prescribed products. Pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments for non-prescribed products such as milk

Speaker: NA
Text: and whey proteins, evaporated milk and baby

Speaker: NA
Text: powders are expected to be based on their con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tent of milk fat and non-fat solids, that is, their

Speaker: NA
Text: protein content. Non-cheddar cheese exports are

Speaker: NA
Text: expected to receive payments equal to cheddar

Speaker: NA
Text: but adjusted for moisture content.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are new underwriting arrangements for

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry. The Government will continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: underwrite or guarantee returns from exports of

Speaker: NA
Text: major dairy products as it does under the present

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements for butter, butter oil, cheddar-type

Speaker: NA
Text: cheeses, skim milk and buttermilk powder, cas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ein and whole milk powder. However, the basis

Speaker: NA
Text: of underwriting will change from the present

Speaker: NA
Text: system of underwriting 90 per cent of the three-

Speaker: NA
Text: year average of export returns to a new system

Speaker: NA
Text: under which we will underwrite 85 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: the trend price. The trend price will be a value

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Bureau of Agricultural Economics esti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mates would have been obtained for the year if

Speaker: NA
Text: export prices were in their longer term trend

Speaker: NA
Text: line, using actual export returns for the past

Speaker: NA
Text: seven years and the estimated average export

Speaker: NA
Text: price in the year of underwriting. Any govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment underwriting payments will be paid to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Market Support Fund. This new system will

Speaker: NA
Text: align with the potholing element of the market

Speaker: NA
Text: support arrangements and will assist the industry

Speaker: NA
Text: better than do current arrangements in the pres-

Speaker: NA
Text: ent international price cycle downturn.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another area that has been raised very strongly

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Government over a long time is domes-

Speaker: NA
Text: tic price support values; what we now call the

Speaker: NA
Text: DPSVs. In the dairy industry one has to get to

Speaker: NA
Text: know some of the abbreviations to understand

Speaker: NA
Text: what it is all about. We have had a lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: discussion in the past about the domestic value

Speaker: NA
Text: for levy purposes or DVLPs. Under the current

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements, the ones about which we have

Speaker: NA
Text: been talking for the last two or three years,

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic prices are underpinned by stabilisation

Speaker: NA
Text: levies on domestic sales which, together with the

Speaker: NA
Text: assessed export prices, or AEPs, provide so-called

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic values for levy purposes, with the levy

Speaker: NA
Text: being distributed over all sales to provide an

Speaker: NA
Text: equalised return. Under the new arrangements,

Speaker: NA
Text: the domestic price support values for skim milk

Speaker: NA
Text: powder, whole milk powder and casein will be

Speaker: NA
Text: set by the sum of the average export price, the

Speaker: NA
Text: market support payment and the supplementary

Speaker: NA
Text: market support payment, resulting in domestic

Speaker: NA
Text: price support values equal to or greater than the

Speaker: NA
Text: old DVLPs.

Speaker: NA
Text: For butter and cheese, however, the sum of

Speaker: NA
Text: the average export price and the two market

Speaker: NA
Text: support payments is likely to be less than their

Speaker: NA
Text: current DVLPs and requires a product levy to

Speaker: NA
Text: reach a domestic price support value equal to

Speaker: NA
Text: the current DVLPs. The product levies for but-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter and cheese will be used to provide supple-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary market support for exports of all dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: products. The cheese levy will be reduced on a

Speaker: NA
Text: six-monthly basis from 1 July 1987 to zero by

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 July 1989. The butter levy will be reduced to

Speaker: NA
Text: half its initial rate by 1 July 1989 and will be

Speaker: NA
Text: reviewed in 1988-89. To help provide a smooth

Speaker: NA
Text: transition to the new arrangements, the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has agreed to set initial rates of product

Speaker: NA
Text: levies so that the new domestic price support

Speaker: NA
Text: values for butter and cheese will exceed the

Speaker: NA
Text: current DVLPs by 5 per cent and 8 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: respectively.

Speaker: NA
Text: In other words, the Government has agreed

Speaker: NA
Text: that there should be a lift in the DVLPs, to use

Speaker: NA
Text: the old terminology, of 5 per cent and 8 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent respectively. The honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Gwydir tried to take credit for that in his speech.

Speaker: NA
Text: He well knows that that will fall on deaf ears in

Speaker: NA
Text: the dairy industry because, as far as the dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: industry is concerned, the Opposition has op-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed this type of legislation all the way through.

Speaker: NA
Text: Even last year when the Victorian dairy industry

Speaker: NA
Text: put its position very clearly, the Opposition came

Speaker: NA
Text: back with what it called the Rowley plan, a plan

Speaker: NA
Text: which the National Party was pushing. The in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry could not agree to that plan and once

Speaker: NA
Text: again the Opposition had to go back and nego-

Speaker: NA
Text: tiate on the Kerin proposals. The Kerin propos-

Speaker: NA
Text: als are being discussed in the Parliament today

Speaker: NA
Text: and they are going to be in place by 1 July.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is good to hear that the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Gwydir, on behalf of the Opposition, at last

Speaker: NA
Text: has conceded that the legislation will be benefi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial to the industry and that the industry is

Speaker: NA
Text: already working to those proposals. I will use a

Speaker: NA
Text: few minutes of my speech later to detail some

Speaker: NA
Text: of the reasons why the industry is working so

Speaker: NA
Text: much better today. The matter of the levy being

Speaker: NA
Text: based on milk fat and not on volume was raised

Speaker: NA
Text: with me, in particular, and with the task force

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) that I have

Speaker: NA
Text: the privilege of chairing. I have been getting

Speaker: NA
Text: around Australia and talking to different indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries and that matter was raised with us while

Speaker: NA
Text: we were in Queensland. The reasons are quite

Speaker: NA
Text: clear. Most farmers at the moment are paid on

Speaker: NA
Text: milk fat delivered. It is desirable, therefore, to

Speaker: NA
Text: align collections of the levies with milk fat rather

Speaker: NA
Text: that with whole milk. Also, experience in Eu-

Speaker: NA
Text: rope with levies based on milk suggests that

Speaker: NA
Text: problems could arise due to milk being dehy-

Speaker: NA
Text: drated. That was also mentioned by the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Gwydir. It is good to see that

Speaker: NA
Text: he does agree with us in that regard.

Speaker: NA
Text: In future, the industry may move to a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: positional system of payments, wherein farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: may be paid on milk fat and protein content-

Speaker: NA
Text: what is better known as solids non-fat. When

Speaker: NA
Text: that occurs the Government will consider basing

Speaker: NA
Text: levies on the compositional basis. We are quite

Speaker: NA
Text: happy to make the adjustment when the indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try can come up with a better formula. Some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the other areas of great importance in the legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation relate to the Australian Dairy Corpora-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion: Who will be in charge, who will advise the

Speaker: NA
Text: Dairy Corporation and how much control will

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government still have in this industry. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are vital issues. I believe we are taking steps in

Speaker: NA
Text: this regard which will put this industry into a

Speaker: NA
Text: position where it will be responsible for its own

Speaker: NA
Text: future, it will be responsible for making its own

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions and it will be less reliant upon govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment direction. When I get around in my elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate-I have been to three meetings in the last

Speaker: NA
Text: four months in relation to the dairy industry-it

Speaker: NA
