Text: does surprise me that, in direct contrast to what

Speaker: NA
Text: was organised against us 12 months ago when

Speaker: NA
Text: the sides of cars were being kicked in by thugs

Speaker: NA
Text: when the Minister for Primary Industry ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Kerin) visited my area, I can now go to meetings

Speaker: NA
Text: in my area where the farmers are quite rational.

Speaker: NA
Text: The farmers in Victoria, and I believe right

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout Australia, have seen through the sort

Speaker: NA
Text: of proposals and the sort of campaign that was

Speaker: NA
Text: being waged 12 months ago and they are now

Speaker: NA
Text: quite clearly behind what the Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: doing. They are prepared to initiate the new

Speaker: NA
Text: initiatives.

Speaker: NA
Text: In my area and in the area of Gippsland

Speaker: NA
Text: people are now prepared to establish new cheese

Speaker: NA
Text: factories. Three factories have already been es-

Speaker: NA
Text: tablished since the Kerin plan was announced.

Speaker: NA
Text: Factories today are not producing those products

Speaker: NA
Text: which were based on levies and pooling before

Speaker: NA
Text: and which were sitting in storehouses. Factories

Speaker: NA
Text: were getting paid to produce the product, paid

Speaker: NA
Text: again to reconstitute it and then paid to store

Speaker: NA
Text: at the farmers' expense. Farmers have woken up

Speaker: NA
Text: to the National Party, in my area at least. I can

Speaker: NA
Text: guarantee that because I can attend a meeting

Speaker: NA
Text: anywhere in my electorate today and at those

Speaker: NA
Text: meetings have resolutions carried congratulating

Speaker: NA
Text: us on getting a job done and on getting it done

Speaker: NA
Text: well.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, I move on to just a couple of points

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Australian Dairy Corporation and where

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry will fit into this in the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: executive council of the Australian Dairy Indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try Conference has been recognised by the Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment as the peak industry council best able

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide industry policy advice to the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and with which the Australian Dairy Cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: poration will consult on its activities. In other

Speaker: NA
Text: words, the industry will have a very active part

Speaker: NA
Text: to play. The Australian Dairy Corporation will

Speaker: NA
Text: be required to consult with the council on the

Speaker: NA
Text: development of its corporate and operational

Speaker: NA
Text: plans and it will report annually to a meeting of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Dairy Industry Conference on its

Speaker: NA
Text: operations. The council will also approve the

Speaker: NA
Text: scope of ADC trading activities and certain kinds

Speaker: NA
Text: of directions that the Australian Dairy Corpo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ration can make in regard to exports and will

Speaker: NA
Text: be consulted on the criteria that the Corpora-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions will use in directing exporters to consult

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Corporation on their export intentions.

Speaker: NA
Text: In other words, factories and exporters will not

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to go ahead and produce products and

Speaker: NA
Text: then pass the economic effects of bad decision

Speaker: NA
Text: making across to somebody else and ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers to pay for it in the long run.

Speaker: NA
Text: The legislation enables the council to make

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations to the Government in respect

Speaker: NA
Text: of the rate to be prescribed for the Corporation

Speaker: NA
Text: levy which funds thl- Australian Dairy Corpora-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Additionally, the council will also be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to make recommendations in respect of the pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: scribed rate of promotion and research levies.

Speaker: NA
Text: The restructuring of the Australian Dairy Cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: poration will be done by a selection committee

Speaker: NA
Text: which will comprise a presiding member chosen

Speaker: NA
Text: and appointed by the Minister, and four mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers nominated by the executive council. The

Speaker: NA
Text: ' council will also be able to express its non-

Speaker: NA
Text: confidence in the Corporation, in which case the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister is empowered to terminate the appoint-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of one or more of the appointed members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Corporation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Expenditure from the dairy industry fund, ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: ministered by the Australian Dairy Corporation,

Speaker: NA
Text: in most cases will be subject to ADIC approval.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is quite clear from the direction that the

Speaker: NA
Text: it Government is taking that the dairy industry in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia can now look forward to developing

Speaker: NA
Text: itself and the industry into the next century. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have thrown off the shackles of the regulations

Speaker: NA
Text: imposed upon the industry for so many years-

Speaker: NA
Text: regulations which have restricted the industry

Speaker: NA
Text: and which have imposed costs upon the industry

Speaker: NA
Text: to the point where it was choking on its own

Speaker: NA
Text: performance. We are no longer witnessing in

Speaker: NA
Text: dairying areas four and five milk trucks driving

Speaker: NA
Text: up and down the one road, burning up fuel and

Speaker: NA
Text: The destroying roads maintained by local govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, to pick up milk from the one dairy farmer

Speaker: NA
Text: simply because there was no rationalisation of

Speaker: NA
Text: that process. A lot of that milk was being taken

Speaker: NA
Text: to factories which were producing products far

Speaker: NA
Text: beyond the expected markets for those products.

Speaker: NA
Text: In my area there was the particular instance

Speaker: NA
Text: of two factories which in the last 12 months

Speaker: NA
Text: rationalised-one a proprietary and one a co-

Speaker: NA
Text: operative. We did not need to legislate for that

Speaker: NA
Text: to happen. The factories knew that was going to

Speaker: NA
Text: happen and they worked towards it. One partic-

Speaker: NA
Text: ular factory now picks up the milk in that area

Speaker: NA
Text: and that double cost of cartage is cut out. An-

Speaker: NA
Text: other factory ceased making butter as soon as

Speaker: NA
Text: the day arrived when it no longer had a profit-

Speaker: NA
Text: able market for that butter. It transferred the

Speaker: NA
Text: milk down the road to another factory which

Speaker: NA
Text: had very profitable products which were sold in

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States of America.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are the sorts of things that have hap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pened under the legislation proposed under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Kerin plan. We will have an industry which will

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to compete with the New Zealand in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry under our closer economic relations pol-

Speaker: NA
Text: icy. We will not be a target now for New Zealand

Speaker: NA
Text: in the manufacturing sector of Australia. Our

Speaker: NA
Text: industry in Victoria will not have to worry to

Speaker: NA
Text: the point where under the old proposals, as costs

Speaker: NA
Text: and prices increased, it was pushed into a very

Speaker: NA
Text: poor marketing situation and its markets in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia-Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane-were

Speaker: NA
Text: becoming clear targets for the New Zealanders

Speaker: NA
Text: who were able to produce in a more efficient

Speaker: NA
Text: manner. We now have a similar system to New

Speaker: NA
Text: Zealand. We are competitive and I believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: this legislation will put the Australian dairy in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry into a very healthy position in the future

Speaker: NA
Text: and it will start to restore some of the confidence

Speaker: NA
Text: in the parts of rural Australia where it is badly

Speaker: NA
Text: needed. I strongly support the legislation.

Speaker: Mr DRUMMOND
Text: Forrest) (11.19)-A lot

Speaker: NA
Text: of what the honourable member for MCMillan

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Cunningham) said in the early part of his

Speaker: NA
Text: address was quite true and accurate. The indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try has fallen into some degree of chaos, partic-

Speaker: NA
Text: ularly in Victoria, I suggest, and maybe to a

Speaker: NA
Text: lesser extent in Tasmania, but for him to lay

Speaker: NA
Text: that on previous Federal governments is a bit

Speaker: NA
Text: unfair. There are some areas in Australia where

Speaker: NA
Text: the dairy industry is not in chaos and is enjoying

Speaker: NA
Text: a fairly prosperous period. I refer to the industry

Speaker: NA
Text: in Western Australia. What has been the differ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence between Western Australia and Victoria?

Speaker: NA
Text: Why has this occurred? It occurred because at

Speaker: NA
Text: least 10 years ago Western Australia made a

Speaker: NA
Text: deliberate effort to rationalises its industry. In

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia there is a three-price scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: and everyone has a share of these different prices.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is an entitlement or quota scheme. We have a

Speaker: NA
Text: price for our liquid milk, we have a price for

Speaker: NA
Text: out white milk products, and then we have an

Speaker: NA
Text: end price. People can produce as much as they

Speaker: NA
Text: want but, as a true indication of what that milk

Speaker: NA
Text: is worth, since there is no domestic market for

Speaker: NA
Text: it it gets a return of something like 5c to 10c a

Speaker: NA
Text: litre because that is the least one would expect

Speaker: NA
Text: on the export market. So production in Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has been limited to profitable areas of

Speaker: NA
Text: return.

Speaker: NA
Text: It might have been a good idea if many years

Speaker: NA
Text: ago New South Wales and Victoria has got to-

Speaker: NA
Text: gether. It might be one of the frailties of our

Speaker: NA
Text: State systems; we have two completely different

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy industries. Each is a child of the State. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have a one-price system in Victoria where the

Speaker: NA
Text: production has not been limited. The return has

Speaker: NA
Text: been equalised between all products, whether for

Speaker: NA
Text: the liquid milk market, the domestic manufac-

Speaker: NA
Text: turing market, or the export market. So what

Speaker: NA
Text: has happened in Victoria? We have increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: production and, of course, diminishing prices as

Speaker: NA
Text: world markets have collapsed. I will return to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Western Australian position in a minute.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am fearful of this legislation. I appreciate

Speaker: NA
Text: that the industry throughout Australia and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government have finally come to a compromise

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement on the way we should go. The com-

Speaker: NA
Text: promise has been reached because of the diffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: culties of the industry being able to get together.

Speaker: NA
Text: It comprises five or six industries throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, and I briefly described the Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian and Victorian industries. It is a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: promise position. I am fearful of this legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: because, quite frankly, I believe that the very

Speaker: NA
Text: basis of it, which aims to tie the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic prices to world traded prices, is wrong.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no such thing as a world traded price.

Speaker: NA
Text: Maybe we can try to relate it to New Zealand's

Speaker: NA
Text: export price, but that is not a true price because

Speaker: NA
Text: it is controlled by the Brussels price. There is no

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy products futures trading or commodities

Speaker: NA
Text: trading on international markets, in the way

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat, grain, metal or anything else is traded.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no such thing because it is a corrupt

Speaker: NA
Text: market. That situation developed because na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions such as those in the European Economic

Speaker: NA
Text: Community and the United States of America-

Speaker: NA
Text: in fact almost every nation in the world, includ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Australia-wished to be self-sufficient, par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly in all forms of dairy products. This has

Speaker: NA
Text: led to a remarkable self-sufficiency in the EEC,

Speaker: NA
Text: but in its rush to become self-sufficient it has

Speaker: NA
Text: ended up with quite a surplus.

Speaker: NA
Text: Only about 4 per cent of all dairy products

Speaker: NA
Text: produced in the world today are actually traded.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other than in New Zealand and Australia, which

Speaker: NA
Text: have been fairly great exporting nations in dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: products over the years, dairy products are traded

Speaker: NA
Text: because people want to get rid of their surplus.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have a situation where the big producers in

Speaker: NA
Text: the European Economic Community overprod-

Speaker: NA
Text: uce by about 2 or 3 per cent, which is a tremen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dous volume. In fact, that 2 or 3 per cent is as

Speaker: NA
Text: much as Australia and New Zealand produce all

Speaker: NA
Text: up-not what they export, what they produce.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those nations do not mind what price they get

Speaker: NA
Text: for their product. They do not care; it is not

Speaker: NA
Text: essential. They just want to get rid of that prod-

Speaker: NA
Text: uct. So at no time is the price of that product

Speaker: NA
Text: tied to a real price. Consumers in Australia pay

Speaker: NA
Text: for their dairy product something like 60 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of what the consumers in the EEC and

Speaker: NA
Text: America pay for their product. Our consumers

Speaker: NA
Text: are getting a reasonably cheap product. As the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Gwydir ( Mr Hunt) has

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned, milk is a nutritious product and one

Speaker: NA
Text: could live longer on it than on any other sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: stance if that was the only thing one had. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: far cheaper than coke, beer, or anything else,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the manufacturers do not have to go through

Speaker: NA
Text: the machinations of the milk industry to produce

Speaker: NA
Text: the product. We have to have a cow in the field,

Speaker: NA
Text: we have to get the milk out of the cow, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: milk has to go to the factory. To produce a

Speaker: NA
Text: bottle of coke, there is a factory somewhere, a

Speaker: NA
Text: bottle is filled with water, a bit of something

Speaker: NA
Text: else is poured into it, and there it is. Yet it

Speaker: NA
Text: lot more expensive than milk.

Speaker: NA
Text: The consumers of the EEC, America and the

Speaker: NA
Text: other exporting nations with which we have to

Speaker: NA
Text: compete-it is not just New Zealand-are pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing at least 40 per cent more for their dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: product than Australian consumers are. Yet we

Speaker: NA
Text: are saying that we have to tie our industry to

Speaker: NA
Text: the world traded price of their surplus. Why do

Speaker: NA
Text: we not tie our price, as is normal with most

Speaker: NA
Text: cases of dumping, to what is reasonable for those

Speaker: NA
Text: consumers to pay in their country? The main

Speaker: NA
Text: reason why we have a regulated industry is to

Speaker: NA
Text: see that people have fresh milk every day, all

Speaker: NA
Text: year round, and at a reasonable price. It is not

Speaker: NA
Text: for the protection of the dairy farmer.

Speaker: NA
Text: The concept of building this efficient and prof-

Speaker: NA
Text: itable industry, as the Minister for Primary In-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry ( Mr Kerin) said in his speech, around

Speaker: NA
Text: world traded prices of dairy products is just a

Speaker: NA
Text: nonsense. No longer will we have pooling, no

Speaker: NA
Text: longer will we have allowances. I agree that a

Speaker: NA
Text: lot of those things had to be tidied up, but it

Speaker: NA
Text: will surely lead to a situation where the export-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers will find it very difficult to get a reasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: price because he will not have the capacity to

Speaker: NA
Text: wait for a sale. I believe production in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: will increase in the short term because there will

Speaker: NA
Text: be no clear market signals to the producer. Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: member that we have to get a General Agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment on Tariffs and Trade minimum price-we

Speaker: NA
Text: are a party to GATT. Exporters will find it

Speaker: NA
Text: increasingly difficult to get a reasonable price

Speaker: NA
Text: and they will naturally look to our domestic

Speaker: NA
Text: market. If this happens we will see the under-

Speaker: NA
Text: cutting of the price of butter, cheese and so on,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that is probably what the Government wishes

Speaker: NA
Text: to achieve.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Cowan-Western Australia has always

Speaker: NA
Text: looked after the market there.

Speaker: Mr DRUMMOND
Text: That is true. As the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable member for Gwydir said earlier, it really

Speaker: NA
Text: is consumer legislation. Undercutting will start

Speaker: NA
Text: in the domestic market because there will be no

Speaker: NA
Text: allowances and no pooling. What will a factory

Speaker: NA
Text: do? It will have to get into the international

Speaker: NA
Text: market-place to try to undercut, which will lead

Speaker: NA
Text: to lots of bad blood with New Zealand. If the

Speaker: NA
Text: factory cannot sell its product it will have to

Speaker: NA
Text: look to the internal market.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those are the broad concerns I have about

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislation and the way in which the dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: industry is expected to go. I also make the point

Speaker: NA
Text: that if world prices continue to move down or

Speaker: NA
Text: collapse over a period-I understand that the

Speaker: NA
Text: is a legislation covers the underwriting-the 130 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of world trade prices becomes a lesser figure

Speaker: NA
Text: and therefore the all-milk levy becomes less. For

Speaker: NA
Text: instance, the levy was estimated to be 1.8c per

Speaker: NA
Text: litre in January 1986 with GATT minimum

Speaker: NA
Text: holdings and the dollar at 70c. With the Euro-

Speaker: NA
Text: pean Economic Community selling under GATT

Speaker: NA
Text: price and with the Australian dollar at US74c,

Speaker: NA
Text: the levy will be under 1.3c. So as the interna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional export markets decrease, so will the levy

Speaker: NA
Text: and so will the assistance to exporters.

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn briefly to the position of Western Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. My State has never been an exporter of

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy products, but many years ago it made a

Speaker: NA
Text: deliberate attempt to put its own industry in

Speaker: NA
Text: order. It introduced a scheme, which it has mod-

Speaker: NA
Text: ified over the years, whereby every dairy farmer

Speaker: NA
Text: participates and has a quota of liquid milk for

Speaker: NA
Text: local consumption and a quota for whitegood

Speaker: NA
Text: products. His return for the milk he has left-

Speaker: NA
Text: and he can produce all he wants to-reflects the

Speaker: NA
Text: true market export price. We have never been a

Speaker: NA
Text: burden to the eastern States. In fact, we are an

Speaker: NA
Text: importer of eastern States' products. We import

Speaker: NA
Text: something like 70 to 80 per cent of our butter,

Speaker: NA
Text: cheese and other manufactured dairy products.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Western Australian farmers are finding it

Speaker: NA
Text: very difficult to understand why they, having

Speaker: NA
Text: put their house in order, will be required under

Speaker: NA
Text: this legislation to give to their eastern States

Speaker: NA
Text: cousins some $4,500 per farm. That is what the

Speaker: NA
Text: net cost of the levy will be to the average farm

Speaker: NA
Text: in Western Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Because the Western Australian dairy indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try's record, because of its isolation and because

Speaker: NA
Text: it has never been a burden on the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy industry or the Australian community, I

Speaker: NA
Text: plead that it be given special consideration. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that it would be possible and reasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: to establish a special mechanism whereby an

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of money equivalent to the levy col-

Speaker: NA
Text: lected could be returned to Western Australia. I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not think there is any sound economic reason

Speaker: NA
Text: for Western Australia to accept this plan. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, we agree that it is a national plan and that

Speaker: NA
Text: we cannot just chop one State out of it. The

Speaker: NA
Text: moneys raised in Western Australia should be

Speaker: NA
Text: returned to Western Australia. Clause 94 of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Dairy Produce Bill deals with market support

Speaker: NA
Text: payments, but another section could be added to

Speaker: NA
Text: in order to recognise the need to make a disabil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity payment if a State is disadvantaged.

Speaker: NA
Text: Given our location, any significant reduction

Speaker: NA
Text: in the production of milk in Western Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: could jeopardise the continued availability of

Speaker: NA
Text: fresh milk and short life products to consumers

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout Western Australia. As honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members know, Western Australia is a long way

Speaker: NA
Text: from the eastern States. It is isolated from the

Speaker: NA
Text: rest of Australia and is not contributing to the

Speaker: NA
Text: national dairy marketing problems. The prices

Speaker: NA
Text: of all milk and cream products, including long

Speaker: NA
Text: life products, entering Western Australia for sale

Speaker: NA
Text: would appropriately reflect retail prices for those

Speaker: NA
Text: products in their State of origin. This legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: should contain a mechanism to allow the State

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister to suspend arrangements if, in his opin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ion, milk or cream were dumped in Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am sure that the Opposition would have put

Speaker: NA
Text: before the Parliament an amendment such as I

Speaker: NA
Text: have suggested. However, understanding that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister had said that there was no way he

Speaker: NA
Text: would accept any amendments to the legislation,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition felt reluctant to do so. I under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand that the Minister has received very strong

Speaker: NA
Text: representations from Western Australia, partic-

Speaker: NA
Text: ularly from the Western Australian Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, which is of his political complexion. I ask

Speaker: NA
Text: him whether he would consider, even at this late

Speaker: NA
Text: stage, introducing such an amendment to this

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill in the interests of equity for the producers

Speaker: NA
Text: of Western Australia. I guess it would really be

Speaker: NA
Text: in the interests of the consumers of Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, because there is no way that produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers in Western Australia can stand this imposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and they will seek a rise in the price of

Speaker: NA
Text: liquid milk. As a result, the consumers of West-

Speaker: NA
Text: ern Australia will be paying this levy to farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: in Victoria, who claim that they are the most

Speaker: NA
Text: efficient in Australia.

Speaker: Mr BEDDALL
Text: Rankin) (11.35)-1t is with

Speaker: NA
Text: great pleasure that I rise to support these long

Speaker: NA
Text: overdue Bills introduced by my colleague the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Primary Industry ( Mr Kerin). It

Speaker: NA
Text: will come as no surprise to anybody who has

Speaker: NA
Text: followed the dairy industry debate that these

Speaker: NA
Text: Bills represent the most comprehensive changes

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Australian dairy industry ever undertaken

Speaker: NA
Text: by a Federal government. After years of neglect

Speaker: NA
Text: by the National and Liberal parties, the Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian dairy industry had reached the position where

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry faced total collapse. The prospect

Speaker: NA
Text: of interstate trade wars was almost a reality and

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry itself was bitterly divided.

Speaker: NA
Text: When the Minister sought to bring about

Speaker: NA
Text: changes to the dairy industry over 12 months

Speaker: NA
Text: ago, he met with massive resistance from those

Speaker: NA
Text: sections of the industry with a vested interest.

Speaker: NA
Text: These vested interests had manoeuvred them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves into positions of influence in the industry's

Speaker: NA
Text: peak councils. They convinced the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Democrats in the Senate that the original Kerin

Speaker: NA
Text: plan did not have the support of the dairy in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry and the initial legislation was rejected.

Speaker: NA
Text: These vested interests made the claim that they

Speaker: NA
Text: could come up with a far better dairy industry

Speaker: NA
Text: plan, and so the Government agreed to listen to

Speaker: NA
Text: their proposals. It is now a matter of history

Speaker: NA
Text: that the so-called Rowley plan has been con-

Speaker: NA
Text: signed to the scrap-heap, as it should have been.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Rowley plan would have benefited only the

Speaker: NA
Text: large producers with financial resources far above

Speaker: NA
Text: those of the ordinary family dairy farmer. This

Speaker: NA
Text: plan, which was thankfully rejected by the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry, was based on rolling entitlements that

Speaker: NA
Text: would have enabled the privileged dairy farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian industry to keep over-produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing so that the extra production could be allo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cated as entitlement at the end of each year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore, after three years the entitlement would

Speaker: NA
Text: have been assessed not on realistic levels of

Speaker: NA
Text: production but on the increased production that

Speaker: NA
Text: had been financed from other sources.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are seven major elements of this legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation: A cessation of export pooling; replace-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of current stabilisation arrangements;

Speaker: NA
Text: market support arrangements; progressive reduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in domestic price support; protection of the

Speaker: NA
Text: local industry against unfair import competition;

Speaker: NA
Text: upgrading of the Australian Dairy Corporation

Speaker: NA
Text: to enhance its effectiveness and accountability;

Speaker: NA
Text: and special assistance for market innovation and

Speaker: NA
Text: research. There are many vital elements to this

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill, perhaps none more important than the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: form of the Australian Dairy Corporation. As I

Speaker: NA
Text: have moved around my electorate of Rankin

Speaker: NA
Text: talking to dairy farmers and dairy co-operatives,

Speaker: NA
Text: I have encountered a great deal of criticism of

Speaker: NA
Text: the current Australian Dairy Corporation. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: been regarded by the industry as ineffectual in

Speaker: NA
Text: promoting Australian dairy products on the world

Speaker: NA
Text: market. A much enhanced Australian Dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporation will be able to seek out world mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: kets. If the dairy industry is to survive, it must

Speaker: NA
Text: be aggressive on world markets despite the un-

Speaker: NA
Text: fair practices it will encounter from our compet-

Speaker: NA
Text: itors. It cannot sit back in the hope that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian dairy products will sell themselves.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other major item which has raised most

Speaker: NA
Text: controversy in relation to this legislation has

Speaker: NA
Text: been the all milk levy that will be used to

Speaker: NA
Text: underwrite the export market. The market sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port fund will be financed from the dairy prod-

Speaker: NA
Text: uct levy which will apply to all milk produced

Speaker: NA
Text: on or after 1 July 1986. Under the new levy

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements, the amount of levy payable by a

Speaker: NA
Text: producer will depend on the amount of milk fat

Speaker: NA
Text: contained in his milk. Under current arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments, where a producer delivers whole milk to

Speaker: NA
Text: a processor, the levy is calculated at a rate per

Speaker: NA
Text: litre regardless of fat content; only where the

Speaker: NA
Text: producer delivers cream is the levy to be based

Speaker: NA
Text: on fat content. The change to a standard milk

Speaker: NA
Text: fat basis arises from a decision to base the

Speaker: NA
Text: ket support levy on milk fat and the desirability

Speaker: NA
Text: of having a standard base for all levies on milk.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Bill provides a clause to cover the situation

Speaker: NA
Text: where it has not been possible to ascertain the

Speaker: NA
Text: milk fat content. This clause should only have

Speaker: NA
Text: to be resorted to for a small proportion of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian production since most milk payment sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tems require the recording of milk fat content.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Bill specifies maximum rates for all milk

Speaker: NA
Text: fat levies with the operative rates to be set by

Speaker: NA
Text: regulation. For market support levy, the maxi-

Speaker: NA
Text: mum rate of levy is to be 45c per kilogram of

Speaker: NA
Text: milk fat, which is equivalent to 2c per litre for

Speaker: NA
Text: milk of average fat content. In the case of the

Speaker: NA
Text: research levy, the maximum rate specified cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: responds to the maximum rate of 2.5c recently

Speaker: NA
Text: set in the Dairying Industry Research and Pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: motion Levy Amendment Act 1986. The maxi-

Speaker: NA
Text: mum rates for the promotion and corporation

Speaker: NA
Text: levies are respectively 5.5c per kilogram fat and

Speaker: NA
Text: 2.5c per kilogram fat.

Speaker: NA
Text: I could not address myself to any dairy legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation before this House without some comment

Speaker: NA
Text: on the mismanagement of the industry in my

Speaker: NA
Text: own State by the scandal-ridden National Party

Speaker: NA
Text: Government led by an irrelevant aging premier.

Speaker: NA
Text: The dairy industry in Queensland has suffered

Speaker: NA
Text: the worst effects of political patronage. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Coast Mafia of the National Party has 80 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of the market milk whereas the poor strug-

Speaker: NA
Text: gling farmers supplying the Warwick Co-opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive in my electorate of Rankin are lucky to

Speaker: NA
Text: reach 40 per cent. In previous speeches in this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament I have fully documented the types of

Speaker: NA
Text: scandals that have existed in Queensland under

Speaker: NA
Text: the National Party State Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister and his Department might be

Speaker: NA
Text: interested in investigating the case of the Gold

Speaker: NA
Text: Coast Dairy Co-operative run by a Mr Hollin-

Speaker: NA
Text: dale, who is a close personal friend of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland Minister for Local Government,

Speaker: NA
Text: Main Roads and Racing, Mr Hinze. On 3 Sep-

Speaker: NA
Text: tember 1985 the State member for Archerfield,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Henry Palaszczuk, stated that the Gold Coast

Speaker: NA
Text: Dairy had avoided paying its correct amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: levy on dairy products to the Commonwealth.

Speaker: NA
Text: The story has not been denied by the State

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Primary Industries, Mr Turner, so I

Speaker: NA
Text: shall outline it for the Minister. The Gold Coast

Speaker: NA
Text: Dairy produces about 500 tonnes of skim milk

Speaker: NA
Text: powder which, in the 1984-85 financial year,

Speaker: NA
Text: attracted a levy of $474 a tonne. Over a 12-

Speaker: NA
Text: month period the levy totalled $237,000. If the

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy's failure to pay its levy has been going on

Speaker: NA
Text: for a number of years, the Commonwe.alth could

Speaker: NA
Text: mar- be owed as much as $lm. I believe that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister should investigate these allegations.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the few favoured co-operatives in

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland, the Gold Coast Dairy has recently

Speaker: NA
Text: ensured the closure of a small country co-oper-

Speaker: NA
Text: ative in nearby Beaudesert. There is a stench

Speaker: NA
Text: about the Gold Coast Dairy. Its leading players

Speaker: NA
Text: and suppliers go to the very heart of the Queens-

Speaker: NA
Text: land National Party hierarchy. The Minister will

Speaker: NA
Text: be doing us a favour if he ensures that the Gold

Speaker: NA
Text: Coast Dairy is paying its correct amount on

Speaker: NA
Text: leviable product, particularly under this legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Levies appear to be the core of the problem

Speaker: NA
Text: in the dairy industry today. Farmers in Warwick

Speaker: NA
Text: in my electorate and in Beaudesert would be

Speaker: NA
Text: advantaged by the maximum 2c per litre all milk

Speaker: NA
Text: levy as proposed by the Minister's plan. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: reliably informed from sources within the indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try that up to 60 per cent of farmers pay no

Speaker: NA
Text: milk levy at all.

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn now to the Dairying Industry Research

Speaker: NA
Text: and Promotion Levy (Termination of Levy) Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: I ask the Minister to give me an assurance that

Speaker: NA
Text: this money will be correctly audited each year.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do so because of the situation within the

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland Dairymen's Organisation in which

Speaker: NA
Text: cheques of up to $500,000 are alleged to have

Speaker: NA
Text: been misappropriated. Every dairy farmer in

Speaker: NA
Text: Gold Queensland has to belong to the Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: Dairymen's Organisation. Apparently the Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional Party is against compulsory unionism ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: cept where it applies in the dairy industry. Each

Speaker: NA
Text: dairyman pays $85 a year to belong and there

Speaker: NA
Text: are 2,500 Queensland dairymen, so the extent of

Speaker: NA
Text: the apparent irregularities will not escape the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister. I find the incident amazing because the

Speaker: NA
Text: accounts should have been audited yearly and,

Speaker: NA
Text: surely, the cheques were countersigned by the

Speaker: NA
Text: chairman or a senior executive member. If not

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister should ask: Why not? Just as the

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland dairymen need to be reassured about

Speaker: NA
Text: the accounting procedures in their own organi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sation, I am sure that the Queensland dairymen

Speaker: NA
Text: will want to be assured that government money

Speaker: NA
Text: targeted for research in the industry actually

Speaker: NA
Text: ends up there. Many Queensland dairymen be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve that their hard won $85 is little more than

Speaker: NA
Text: a campaign contribution to the National Party.

Speaker: NA
Text: Their newsletter, Queensland Dairy Farmers,

Speaker: NA
Text: makes no honest attempt at impartiality. Any

Speaker: NA
Text: observer would have thought that an industry

Speaker: NA
Text: suffering as much injustice as the Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy industry would be pressing the State Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment for much needed reform. Instead, all

Speaker: NA
Text: the vitriol is reserved for this Government and

Speaker: NA
Text: this Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: These Bills are designed to give the industry a

Speaker: NA
Text: better support mechanism. I am certain that

Speaker: NA
Text: they will achieve that. I particularly welcome

Speaker: NA
Text: the abolition of the allowances which have ena-

Speaker: NA
Text: bled Victorian manufacturers to sell butter in

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland more cheaply than in Victoria. My

Speaker: NA
Text: producers on the southern Darling Downs will

Speaker: NA
Text: eagerly welcome that proposal. It is, neverthe-

Speaker: NA
Text: less, a reality that, in spite of all the assistance,

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers will still leave the industry. The Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has done a great deal in the rural recon-

Speaker: NA
Text: struction scheme and the rural adjustment scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure that financially hard-pressed farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: are cared for. In Queensland, because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: generosity of the Federal Government, almost

Speaker: NA
Text: $38.824m has been accumulated in these two

Speaker: NA
Text: funds. Unfortunately, on its own budget esti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mates, the Queensland National Party Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment plans to receive $29.7l8m from farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: and is expected to spend only $32.48m. In real-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity, the Queensland Government will only dip

Speaker: NA
Text: into its massive accumulations by $2.763m.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is time the Queensland Government emp-

Speaker: NA
Text: tied out these hollowed logs and tried to give

Speaker: NA
Text: genuine assistance to Queensland farmers. The

Speaker: NA
Text: figures show that the Queensland Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: profiteering while farmers go to the wall. These

Speaker: NA
Text: actions contrast with the rural policies of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. Our concern is for the efficient

Speaker: NA
Text: management of rural industries. I support the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister in these Bills and hope the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: will distance itself from its Queensland col-

Speaker: NA
Text: leagues and do something for all dairy farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: and not just the favoured few.

Speaker: Mr MILES
Text: Braddon) (11.45)-One is

Speaker: NA
Text: amazed that such important legislation for the

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy farmers of Australia is being guillotined

Speaker: NA
Text: through this House today. One comes into the

Speaker: NA
Text: House and hears the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: MCMillan ( Mr Cunningham) say: 'It took a La-

Speaker: NA
Text: bor government to initiate these changes'. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is absolute rubbish. It is the industry which ini-

Speaker: NA
Text: tiates these changes and they would not have

Speaker: NA
Text: occurred had the Opposition not opposed the

Speaker: NA
Text: measures in the Senate in 1985. The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Rankin ( Mr Beddall) said that this

Speaker: NA
Text: is the most comprehensive change ever made by

Speaker: NA
Text: a Federal government. It is absolutely incredible

Speaker: NA
Text: when governments laud themselves and it is really

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry which comes up with the initiatives

Speaker: NA
Text: and ideas to restructure its plan. The Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment wants to heap praise on itself whereas in

Speaker: NA
Text: actual fact the ideas and creativity come from

Speaker: NA
Text: other people.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ian Robinson-The Kerin plan was

Speaker: NA
Text: rejected.

Speaker: Mr MILES
Text: That is right. As the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member says, the Kerin plan was rejected out-

Speaker: NA
Text: right by the farmers of Australia. Today six Bills,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Dairy Produce Bill, the Dairy Produce Levy

Speaker: NA
Text: (No.1) Bill, the Dairy Produce Levy (No.2)

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill, the Dairying Industry Research and Pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: motion Levy (Termination of Levy) Bill, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Dairy Industry Stabilization Levy (Termination

Speaker: NA
Text: of Levy) Bill and the Dairy Legislation (Tran-

Speaker: NA
Text: sitional Provisions and Consequential Amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments) Bill, are before the House. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: designed to implement new marketing arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments for the Australian dairy industry and to

Speaker: NA
Text: alter the structure and functions of the Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian Dairy Corporation. They will replace the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation brought before this House in May last

Speaker: NA
Text: year and amended in the Senate. Because the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition opposed the legislation that would

Speaker: NA
Text: have had a severe fall-out effect on the dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: industry and its families, the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: now modified its legislation. Although a safety

Speaker: NA
Text: clause has been inserted and the outstanding

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of an increase in price of certain manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: factured products has been overcome to the sat-

Speaker: NA
Text: isfaction of the Australian Dairy Farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: Federation, the legislation has no satisfactory

Speaker: NA
Text: mechanism to reduce the production of milk.

Speaker: NA
Text: Such a mechanism was regarded by many in the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry to be a necessary step towards placing

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry on a more stable footing with better

Speaker: NA
Text: long term prospects.

Speaker: NA
Text: The dairy industry in Australia has undergone

Speaker: NA
Text: an enormous rationalisation in recent years. In

Speaker: NA
Text: the last 20 years the number of dairy farms has

Speaker: NA
Text: declined by 73 per cent, from 49,000 in 1964 to

Speaker: NA
Text: an estimated 18,300 in 1985. Direct employment

Speaker: NA
Text: has fallen by over 60 per cent in the last 30

Speaker: NA
Text: years and the number of factories has declined

Speaker: NA
Text: by over 30 per cent in the last 10 years. Yet this

Speaker: NA
Text: industry continues to be a vibrant one that earns

Speaker: NA
Text: in excess of $350m in exports and the value of

Speaker: NA
Text: total dairy production exceeds $1 billion per

Speaker: NA
Text: annum. Due to the nature of the products of

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry, it remains a State based industry

Speaker: NA
Text: that has focused its attention on the fresh milk

Speaker: NA
Text: markets of the more populous areas of each

Speaker: NA
Text: State.

Speaker: NA
Text: The industry can be divided into two sectors-

Speaker: NA
Text: the liquid fresh milk market and the manufac-

Speaker: NA
Text: turing market. The historical development of the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry that has been controlled by the States

Speaker: NA
Text: has meant that Victoria and Tasmania manufac-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture by far the majority of their milk whilst

Speaker: NA
Text: States such as New South Wales and Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia manufacture less than 50 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: their milk. Thus the burden of lower returns

Speaker: NA
Text: from the manufactured milk sector has previ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ously fallen more heavily on Victorian and Tas-

Speaker: NA
Text: manian farmers than on farmers in other States.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, it is the manufactured products such

Speaker: NA
Text: as cheese, butter, casein and milk powder that

Speaker: NA
Text: earn the export dollar that is so vital to Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia, particularly when our trade balance is in

Speaker: NA
Text: the red to the tune of $1.5 billion.

Speaker: NA
Text: This legislation will place a financial burden

Speaker: NA
Text: on the producers of New South Wales and West-

Speaker: NA
Text: ern Australia in particular, and that raises an

Speaker: NA
Text: important principle that governments of all

Speaker: NA
Text: shades and colours should give credence to, that

Speaker: NA
Text: is, where an industry is to be restructured for

Speaker: NA
Text: the overall benefit of the nation those areas

Speaker: NA
Text: are disadvantaged by the restructuring should

Speaker: NA
Text: have available to them resources that would

Speaker: NA
Text: minimise the dislocation and social upheaval in

Speaker: NA
Text: families that may be caused by such restructur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. The overwhelming majority of Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: accept that Australia has a major task ahead of

Speaker: NA
Text: it to restructure its economic base so that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: more competitive in world markets. Although

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Howard) has

Speaker: NA
Text: been constantly pointing to the practical meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ures that would lead the economy in the right

Speaker: NA
Text: direction, it was only last week that the Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian Labor Party gave even any semblance of

Speaker: NA
Text: recognition that a problem existed. The Treas-

Speaker: NA
Text: urer ( Mr Keating) then used irresponsibly col-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourful language, saying that Australia was

Speaker: NA
Text: heading towards being a banana republic. The

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy industry most likely would not be in need

Speaker: NA
Text: of Federal Government intervention if Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: had remained competitive in the world market

Speaker: NA
Text: for dairy products.

Speaker: NA
Text: We cannot place all the blame on the cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: rupted policies of the European Community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some of the difficulties of this industry can be

Speaker: NA
Text: laid squarely at the feet of the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: policies. How can this Government have the gall

Speaker: NA
Text: to burden farmers with a capital gains tax, which

Speaker: NA
Text: was introduced into this House last night, at a

Speaker: NA
Text: time when they are already experiencing severe

Speaker: NA
Text: financial hardships? This Government has shown

Speaker: NA
Text: little concern for the productive sector of the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy. Dairy farmers are skilled operators

Speaker: NA
Text: who cope with a tedium of routine that many

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians have rejected. Yet it is these people

Speaker: NA
Text: who are at the base of Australia's wealth-creat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing export commodities.

Speaker: NA
Text: In this area I commend the industry initiative

Speaker: NA
Text: of an all-milk levy that is designed to support

Speaker: NA
Text: returns to producers who sell to the lower priced

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing markets. That is where we earn

Speaker: NA
Text: our export income. There is no funding from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth for this initiative. It is, there-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore, particularly commendable because it shows

Speaker: NA
Text: a very tangible way that the dairy industry is

Speaker: NA
Text: not looking for easy options and Government

Speaker: NA
Text: handouts. It is realistic in facing the present

Speaker: NA
Text: economic difficulties of its members and has

Speaker: NA
Text: faced the issue with a boldness that shows that

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers are confident in their ability to compete

Speaker: NA
Text: with world market forces that are operating at

Speaker: NA
Text: present.

Speaker: NA
Text: The new marketing arrangements are, how-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, going to affect the Western Australian in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry and some moves are expected from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australian Government to exempt

Speaker: NA
Text: that Western Australian dairy farmers from the levy

Speaker: NA
Text: on all-milk products. If we are to have a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trollable and orderly restructuring of the dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, the rules have to apply to everybody

Speaker: NA
Text: involved. Yet I hasten to add that a mechanism

Speaker: NA
Text: of support must be found to ease the transition

Speaker: NA
Text: for those more seriously affected-the Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian, Queensland and New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers in this instance. I am acutely aware of

Speaker: NA
Text: the severe disruption that can occur when re-

Speaker: NA
Text: structuring for the benefit of the nation as a

Speaker: NA
Text: whole affects particular regions of the nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The closer economic ties and relationships

Speaker: NA
Text: which we have with New Zealand overall have

Speaker: NA
Text: probably been beneficial to Australia as a whole

Speaker: NA
Text: but northern Tasmania, which includes the elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torates of Bass, Braddon and part of Lyons, has

Speaker: NA
Text: been seriously affected. Perhaps this was one of

Speaker: NA
Text: the first attempts by governments to restructure

Speaker: NA
Text: in a major way for the benefit of the nation, but

Speaker: NA
Text: very little understanding of the affected regions

Speaker: NA
Text: was shown. There was no realistic appraisal by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government of the pain that was caused to

Speaker: NA
Text: northern Tasmania by restructuring under the

Speaker: NA
Text: CER legislation. This legislation again raises the

Speaker: NA
Text: issue that certain regions will be affected. Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernments should give cognisance to that and try

Speaker: NA
Text: to help these areas adjust.

Speaker: NA
Text: We must restructure our industries, our indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: vidual enterprises and the economic base of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia and make our industrial relations, wage

Speaker: NA
Text: fixing and training structures more flexible so

Speaker: NA
Text: that industries can be far more responsive to

Speaker: NA
Text: changing factors in the market-place. We all

Speaker: NA
Text: agree with that. At the same time, ways must

Speaker: NA
Text: be sought to help those who are detrimentally

Speaker: NA
Text: affected. In this case I call on the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: to consult the industry and to seek ways in

Speaker: NA
Text: which families of Western Australia can be as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sisted in making a readjustment of their loss, on

Speaker: NA
Text: average of between $4,000 to $5,000 in income

Speaker: NA
Text: in this legislation's first year of operation. If

Speaker: NA
Text: wage earners around Australia were to have

Speaker: NA
Text: their income dropped by $80 a week they would

Speaker: NA
Text: realise that it would create severe problems for

Speaker: NA
Text: them in their home budgets. The principle I have

Speaker: NA
Text: outlined should be etched into the minds of

Speaker: NA
Text: Government Ministers so that as the process of

Speaker: NA
Text: restructuring gathers momentum, as inevitably it

Speaker: NA
Text: will and must, the small people will not be

Speaker: NA
Text: ignored. There are some small people in the

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy industry in Western Australia, New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales and Queensland who could well be ig-

Speaker: NA
Text: nored in this legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is easy for people in government who draft

Speaker: NA
Text: policies to forget the real world of competition

Speaker: NA
Text: and hardship that can" be caused when govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments change direction. This Government to date

Speaker: NA
Text: has shown little practical concern for helping

Speaker: NA
Text: the productive sector cope with its radical

Speaker: NA
Text: changes. It is always interested in taxing the

Speaker: NA
Text: hard working, productive sector of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The entrepreneurs of this country are given min-

Speaker: NA
Text: imal incentive by this Government while it re-

Speaker: NA
Text: distributes wealth to the consuming sector of the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy as if money grows on trees. If it had

Speaker: NA
Text: not been for the strength and determination of

Speaker: NA
Text: the dairy industry's leadership and the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion's sound judgment in the Senate, dairy farm-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers and their families would have had the impost

Speaker: NA
Text: of an uncaring, unsympathetic Kerin plan foisted

Speaker: NA
Text: on them. The Opposition supports the legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: because marked changes have occurred which

Speaker: NA
Text: will give a degree of security to the hard working

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy farmers to plan for the future. That would

Speaker: NA
Text: not have occurred if the 1985 legislation had

Speaker: NA
Text: been passed unopposed.

Speaker: Mr FITZGIBBON
Text: Hunter) (11.58)-1 thank

Speaker: NA
Text: the Lord that the dairy farmers in the Hunter

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate have more sense than some politicians.

Speaker: NA
Text: They would have laughed at some of the biased

Speaker: NA
Text: nonsense spoken by the previous speaker, the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Braddon ( Mr Miles). I

Speaker: NA
Text: am very pleased to have the opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: speak in support of the Dairy Produce Bill 1986,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Dairy Produce Levy (No.1) Bill 1986, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Dairy Produce Levy (No.2) Bill 1986, the Dairy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Industry Research and Promotion Levy

Speaker: NA
Text: (Termination of Levy) Bill 1986, the Dairy In-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry Stabilization Levy (Termination of Levy)

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill 1986 and the Dairy Legislation (Transitional

Speaker: NA
Text: Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the second time we have had dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation before this House. It is important to

Speaker: NA
Text: stress that this legislation has been achieved after

Speaker: NA
Text: widespread and lengthy consultation between

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal and State governments and, more im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portantly, with State representatives of the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry itself. The dairy industry supports this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation and, if a bipartisan approach can be

Speaker: NA
Text: achieved, will be able to face the future with a

Speaker: NA
Text: degree of confidence that has not been possible

Speaker: NA
Text: in the past.

Speaker: NA
Text: The legislation provides the greatest scope for

Speaker: NA
Text: long term gains in economic efficiency. The prin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciple objective is the development of a more

Speaker: NA
Text: efficient and profitable dairy industry which is

Speaker: NA
Text: able to respond quickly to changing market con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ditions and technology. The reforming of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Dairy Corporation can do nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: but enhance the Corporation's ability to max-

Speaker: NA
Text: imise its market opportunities, despite the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that it faces a difficult market situation. The

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy industry has been in the doldrums for such

Speaker: NA
Text: a long time. The industry in the past has failed

Speaker: NA
Text: to agree on the direction legislation should take.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Kerin plan was defeated in the other place,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Rowley plan was defeated by the Victorians,

Speaker: NA
Text: and today we are now able to debate this legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation knowing that it has the support of the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. I believe that this legislation will give

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry the impetus it needs to get its act

Speaker: NA
Text: together, decide where it is going and move into

Speaker: NA
Text: more profitable areas of export, thus ending the

Speaker: NA
Text: turmoil that has prevailed for so many years.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I have said in this House before, the elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate of Hunter has a large dairy farming and

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing industry, and long before I was

Speaker: NA
Text: elected to represent the electorate of Hunter,

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy farmers there saw the need to rationalise,

Speaker: NA
Text: and many opted out of the industry. Today the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hunter is left with some of the most modern

Speaker: NA
Text: and efficient dairy farms in the whole of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia, and I assure those farmers that I sincerely

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that this legislation will not harm them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Instead, it will bring long term benefits by main-

Speaker: NA
Text: taining the largest Australian dairy industry that

Speaker: NA
Text: is viable, at an acceptable level of industry as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sistance. The domestic market must be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: defend its position on the basis of its competi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tiveness and the export market must strive to

Speaker: NA
Text: exploit the most profitable markets and minimise

Speaker: NA
Text: sales that are a net loss to Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I circulated this legislation to a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: people in the Hunter electorate involved in the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry to gauge their opinion of how the leg-

Speaker: NA
Text: islation would affect them. I take this opportu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity to express my deep appreciation to Singleton

Speaker: NA
Text: Shire President, Councillor Neil MCNamara, who

Speaker: NA
Text: is also a dairy farmer; Mr Bruce Payne, General

Speaker: NA
Text: Manager of the Hunter Valley Dairy Co-opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive Co. Pty Ltd, at Hexham, and Mr Bob

Speaker: NA
Text: Baldwin of the Singleton branch of the Hunter

Speaker: NA
Text: Valley Dairy Co-op; Mr Bruce Whitten of

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Anembo', Denmam, who has been most helpful;

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Bruce Russell of 'Rockley', Singleton; Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: of 'Eden Vale', Vacy; and others who found the

Speaker: NA
Text: time in their busy lives to consider the legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: and let me have their comments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Overall, the comment was that the legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: was well presented, and all acknowledged that

Speaker: NA
Text: it did have industry support from Mr Jack Eg-

Speaker: NA
Text: gert of the New South Wales Dairy Farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: Association. Some farmers expressed concern.

Speaker: NA
Text: One farmer expressed concern about the closer

Speaker: NA
Text: economic relations trade agreement with New

Speaker: NA
Text: Zealand and interpreted the second reading

Speaker: NA
Text: speech of the Minister for Primary Industry ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Kerin) to mean that the Australian domestic

Speaker: NA
Text: market milk price would be reduced to the price

Speaker: NA
Text: in New Zealand. However, the legislation does

Speaker: NA
Text: not intend to reduce the Australian domestic

Speaker: NA
Text: market milk price. In fact, the Federal Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has no control over domestic milk prices;

Speaker: NA
Text: they are the province of State governments.

Speaker: NA
Text: What the legislation seeks to do is progres-

Speaker: NA
Text: sively reduce the domestic price support to not

Speaker: NA
Text: higher than the price level at which New Zea-

Speaker: NA
Text: land dairy products could be sold in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: on a fair trade basis. In other words, there will

Speaker: NA
Text: be no price support beyond that level. The leg-

Speaker: NA
Text: islation also says that under the closer economic

Speaker: NA
Text: relations trade agreement with New Zealand, we

Speaker: NA
Text: should try to bring our dairy products into line

Speaker: NA
Text: with New Zealand, so we become more compet-

Speaker: NA
Text: itive on international markets. Domestic milk

Speaker: NA
Text: prices recently went up in Victoria and Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, and I believe they are due to go up in

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales today. This is the result of

Speaker: NA
Text: industry pressure on State governments to in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease the price.

Speaker: NA
Text: As all honourable members are aware, the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry is divided into two distinct sections-

Speaker: NA
Text: one is the fresh milk market and the other is the

Speaker: NA
Text: not so profitable manufacturing milk market.

Speaker: NA
Text: We export most of our manufactured milk, but,

Speaker: NA
Text: under the existing arrangements we often export

Speaker: NA
Text: at a loss, on already oversupplied international

Speaker: NA
Text: markets. Under the new arrangements, produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers and manufacturers can reap the benefits of

Speaker: NA
Text: their own decisions. By replacing the current

Speaker: NA
Text: stabilisation arrangements with a uniform level

Speaker: NA
Text: of assistance for all products, we will get rid of

Speaker: NA
Text: the distortions that exist. People will be encour-

Speaker: NA
Text: aged to be more efficient, to not over-produce,

Speaker: NA
Text: and to choose the right product to gain the best

Speaker: NA
Text: returns.

Speaker: NA
Text: From two dairy farmers in the Hunter Valley

Speaker: NA
Text: came the comment that they were concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: about the levy being on kilogram of milk fat

Speaker: NA
Text: content rather than by volume. They specifically

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned that jersey cows tend to produce milk

Speaker: NA
Text: with a higher content of milk fat than other

Speaker: NA
Text: breeds. However, most farmers are paid on milk

Speaker: NA
Text: fat content and technical reports on production

Speaker: NA
Text: of milk cattle indicate that although the milk fat

Speaker: NA
Text: content of milk produced by certain breeds of

Speaker: NA
Text: milk cattle is higher than others, the production

Speaker: NA
Text: of milk fat per cow is not significantly different.

Speaker: NA
Text: The market support levy on all milk recog-

Speaker: NA
Text: nises that under the current arrangements var-

Speaker: NA
Text: ious methods have determined the rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: payment, and this has differed from State to

Speaker: NA
Text: State. The new arrangement recognises these

Speaker: NA
Text: differences and the Government has tried to

Speaker: NA
Text: choose the method that is simplest and that is

Speaker: NA
Text: acceptable to the industry; the method which

Speaker: NA
Text: has the least number of enforcement problems.

Speaker: NA
Text: It could be argued that a levy on milk should

Speaker: NA
Text: be based on milk fat content and the solids non-

Speaker: NA
Text: fat content of milk, the same as in the European

Speaker: NA
Text: Economic Community countries. But the Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian manufacturers pay their suppliers on milk

Speaker: NA
Text: fat content only and have testing facilities for

Speaker: NA
Text: milk fat only. Installing testing facilities for sol-

Speaker: NA
Text: ids non-fat content could cost the industry mil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lions of dollars. If the industry can come up

Speaker: NA
Text: with a better formula, I know that the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: will be prepared to listen. As has been men-

Speaker: NA
Text: tioned by other honourable members, particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly the honourable member for MCMillan ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Cunningham), other formulae are being

Speaker: NA
Text: considered.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another dairy farmer expressed concern about

Speaker: NA
Text: over-production by the Victorians, and he felt

Speaker: NA
Text: that the levy might induce the Victorians to go

Speaker: NA
Text: on producing more and more manufactured milk

Speaker: NA
Text: on an already over-supplied market, and then

Speaker: NA
Text: ask for an increase in the rate of the levy. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government cannot set controls on production.

Speaker: NA
Text: The legislation seeks to reduce the gap between

Speaker: NA
Text: returns for fresh market milk and manufactured

Speaker: NA
Text: milk, thereby reducing the incentive for farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: to move into the fresh milk market. In a way,

Speaker: NA
Text: this is a bit of a transfer to the Victorians by

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing their income from manufactured milk

Speaker: NA
Text: products, but at the same time it takes pressure

Speaker: NA
Text: off the domestic milk market. It creates stability

Speaker: NA
Text: and reduces the likelihood of a trade war be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween the States. Nobody in the industry wants

Speaker: NA
Text: that.

Speaker: NA
Text: If there are no arrangements in place, all dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers would be out of pocket, there would be

Speaker: NA
Text: market wars and the only ones to benefit would

Speaker: NA
Text: be the consumers, and of course the New Zea-

Speaker: NA
Text: land dairy industry. I guess some dairy farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: are worrying unnecessarily about an increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: the levy. The levy could be increased only if the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry requested such an increase.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another comment related to the 60-day delay

Speaker: NA
Text: in lifting the levy-the comfort clause. Here

Speaker: NA
Text: again, it was acknowledged by all farmers-all

Speaker: NA
Text: dairymen-that this comfort clause allowing for

Speaker: NA
Text: a 60-day delay had the agreement of the indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try. Having a 60-day delay and also a mechanism

Speaker: NA
Text: whereby agreement from the other States is re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quired allows for a cooling-off period and will

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly stop people from overreacting.

Speaker: NA
Text: Victorians realise that there is nothing to be

Speaker: NA
Text: gained from a milk war. They have just as much

Speaker: NA
Text: to lose as their colleagues in other States. What

Speaker: NA
Text: the Victorians want-what all dairy farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: should want-is to have in place some sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: orderly marketing system. For this to happen

Speaker: NA
Text: they realise that they must try to lower their

Speaker: NA
Text: production to meet market-place demands. I be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve that dairy farmers, not just in the Hunter

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate, not just in New South Wales, but in

Speaker: NA
Text: all other States, have shown a great deal of

Speaker: NA
Text: common sense, and I believe that this legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: will be beneficial for all dairy farmers. This

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation will be beneficial because it provides

Speaker: NA
Text: for orderly marketing arrangements and presents

Speaker: NA
Text: a better balance of equity. That better balance

Speaker: NA
Text: and those improved marketing arrangements will

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit the entire industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another farmer in the Hunter electorate ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pressed concern about the research levy rate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Again, the dairy farmers realise that the industry

Speaker: NA
Text: as a whole has agreed to that rate. They have

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing to fear because the industry sets the

Speaker: NA
Text: levy. Today, when we are facing difficult mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: keting situations, research is the light at the

Speaker: NA
Text: of the tunnel. Every dairy farmer must realise

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is only by lifting our research activities

Speaker: NA
Text: that the industry will be able to develop new

Speaker: NA
Text: products which are more profitable. The whole

Speaker: NA
Text: spectrum of research benefits farmers and man-

Speaker: NA
Text: ufacturers alike and has the potential to increase

Speaker: NA
Text: significantly returns to the individual dairy farmer

Speaker: NA
Text: and to the whole industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: As was outlined by the Minister for Primary

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry in his second reading speech, export

Speaker: NA
Text: pooling arrangements will cease so that exporters

Speaker: NA
Text: become more market responsive. By replacing

Speaker: NA
Text: the current stabilisation arrangements with a

Speaker: NA
Text: more uniform level of assistance, a more profit-

Speaker: NA
Text: able mix of production will be encouraged. The

Speaker: NA
Text: new market support arrangements will be fi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nanced by a levy on all milk production. The

Speaker: NA
Text: local industry will continue to be protected

Speaker: NA
Text: against unfair import competition, and assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: is to be made available for specific purposes;

Speaker: NA
Text: namely, for adjustment, marketing innovation,

Speaker: NA
Text: research, and dairy underwriting. All these meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ures, along with others contained in the Bills,

Speaker: NA
Text: should place the Australian dairy industry in a

Speaker: NA
Text: much better position to adjust to market signals.

Speaker: NA
Text: They will ensure that the industry has a long

Speaker: NA
Text: term viable future, after years and years of worry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Not through any fault of this Government but

Speaker: NA
Text: because of a reluctance on the part of previous

Speaker: NA
Text: governments, the dairy farmers have been

Speaker: NA
Text: through periods of uncertainty and turmoil.

Speaker: NA
Text: Hopefully, those periods of uncertainty will come

Speaker: NA
Text: to an end.

Speaker: NA
Text: Despite what some honourable members op-

Speaker: NA
Text: posite had to say in their own petty little way,

Speaker: NA
Text: everybody within the dairy industry knows that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Primary Industry has done an

Speaker: NA
Text: absolutely marvellous job-he has probably taken

Speaker: NA
Text: ten years off his life-in bringing together this

Speaker: NA
Text: excellent dairy legislation package. His success

Speaker: NA
Text: has been outstanding. He has been able to bring

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry together, as it has never been brought

Speaker: NA
Text: together before, to reach agreement on this leg-

Speaker: NA
Text: islation. I commend the Minister-a great Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister for Primary Industry-and I commend the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bills to the House.

Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Text: Murray) (12.lS)-Like the dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers of Australia, the Opposition, while not

Speaker: NA
Text: being actually enthusiastic about the legislation,

Speaker: NA
Text: will not oppose it because it is seen as the best

Speaker: NA
Text: possible compromise at this time. I suggest to

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Hunter ( Mr Fitzgib-

Speaker: NA
Text: bon), who named certain dairy industry leaders

Speaker: NA
Text: in his electorate, that their attitude may more

Speaker: NA
Text: accurately be described as accepting the inevita-

Speaker: NA
Text: end ble compromise rather than really being in fa-

Speaker: NA
Text: vour of this legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Dairy Produce Bill, the Dairy Produce

Speaker: NA
Text: Levy (No.1) Bill, the Dairy Produce Levy (No.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2) Bill, the Dairying Industry Research and Pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: motion Levy (Termination of Levy) Bill, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Dairy Industry Stabilization Levy (Termination

Speaker: NA
Text: of Levy) Bill and the Dairy Legislation Transi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional Provisions and Consequential Amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments) Bill, which are before us today, are

Speaker: NA
Text: definitely better than the legislation presented 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months ago by the Minister for Primary Industry

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Kerin). To say that this legislation is part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Kerin plan and to say that it is in any

Speaker: NA
Text: way the same as the legislation introduced last

Speaker: NA
Text: year is not only an exaggeration but also most

Speaker: NA
Text: unfair both on the Minister and certainly on the

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy industry because of the improvements that

Speaker: NA
Text: have been made in that time. Because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: inability of the industry-it is no criticism of the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry to say that-in a most complex situa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to present a united and better proposal than

Speaker: NA
Text: that which we have now, it certainly is the best

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry can expect. For that reason it has

Speaker: NA
Text: the overall support of or, if you like, lack of

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition from the industry around Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is certainly better to have this legislation in

Speaker: NA
Text: place for the next season than to continue with

Speaker: NA
Text: the present arrangements, particularly when the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister has the ability to change or modify

Speaker: NA
Text: those arrangements, as he did for this current

Speaker: NA
Text: season, and thus reduce their value. Deferring

Speaker: NA
Text: that legislation for 12 months, which was spear-

Speaker: NA
Text: headed a year ago by the shadow Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Primary Industry, the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Gwydir ( Mr Hunt), in association with the dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, has been of tremendous value to the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry around Australia not only because of

Speaker: NA
Text: the additional income to the industry but also

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the better scheme that we have now.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is important legislation in that not only

Speaker: NA
Text: does it provide some stability for the industry

Speaker: NA
Text: and is a reasonable compromise between con-

Speaker: NA
Text: flicting interests; it is also a step towards a

Speaker: NA
Text: national industry. It is certainly the best hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that the industry has of maintaining stability on

Speaker: NA
Text: a national basis and of preventing a destructive

Speaker: NA
Text: interstate price war, which the great majority of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian dairy farmers, including those in Vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: toria, do not want to happen. I want to pay a

Speaker: NA
Text: tribute to Pat Rowley, the Chairman of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Dairy Farmers Federation, a man

Speaker: NA
Text: who has been very patient, very tolerant and

Speaker: NA
Text: very understanding of the complications and

Speaker: NA
Text: complexities in the industry. He is a great indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try leader. As a Victorian dairy farmer and a

Speaker: NA
Text: representative of more dairy cows, if you like,

Speaker: NA
Text: than any other member of the House of Repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives, I certainly pay him that tribute.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nevertheless, this legislation is less than the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry needs and deserves. The price increases

Speaker: NA
Text: to be allowed of 5 per cent for butter and 8 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent for cheese will be the first increases for

Speaker: NA
Text: years. They are under half the increase in salar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ies and wages that the great majority of Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lians have received in that four-year period. In

Speaker: NA
Text: that time there has been a dramatic increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: the government taxes and charges that have

Speaker: NA
Text: been inflicted on the dairy industry and on rural

Speaker: NA
Text: industry generally in Australia. That has also

Speaker: NA
Text: been highlighted by the shadow Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Primary Industry. The legislation also provides

Speaker: NA
Text: less than the industry needs and deserves in that

Speaker: NA
Text: the underwriting level has been reduced from

Speaker: NA
Text: the coalition level of 95 per cent to 85 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: I acknowledge that in some ways it is a better

Speaker: NA
Text: form of underwriting, but the fact that there is

Speaker: NA
Text: never likely to be any government commitment

Speaker: NA
Text: indicates what sort of weak underwriting it will

Speaker: NA
Text: be.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another factor is the closer economic relations

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangement with New Zealand, as now rede-

Speaker: NA
Text: fined by the Minister for Primary Industry. When

Speaker: NA
Text: CER was negotiated with New Zealand some

Speaker: NA
Text: years ago the dairy industry, to its credit, in co-

Speaker: NA
Text: operation with the Australian Government, the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry in New Zealand and the New Zealand

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, made an arrangement for a per-

Speaker: NA
Text: centage of cheese to come into Australia from

Speaker: NA
Text: New Zealand. Beyond that, for any basic change

Speaker: NA
Text: to occur in dairy trade between the two coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries required the agreement of both industries

Speaker: NA
Text: and, through them, of both governments. That

Speaker: NA
Text: was to be a permanent part of the agreement.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet at the National Agricultural Outlook Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ference last year we heard for the first time

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Minister for Primary Industry that that

Speaker: NA
Text: would no longer be the case. The arrangement

Speaker: NA
Text: was to be redefined to allow for a phase-out

Speaker: NA
Text: situation which would basically require an open-

Speaker: NA
Text: more door policy with New Zealand by 1990 to 1992.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is certainly not what the industries of both

Speaker: NA
Text: countries negotiated just a few years before.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that the fourth point of genuine

Speaker: NA
Text: criticism about this legislation is that the chair-

Speaker: NA
Text: man of the revised, the reformed or the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: worked Australian Dairy Corporation should be

Speaker: NA
Text: a dairy farmer. That is so in the case of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Wool Corporation; it is so in the case

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian Wheat Board. It should equally

Speaker: NA
Text: be so with the Dairy Corporation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The all-milk levy of up to 2c a litre or, tran-

Speaker: NA
Text: scribed, to a maximum of 45c per kilogram of

Speaker: NA
Text: butterfat, is a step towards a more national
