Speaker: NA
Text: industry. The comfort or escape clause which is

Speaker: NA
Text: part of the all-milk levy, which allows for the

Speaker: NA
Text: termination of the levy if there is a breakdown

Speaker: NA
Text: in the arrangements by the unauthorised inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: four state trade in milk is something in which both I

Speaker: NA
Text: and, I believe, the majority of my dairy farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: accept. I believe that it is both pointless and

Speaker: NA
Text: unfair to continue a levy if the reason for its

Speaker: NA
Text: being there has not been met. If there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: breakdown because of the entry of unauthorised

Speaker: NA
Text: interstate milk, I think that it is completely

Speaker: NA
Text: pointless to continue that levy and that, there-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore, the comfort clause is appropriate. That all-

Speaker: NA
Text: milk levy is really an insurance premium paid

Speaker: NA
Text: by those in the protected part of the dairy in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry of Australia. It is a premium paid by

Speaker: NA
Text: those who supply a large percentage of their

Speaker: NA
Text: milk to the city or market milk sector of the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. It is their insurance premium paid

Speaker: NA
Text: against the breakdown of the separation of pric-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing between manufacturing milk and market milk.

Speaker: NA
Text: Such an arrangement will bring financial pain

Speaker: NA
Text: to those dairy farmers who specialise in city milk

Speaker: NA
Text: production. At the estimated introductory rate

Speaker: NA
Text: of It to 1.7c per litre, I am told that it will cost

Speaker: NA
Text: the average dairy farmer in that situation $4,000

Speaker: NA
Text: to $5,000. I acknowledge that that will mean

Speaker: NA
Text: real financial pain for those dairy farmers and

Speaker: NA
Text: that it could force some of them to leave the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. It will be of value to the manufacturing

Speaker: NA
Text: milk dairy farmers in Victoria, Tasmania and

Speaker: NA
Text: parts of New South Wales and South Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, I say that it is the minimum insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: premium necessary to provide stability in the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the Murray River area, a dairy farmer

Speaker: NA
Text: farming immediately south of the Murray River

Speaker: NA
Text: compared to a dairy farmer farming immediately

Speaker: NA
Text: north of the Murray River receives a dramati-

Speaker: NA
Text: cally reduced net income for producing the same

Speaker: NA
Text: product of the same standard. To me, as an

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian, in this day of refrigerated milk, this

Speaker: NA
Text: is an absurdity. The same situation does not

Speaker: NA
Text: apply to the fat lamb producer of Australia. The

Speaker: NA
Text: same situation does not apply to the beef cattle

Speaker: NA
Text: producer, the grain producer and those who

Speaker: NA
Text: make manufactured products, et cetera.

Speaker: NA
Text: The comparison with New Zealand in this

Speaker: NA
Text: regard is quite interesting at present. I am ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vised that because of the termination of the very

Speaker: NA
Text: dramatic subsidies paid to New Zealand dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers through the supplementary minimum

Speaker: NA
Text: price scheme the price paid to New Zealand

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy farmers in the coming season will fall by

Speaker: NA
Text: about 25 per cent, from $NZ4 per kilogram

Speaker: NA
Text: butterfat to about $NZ3 a kilogram. What is

Speaker: NA
Text: interesting about that is that New Zealand also

Speaker: NA
Text: has a separate city milk sector and a separate

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing milk sector, as does Australia. In

Speaker: NA
Text: New Zealand the city milk sector producers will

Speaker: NA
Text: suffer a drop of 6c a litre in what they receive

Speaker: NA
Text: for their milk next year because that amount

Speaker: NA
Text: approximates the fall in what the manufacturing

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy farmers in New Zealand also will receive.

Speaker: NA
Text: In other words, they acknowledge the danger

Speaker: NA
Text: once the price for milk in the city milk sector

Speaker: NA
Text: gets too far away from that price paid for milk

Speaker: NA
Text: for the manufacturing sector. They believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: the insurance premium necessary for them to

Speaker: NA
Text: maintain their specialist role-their special sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor of the market-is worth far more than 1tc

Speaker: NA
Text: a litre; they believe it is worth 6c a litre. The

Speaker: NA
Text: pain that the New Zealand dairy farmers will

Speaker: NA
Text: suffer next year with a drop of about 25 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent in their price actually happened to the

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing dairy sector farmers not only in

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria but elsewhere in Australia three years

Speaker: NA
Text: ago. That pain of being confronted with the

Speaker: NA
Text: corrupted international dairy markets has inten-

Speaker: NA
Text: sified since then, and net returns to dairy farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: who supply manufacturing milk are now about

Speaker: NA
Text: 40 per cent less than what they were three years

Speaker: NA
Text: ago. That is exposure to the world market. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is exposure to market forces. That represents far

Speaker: NA
Text: more exposure to those manufacturing milk pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducers than for those who are able to concen-

Speaker: NA
Text: trate on producing city milk.

Speaker: NA
Text: I make the point that the greater the differ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ences between the manufacturing milk price and

Speaker: NA
Text: the city milk price, the greater the danger of a

Speaker: NA
Text: breakdown in this arrangement. Therefore, I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that there is a responsibility on the State

Speaker: NA
Text: pricing authorities to ensure that if they believe

Speaker: NA
Text: it is worthwhile to maintain a stable industry

Speaker: NA
Text: and for them to be able to maintain specialist

Speaker: NA
Text: sectors of the industry in those States, that price

Speaker: NA
Text: gap cannot be allowed to increase.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MCGauran-Gippsland demands it.

Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Text: The point made by the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member in regard to Gippsland is very

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate. Apart from me in my electorate,

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Gippsland probably

Speaker: NA
Text: represents more dairy cows than anyone else in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and the two most efficient sectors of

Speaker: NA
Text: the dairying industry in Australia. For anyone in

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland, for example, to say that it is unfair

Speaker: NA
Text: that Victorian dairy farmers should continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: produce milk because they have not adjusted to

Speaker: NA
Text: the market is like the Gippsland dairy farmer

Speaker: NA
Text: saying in turn: 'We used to produce sugar down

Speaker: NA
Text: here but we gave it away because it was more

Speaker: NA
Text: efficient to produce sugar in Queensland'. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: we should look at the dairy industry in the same

Speaker: NA
Text: way.

Speaker: NA
Text: I make the point, on the question of adjust-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, that in the Victorian situation not only

Speaker: NA
Text: has there been the pain of adjustment to a 40

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent drop in net returns over the last few

Speaker: NA
Text: years and hundreds of dairy farmers leaving the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry in that time, but also in the city milk

Speaker: NA
Text: sector of the industry in Victoria it can be seen

Speaker: NA
Text: that Victoria had a phase out arrangement over

Speaker: NA
Text: a 10-year period to end its milk quotas in order

Speaker: NA
Text: to rely on a price incentive to enable it to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide enough milk in those more difficult times

Speaker: NA
Text: of the year. That lO-year period has just· fin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ished. Quite a number of Victorian dairy farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: will cease production because they have been in

Speaker: NA
Text: that high priced specialist sector. Victorian dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers ask why the other eastern States do not

Speaker: NA
Text: put their own city milk sectors in more efficient

Speaker: NA
Text: order and make them as efficient as they can by

Speaker: NA
Text: doing the same thing as has been done in Vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: toria. I personally believe that both Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: and New South Wales could continue to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce all the milk they need for their own city

Speaker: NA
Text: milk requirements 12 months of the year by

Speaker: NA
Text: using a price incentive system rather than a

Speaker: NA
Text: quota system, and in a far more efficient way.

Speaker: NA
Text: My last point is that when one talks about

Speaker: NA
Text: fair competition in the industry-we are talking

Speaker: NA
Text: about it now-one also has to include fair com-

Speaker: NA
Text: petition from overseas. We talk in particular in

Speaker: NA
Text: this regard about cheese imports from Europe-

Speaker: NA
Text: not just from the European Economic Commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity. We are not talking just about subsidised

Speaker: NA
Text: imports; we are talking about the addition of

Speaker: NA
Text: additives and preservatives to those products-

Speaker: NA
Text: additives and preservatives which are banned in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia because they are considered a danger

Speaker: NA
Text: to the health of the people of Australia. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have been told-I have tended to accept this-

Speaker: NA
Text: that because the pure food Act powers are under

Speaker: NA
Text: the control of the States rather than the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth, we have to wait for the model food

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation-which is taking some years to come

Speaker: NA
Text: through, but which is on its way-when we will

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to do something on a uniform basis. We

Speaker: NA
Text: will then be able to say that that cheese coming

Speaker: NA
Text: from France will no longer be allowed in be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause it contains a preservative which we con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sider to be injurious to our health in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: That explanation was fine until 8 May, when

Speaker: NA
Text: in this place the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke),

Speaker: NA
Text: in response to a good question asked by the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Wannon ( Mr Hawker)

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to contaminated foodstuffs from the

Speaker: NA
Text: area contaminated by the Chernobyl nuclear dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: aster in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics,

Speaker: NA
Text: said:

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . the Department of Health asked the Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian Customs Service to hold all food consignments

Speaker: NA
Text: which left the potentially affected countries on or after

Speaker: NA
Text: 25 April. Should it prove necessary, the Department

Speaker: NA
Text: will establish a mechanism for monitoring these partic-

Speaker: NA
Text: ular food imports with the Customs Serv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ice . . . As the Department gets further

Speaker: NA
Text: information, those controls will be adjusted if necessary.

Speaker: NA
Text: Suddenly, out of the blue, we have a Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth power. We have a Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: power to stop dangerous food substances coming

Speaker: NA
Text: into this country. What the hell! Consider all

Speaker: NA
Text: the time that we have lost with not having the

Speaker: NA
Text: power to stop the import of these dairy products

Speaker: NA
Text: containing additives. If honourable members be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve that I am joking, I will inform them of

Speaker: NA
Text: something that happened in California recently.

Speaker: NA
Text: Cheese imports to the United States from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bessnier cheese company of France caused the

Speaker: NA
Text: death of 85 people in California last year. In

Speaker: NA
Text: response to a question on notice from me as to

Speaker: NA
Text: whether any of the cheese from this same com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pany was coming in to Australia, the answer was

Speaker: NA
Text: yes. What are we doing about it? We found out

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is not the same brand, but everybody

Speaker: NA
Text: knows that different brands are put on the same

Speaker: NA
Text: production line, depending on the country to

Speaker: NA
Text: which the brand is going. That is all that has

Speaker: NA
Text: been done, other than to refer it to the States to

Speaker: NA
Text: see whether they want to check it. Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: consumers are being exposed to great dangers

Speaker: NA
Text: and this is a specific example of the great danger

Speaker: NA
Text: of injurious foods-in this case, cheese-being

Speaker: NA
Text: imported. I conclude by making the point that

Speaker: NA
Text: when we talk about fair competition we are

Speaker: NA
Text: talking not just about fair competition for the

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy industry in Australia but about fair com-

Speaker: NA
Text: petition from New Zealand and particularly from

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe. Fair competition does not mean just

Speaker: NA
Text: price, it means the quality of the product. I

Speaker: NA
Text: support the legislation.

Speaker: Mr SNOW
Text: Eden-Monaro) (12.31)-The

Speaker: NA
Text: Dairy Produce Bill, the Dairy Produce Levy

Speaker: NA
Text: (No.1) Bill, the Dairy Produce Levy (No.2)

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill, the Dairying Industry Research and Pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: motion Levy (Termination of Levy) Bill, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Dairy Industry Stabilization Levy (Termination

Speaker: NA
Text: of Levy) Bill and the Dairy Legislation (Tran-

Speaker: NA
Text: sitional Provisions and Consequential Amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments) Bill include some small but very

Speaker: NA
Text: significant changes to the Bills dealt with by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament last year. Consultation between the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry and the Government has led to this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation which, while based substantially on

Speaker: NA
Text: previous legislation, is far more widely accepted.

Speaker: NA
Text: I congratulate the industry and the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Primary Industry ( Mr Kerin) for their intermin-

Speaker: NA
Text: able patience and preparedness continually to

Speaker: NA
Text: discuss, probe and rehash the various proposals.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Bills provide for a number of changes

Speaker: NA
Text: which will overcome many, if not all, of the

Speaker: NA
Text: inefficiencies of the present arrangements. Firstly,

Speaker: NA
Text: the overall aim is to turn our attention to the

Speaker: NA
Text: more profitable export markets and to disc-ur­

Speaker: NA
Text: age sales to the loss making markets. Secondly,

Speaker: NA
Text: the BiIIs will improve the accountability to the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry of the Australian Dairy Corporation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Thirdly, instead of a range of different levies,

Speaker: NA
Text: charges and support rates for different products,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Bills provide for an all milk levy. There

Speaker: NA
Text: be no artificial or contrived distortions to the

Speaker: NA
Text: market signals.

Speaker: NA
Text: Because any change creates uncertainty and

Speaker: NA
Text: confusion, the initial market support rate will

Speaker: NA
Text: set at 30 per cent, which closely parallels the

Speaker: NA
Text: current export pooling figure. This rate can be

Speaker: NA
Text: altered by mutual agreement between the Cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: poration and the Council of the Australian Dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry Conference. The industry will decide

Speaker: NA
Text: its own rate, not members of parliament or

Speaker: NA
Text: bureaucrats. To assist the transition further, a

Speaker: NA
Text: supplementary series of payments wiII be made.

Speaker: NA
Text: These will decline over time as the levies which

Speaker: NA
Text: are used to fund them are reduced. As with

Speaker: NA
Text: most changes, a lot depends on consistent eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic policies by the government of the day. In

Speaker: NA
Text: that light, one potential trouble spot in the ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rangements is the concept of reducing domestic

Speaker: NA
Text: price support until it is in accord with a fair

Speaker: NA
Text: New Zealand price. This could be a problem if

Speaker: NA
Text: wages and government charges are not kept sta-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble, as they have been under the Hawke Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister's motives in leading up to this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation over years rather than months have

Speaker: NA
Text: never been doubted by the industry leaders, right

Speaker: NA
Text: through the discussions. In public and private

Speaker: NA
Text: discussions the Minister dealt with the interests

Speaker: NA
Text: of the industry, consumers and the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: with honesty and discernment, but above all

Speaker: NA
Text: with wisdom based on his wide knowledge and

Speaker: NA
Text: experience of the industry. Having been involved

Speaker: NA
Text: in extensive discussions, lobbying and sheer hard

Speaker: NA
Text: work with many industry leaders, I see this leg-

Speaker: NA
Text: islation, the end result, as a direct consequence

Speaker: NA
Text: of vigorous work by people such as Pat Rowley,

Speaker: NA
Text: the President of the Dairy Farmers Federation;

Speaker: NA
Text: Clay Manners; and Phillip Armstrong and his

Speaker: NA
Text: associates from Bega Co-op Society Ltd. Pat

Speaker: NA
Text: Rowley, on behalf of the Australian Dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: Farmers Federation, has thanked me for my

Speaker: NA
Text: work. More importantly, he has said that the

Speaker: NA
Text: package of legislation wiII be worth tens of

Speaker: NA
Text: lions of dollars more to the industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: I return to the point I made concerning the

Speaker: NA
Text: problem of the effect of possible wage and price

Speaker: NA
Text: changes on the industry and the potential trou-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble spot in reducing domestic price support until

Speaker: NA
Text: It IS In accord with a fair New Zealand price,

Speaker: NA
Text: unless we have that stability. I remind my col-

Speaker: NA
Text: leagues and listeners of the rampant and hap-

Speaker: NA
Text: hazard wage and price movements during the

Speaker: NA
Text: Fraser years. Without a wage policy or an ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cord, oil refinery workers at that time were able

Speaker: NA
Text: to gain large wage increases because the oil

Speaker: NA
Text: will companies, which could pass on costs to the

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers, fishermen, truckies and the general mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: toring public, capitulated to their demands.

Speaker: NA
Text: The latest Opposition policy on industrial re-

Speaker: NA
Text: be lations would make things worse and I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that it could have a significant effect on the

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy industry. The proposal in the coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: policy to replace award rates with negotiated

Speaker: NA
Text: rates between employers and employees would

Speaker: NA
Text: lead to even higher wages for those earners with

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial muscle, lower wages for those workers

Speaker: NA
Text: in the country who have no industrial muscle

Speaker: NA
Text: and more of the old Fraser-Howard wage price

Speaker: NA
Text: spirals nationally. This would hinder, or perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: even obliterate, the competitive aim of a reduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in domestic price support.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the most significant factors of this Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: is the improved market signals which will result

Speaker: NA
Text: from it. Current underwritten prices are 90 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of a three-year average. This allows the

Speaker: NA
Text: underwriting mechanism to be triggered as prices

Speaker: NA
Text: decline after a period of buoyant prices. This

Speaker: NA
Text: could and did occur even though the absolute

Speaker: NA
Text: prices were relatively good. On the other hand,

Speaker: NA
Text: if prices declined gradually over a long period,

Speaker: NA
Text: the mechanism was not triggered. This not only

Speaker: NA
Text: deprived everyone involved of a proper price for

Speaker: NA
Text: their product but also masked any market signals.

Speaker: NA
Text: The two major problems which have been

Speaker: NA
Text: collectivdy perceived by the industry in Victoria

Speaker: NA
Text: and New South Wales are the need for an initial

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic price increase and the need for protec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion from market disruption by people seIling in

Speaker: NA
Text: desperation at below the cost of production and

Speaker: NA
Text: distribution or a little above that cost. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: light of that, the Government has allowed for a

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic market price increase. The Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has agreed to implement a domestic mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ket price increase for butter and cheese effective

Speaker: NA
Text: from 1 July. The Australian Dairy Corporation

Speaker: NA
Text: had recommended a 5 per cent increase in butter

Speaker: NA
Text: prices and an 8 per cent increase in cheese

Speaker: NA
Text: mil- prices, and the Government has accepted the

Speaker: NA
Text: ADC's recommendation. If we are to allow those

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic market price increases, we need to

Speaker: NA
Text: balance them with an escape clause to offset the

Speaker: NA
Text: anxiety in some States of supporting the export

Speaker: NA
Text: of dairy products by a levy on all milk in the

Speaker: NA
Text: event of a collapse in market milk prices. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has agreed to insert an escape clause

Speaker: NA
Text: in clause 6 of the Dairy Produce Levy (No.1)

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill. The inclusion of that clause in the legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is endorsed by all State dairy farmer

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations.

Speaker: NA
Text: World milk production is currently around

Speaker: NA
Text: 500 million tonnes, 60 per cent of which is

Speaker: NA
Text: produced in three regions; the European Eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic Community, the United States of Amer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ica and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.

Speaker: NA
Text: The majority of milk produced in those coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries is consumed within those countries; only 6

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent enters the world trade. Historically the

Speaker: NA
Text: European Economic Community has been the

Speaker: NA
Text: major stockholder and the major exporting re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gion, accounting for about half of global stocks.

Speaker: NA
Text: Relatively low economic growth in the major

Speaker: NA
Text: importing countries, together with their debt

Speaker: NA
Text: servicing problems, has seriously affected the

Speaker: NA
Text: trade patterns of the European Economic Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity. In 1983 production exceeded consump-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion by approximately 21 million tonnes, which

Speaker: NA
Text: is 19 per cent of its total annual output. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: idea of the impact that has had on world mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: kets can be seen by considering that in 1984 the

Speaker: NA
Text: European Economic Community sold 222 kilo-

Speaker: NA
Text: tons of butter to the Soviet Union at prices

Speaker: NA
Text: below the General Agreement on Tariffs and

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade minimum. It is estimated that at present

Speaker: NA
Text: international stocks of butter are at a level of

Speaker: NA
Text: 1.2 million tonnes. Where would the world, and

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly the European Community be with-

Speaker: NA
Text: out preservatives?

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn to Australia's position in world trade.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are a relatively small exporter of dairy prod-

Speaker: NA
Text: ucts. About a quarter of our output is exported,

Speaker: NA
Text: but that accounts for only between 2 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: and 8 per cent in various world product markets.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our dairy industry represents between 6 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: and 8 per cent of rural production. That is still

Speaker: NA
Text: a major component of the economy. It also

Speaker: NA
Text: represents 3 to 4 per cent of Australia's exports.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian dairy industry is extremely effi-

Speaker: NA
Text: -ient. The milk yield per cow, for instance, has

Speaker: NA
Text: mcreased by 18 per cent since 1970. Australia is

Speaker: NA
Text: internationally accepted as being the most effi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cient milk producer. I have had great pleasure

Speaker: NA
Text: in representing the most efficient producers within

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia in spite of what our Victorian col-

Speaker: NA
Text: leagues have said. I refer to those in the south

Speaker: NA
Text: coast area-the Bega Valley Shire, the Eurobod-

Speaker: NA
Text: alIa Shire and the City of Shoalhaven.

Speaker: NA
Text: Part of the problem leading up to this legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is that the pattern throughout Australia is

Speaker: NA
Text: extremely uneven. Hence the different responses

Speaker: NA
Text: to this legislation, even today. Even within polit12.45

Speaker: NA
Text: ical parties we have seen different responses to

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislation. Seventy-three per cent of our

Speaker: NA
Text: national output goes into manufacturing milk,

Speaker: NA
Text: yet in Victoria manufacturing milk constitutes

Speaker: NA
Text: 87 per cent of output. Further insight into our

Speaker: NA
Text: unbalanced production pattern can be gained by

Speaker: NA
Text: comparing the two major milk-producing States-

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales and Victoria. Victoria pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duces 57.6 per cent of total milk output, repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: senting 28 per cent of total market milk sales

Speaker: NA
Text: and 68 per cent of manufacturing milk. On the

Speaker: NA
Text: other hand, New South Wales output represents

Speaker: NA
Text: 16 per cent of total production, being 35 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of all market milk sales and only 9 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: of the manufacturing milk. Victoria produces 68

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of the manufacturing milk and New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales produces 9 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: As can be seen from the broad range of figures

Speaker: NA
Text: that I have cited, Australia is only a relatively

Speaker: NA
Text: small participant in the world trade. As a r!!suit,

Speaker: NA
Text: we are at the mercy of large-albeit relatively

Speaker: NA
Text: inefficient-producers such as those in the Eu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ropean community and the United States of

Speaker: NA
Text: America. We also have our own unbalanced

Speaker: NA
Text: internal production pattern with different areas

Speaker: NA
Text: concentrating on different sectors of production.

Speaker: NA
Text: For this reason, I believe it is vital that we

Speaker: NA
Text: overhaul our markets and our production strat-

Speaker: NA
Text: egies. These Bills seek to do just that. The dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: industry traditionally has been one of boom or

Speaker: NA
Text: bust. To quite an extent it is in the export area

Speaker: NA
Text: that a lot of problems have been created. Our

Speaker: NA
Text: consumption has been fairly stable and our

Speaker: NA
Text: growth has been fairly predictable.

Speaker: NA
Text: Legislation before us today is designed gradu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ally to move away from the low-priced end of

Speaker: NA
Text: the market and to stop exports of products at

Speaker: NA
Text: below cost, discourage the processors and co-

Speaker: NA
Text: operatives from taking milk at any price-even

Speaker: NA
Text: as low as perhaps one cent a litre, just to take

Speaker: NA
Text: it from the producer-concentrate our efforts on

Speaker: NA
Text: the more lucrative areas and make the market

Speaker: NA
Text: signals to our producers much clearer and at a

Speaker: NA
Text: much earlier stage. Surely this is much fairer to

Speaker: NA
Text: them as well as to the consumer. To sum up the

Speaker: NA
Text: words of Pat Rowley, the President of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Dairy Farmers Federation, in money terms

Speaker: NA
Text: this legislation will be worth tens of millions of

Speaker: NA
Text: dollars more to the industry. I have great pleas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ure in supporting the Bills before the House.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Cowan)-I call

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Berowra.

Speaker: Dr HARRY EDWARDS
Text: Berowra) (12.45)-

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Order! It being

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m., the debate is interrupted in accord-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance with sessional order lOlA. The debate may

Speaker: NA
Text: be resumed at a later hour. The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member will then receive the opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: continue his speech.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

Speaker: NA
Text: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: NA
Text: ANZUS TREATY

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the Acting Prime Minister. I draw his attention

Speaker: NA
Text: to Press reports, the first of which emanated in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Hobart Mercury on Monday of this week

Speaker: NA
Text: following the State Labor Conference, indicating

Speaker: NA
Text: that a member of the Australian Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: national foreign affairs and defence platform

Speaker: NA
Text: committee had said that the ANZUS Treaty

Speaker: NA
Text: would soon be replaced by two separate agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments with the United States of America and

Speaker: NA
Text: New Zealand. Bearing in mind that this platform

Speaker: NA
Text: committee also comprises Ministers Beazley,

Speaker: NA
Text: Hayden and Evans, will the Acting Prime Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister confirm that two such agreements are being

Speaker: NA
Text: or have been drafted; and, if so, why the ParliaUnited

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and the people of Australia have not been

Speaker: NA
Text: told that ANZUS; our most basic defence treaty,

Speaker: NA
Text: is to be scrapped?

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Text: It must be clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: understood that in the process of policy formu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation there are committees' of the parties that

Speaker: NA
Text: make suggestions which even the Liberal Party

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia at times is not prepared to accept.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can understand that there might be a view that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a need to talk about ANZUS in another

Speaker: NA
Text: form. It is certainly not official. From the Govthere

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment's point of view there has been no

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendation.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: committee.

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Text: That does not mean

Speaker: NA
Text: a lot in terms of the recommendation. We are a

Speaker: NA
Text: very democratic party and everybody has a right

Speaker: NA
Text: to express a point of view. ANZUS is a very

Speaker: NA
Text: important aspect of treaty organisations in the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole of the Pacific region. The Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: has already indicated the support of the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment for the continuance of that treaty. I would

Speaker: NA
Text: think it would require strong evidence to suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: that it might be altered in any way.

Speaker: NA
Text: As honourable members will be aware, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has already indicated that it is very

Speaker: NA
Text: anxious to ensure that there is continued peace

Speaker: NA
Text: and stability in the whole of the Pacific region.

Speaker: NA
Text: ANZUS is a very important part of that. The

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable gentleman would be aware that in

Speaker: NA
Text: parts of the world, not only in the Pacific, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: recognised that there is concern about nuclear

Speaker: NA
Text: weapons and matters of that nature. The whole

Speaker: NA
Text: question of whether there has been some defect

Speaker: NA
Text: in ANZUS, which I do not think there is, was

Speaker: NA
Text: the concept of visiting nuclear powered war-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships. A problem which has attracted public

Speaker: NA
Text: opinion in New Zealand is the tendency to per-

Speaker: NA
Text: haps talk about ANZUS in a form other than

Speaker: NA
Text: allowing nuclear armed warships to visit its ports.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that is the whole weakness of the struc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture. I would have thought that if the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States had had a chance to discuss this matter

Speaker: NA
Text: in a better atmosphere than apparently occurred

Speaker: NA
Text: at the time we would have found that the New

Speaker: NA
Text: Zealand people fully support close collaboration

Speaker: NA
Text: with the United States in stability and peace in

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole of the Pacific region. The one concept

Speaker: NA
Text: that seemed to concern them was the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: there might have been nuclear powered warships

Speaker: NA
Text: visiting their country.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know that is a distinction the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman would be able to understand. The

Speaker: NA
Text: States was not prepared to identify its

Speaker: NA
Text: warships on the basis that they would become

Speaker: NA
Text: vulnerable. No other power in the world identi-

Speaker: NA
Text: fies its nuclear armed warships, so for that rea-

Speaker: NA
Text: son there is a very clear understanding why the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States is reticent to disclose the identity

Speaker: NA
Text: of weaponry on its ships. For that reason I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not think the honourable gentleman should be

Speaker: NA
Text: unduly concerned about whether there would be

Speaker: NA
Text: any weakening of ANZUS. In my view, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is firmly committed to ANZUS. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, in party deliberations in a democracy

Speaker: NA
Text: are different points of view, all of which

Speaker: NA
Text: must be listened to, but from the point of view

Speaker: NA
Text: of a committee making recommendations to a

Speaker: NA
Text: national conference I would not give the rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ommendations any greater weight at this stage.

Speaker: NA
Text: WAGE INCREASE

Speaker: Mr ALLAN MORRIS
Text: My question is ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dressed to the Minister for Employment and

Speaker: NA
Text: Industrial Relations. Is it a fact that the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and the Australian Council of Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: Unions, in recognition of the inflationary and

Speaker: NA
Text: other effects of devaluation, have made submis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Commission that would reduce the next

Speaker: NA
Text: wage increase by 2 per cent? Is it also a fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that Australian unions and workers in general

Speaker: NA
Text: have accepted the need for this discounting of

Speaker: NA
Text: the next wage increase? Can the Minister advise

Speaker: NA
Text: the House what action the Government is taking

Speaker: NA
Text: to attempt to ensure that other people working

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia in professions, in executive positions

Speaker: NA
Text: and in the various other areas not covered by

Speaker: NA
Text: the national wage case have their income in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creases discounted by 2 per cent? Will the Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister further advise the House whether the many

Speaker: NA
Text: professional and business organisations who are

Speaker: NA
Text: calling on the Government to cut real wages

Speaker: NA
Text: further are making any real effort to achieve at

Speaker: NA
Text: least the 2 per cent discounting agreed to by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and the ACTU?

Speaker: Mr WILLIS
Text: The answer to the first two

Speaker: NA
Text: parts of the honourable member's question is, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, yes. As a consequence, it is likely that,

Speaker: NA
Text: as in the current national wage case, the out-

Speaker: NA
Text: come will be an adjustment of wages of at least

Speaker: NA
Text: 2 per cent less than the increases that would

Speaker: NA
Text: come with full indexation. So we see that there

Speaker: NA
Text: is a considerable adjustment taking place with

Speaker: NA
Text: the agreement of the ACTU and the trade union

Speaker: NA
Text: movement. The thrust of the honourable gentle-

Speaker: NA
Text: man's question is, of course, one with which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government very much agrees. If there is to be

Speaker: NA
Text: restraint exercised by wage and salary earners it

Speaker: NA
Text: is very important that restraint is exercised by

Speaker: NA
Text: all sections of the community. That is something

Speaker: NA
Text: that was unanimously agreed to by all parties at

Speaker: NA
Text: what was a summit in this chamber in 1983.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since that time action has been taken by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government to try to ensure that there would

Speaker: NA
Text: be restraint in the environment of wage and

Speaker: NA
Text: salary earners, and that there be restraint by

Speaker: NA
Text: other income recipients. In that respect, action

Speaker: NA
Text: has been taken to establish a number of tribunals

Speaker: NA
Text: to look at establishing the fees in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the professions. I refer to the Pharma-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal; the

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Costs Advisory Committee, which deter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mines solicitors' cost scales in the Federal legal

Speaker: NA
Text: jurisdiction; the medical fees inquiry, which this

Speaker: NA
Text: year unfortunately has been walked away from

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Australian Medical Association and its

Speaker: NA
Text: surgeons-the Government has made a decision

Speaker: NA
Text: of its own in that respect for this year, but

Speaker: NA
Text: prefers the inquiry approach-and also in rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to pathology services.

Speaker: NA
Text: In respect of all of those tribunals or fee

Speaker: NA
Text: setting processes there have been two elements

Speaker: NA
Text: to the consideration. In all those cases it has a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the Arbitration Commission who has

Speaker: NA
Text: formed the tribunal or inquiry which has looked

Speaker: NA
Text: at fees in two respects: One is a net income

Speaker: NA
Text: component and the other is a professional costs

Speaker: NA
Text: component. In both those respects they have had

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to wage fixing principles; that is, they

Speaker: NA
Text: have adjusted costs only where they have moved

Speaker: NA
Text: in line with wages, where they are wage costs.

Speaker: NA
Text: In respect of net incomes they have looked at

Speaker: NA
Text: the reason for those incomes to increase in line

Speaker: NA
Text: with movement for wage and salary earners. So

Speaker: NA
Text: the members of those tribunals have had very

Speaker: NA
Text: much in mind the need for the national wage

Speaker: NA
Text: fixing principles to apply in those areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: Reviews have also been conducted of fee set-

Speaker: NA
Text: ting processes for various other professionals such

Speaker: NA
Text: as architects, consulting engineers, accountants,

Speaker: NA
Text: dentists, quantity surveyors and veterinarians,

Speaker: NA
Text: and one review will start shortly on land survey-

Speaker: NA
Text: ors. All those have been conducted by members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Arbitration Commission, with the agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the professions, and have generally been

Speaker: NA
Text: established to ensure that the fee setting proc-

Speaker: NA
Text: esses are such as to mean that the general prin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciples applying to wage and salary earners apply

Speaker: NA
Text: in these areas to the extent that it is appropriate.

Speaker: NA
Text: That has given substantial assurance that in the

Speaker: NA
Text: area of the professions there has been that close

Speaker: NA
Text: association of principles applying in the profes-

Speaker: NA
Text: sional fee setting area with wage and salary

Speaker: NA
Text: earners.

Speaker: NA
Text: In relation to executive remuneration, the Ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: visory Committee on Prices and Incomes has

Speaker: NA
Text: kept a close watch on that with available mate-

Speaker: NA
Text: rial and has also commissioned some material.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over the period we have been in government,

Speaker: NA
Text: broadly speaking executive remuneration has

Speaker: NA
Text: been moving in line with that of wage and salary

Speaker: NA
Text: earners. We will be keeping a close check on

Speaker: NA
Text: that to ensure that that will continue to be the

Speaker: NA
Text: case. An examination of profits, dividends and

Speaker: NA
Text: investment has been conducted, which has shown

Speaker: NA
Text: that restraint has been exercised generally in

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of dividend policy. We would also expect

Speaker: NA
Text: that to continue. It is also establishing a meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: urement of profits and an agreement to a vol-

Speaker: NA
Text: untary standard within the accounting profession

Speaker: NA
Text: in respect of the use of that measurement of

Speaker: NA
Text: profits. We hope that that will be achieved in

Speaker: NA
Text: the near future.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, in relation to price restraint let me

Speaker: NA
Text: say that the Prices Surveillance Authority has,

Speaker: NA
Text: of course, been established. That body was in-

Speaker: NA
Text: structed by the Treasurer last year to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that the policy it pursued in respect of pricing

Speaker: NA
Text: matters which come before it was such that

Speaker: NA
Text: prices did not increase in excess of movements

Speaker: NA
Text: in unit costs. That is a general principle which

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriately applies, and rightly so.

Speaker: NA
Text: So, a number of processes have been estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lished to try to ensure that restraint is exercised

Speaker: NA
Text: across the board. Of course, I note the objections

Speaker: NA
Text: of members of the Opposition who do not care

Speaker: NA
Text: about what happens to the incomes of others.

Speaker: NA
Text: They think that restraints should apply to wage

Speaker: NA
Text: and salary earners. They do not give a damn

Speaker: NA
Text: what happens in respect of other areas and

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that people can do as they like. That, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, is not a policy which is accepted by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. We will be continuing to monitor

Speaker: NA
Text: this area and, if further steps are needed to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that restraint is exercised in the non-wage

Speaker: NA
Text: income area, we will take those steps.

Speaker: NA
Text: TAXATION REFORM

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: My question is addressed to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer. I refer the honourable gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Prime Minister's enunciation last year of

Speaker: NA
Text: nine fundamental principles of tax reform. In

Speaker: NA
Text: particular I refer him to the fourth and eighth

Speaker: NA
Text: of those principles. The fourth principle read as

Speaker: NA
Text: follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: Any reform must lead to a simpler system, which

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore all Australians can understand easily.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other principle is:

Speaker: NA
Text: Any reform must provide the best possible climate

Speaker: NA
Text: for investment, growth and employment in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I ask the Treasurer: By what stretch of imagi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nation can the fringe benefits tax legislation of

Speaker: NA
Text: 139 pages, the capital gains tax legislation of 103

Speaker: NA
Text: pages, the negative gearing legislation of 47 pages,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the other legislation introduced last night of

Speaker: NA
Text: 77 pages, meet the Prime Minister's criteria for

Speaker: NA
Text: sensible tax reform? Furthermore, will the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer indicate whether his inability to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide the Parliament with explanatory memo-

Speaker: NA
Text: randa for the capital gains tax and the foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: tax credit legislation is due to administrative

Speaker: NA
Text: incompetence, or is it the sheer complexity of

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislation which is defying proper

Speaker: NA
Text: explanation?

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: Just on the last point, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government provided the Opposition with all of

Speaker: NA
Text: the documentation it had three hours before I

Speaker: NA
Text: presented the Bills last night, including the Bills

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves and those explanatory memoranda

Speaker: NA
Text: which were available. The reason that the other

Speaker: NA
Text: material is not available is not just that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: had continual difficulties in getting all of this

Speaker: NA
Text: drafted but also that there have been industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: problems in the printery this week. I might just

Speaker: NA
Text: add that, despite the wailing by the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Mackellar last evening, and despite

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that the Government provided these

Speaker: NA
Text: things to Senator Messner three hours later, when

Speaker: NA
Text: I provided a briefing on the Bills this morning

Speaker: NA
Text: by tax officers, the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Mackellar never even bothered to turn up. So

Speaker: NA
Text: what about that? A couple of staff people ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rived. Although the honourable member has

Speaker: NA
Text: made such a brouhaha about it, he did not even

Speaker: NA
Text: have the decency to turn up and listen or ask a

Speaker: NA
Text: question. This really meant that he was trying

Speaker: NA
Text: to make a cheap political point rather than learn

Speaker: NA
Text: something, which I understood was his attitude

Speaker: NA
Text: in the first place.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me deal with the first question. This man

Speaker: NA
Text: who made a swill of the Australian tax system

Speaker: NA
Text: and who was dragged into doing something about

Speaker: NA
Text: it by the MCCabe-Lafranchi report and the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: port of the Costigan Royal Commission on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and

Speaker: NA
Text: Dockers Union, now wishes to refer to the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's nine principles in respect of tax re-

Speaker: NA
Text: form as some sort of reason why the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment should not move on tax avoidance in the

Speaker: NA
Text: fringe benefits area and why the Government, in

Speaker: NA
Text: a capital scarce country, ought not to do some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing about the proper placement of capital

Speaker: NA
Text: rather than seeing it squandered, by tax driven

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions, in areas of tax free capital gains. What

Speaker: NA
Text: we see is the Opposition using any port of call

Speaker: NA
Text: to continue its barrage and its sham of a policy

Speaker: NA
Text: for its inaction of years gone by in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: fairness, equity and decency in the tax system.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Oppc;sition referred to the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of pages in the 'Fringe Benefits Tax-a

Speaker: NA
Text: Guide for Employers'. Obviously, there are a lot

Speaker: NA
Text: of different kinds of fringe benefits and the

Speaker: NA
Text: booklet devotes a couple of pages to each one. I

Speaker: NA
Text: would have thought that the fact that there are

Speaker: NA
Text: so many pages was one of the reasons why the

Speaker: NA
Text: former Treasurer should have moved against it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact that a couple of pages are devoted to

Speaker: NA
Text: each fringe benefit is the reason why there are

Speaker: NA
Text: so many pages. Those pages are designed to help

Speaker: NA
Text: people and to tell taxpayers and companies what

Speaker: NA
Text: their obligations are. There is no point in Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position members manufacturing mock indigna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion about some burdens being placed on

Speaker: NA
Text: employers by their having to read these docu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments or their being forced to attend to these

Speaker: NA
Text: matters. We all know that employers have had

Speaker: NA
Text: cheaper labour than they would otherwise have

Speaker: NA
Text: had by using the fringe benefit mechanism. They

Speaker: NA
Text: have been able to engage the service of people

Speaker: NA
Text: without paying higher levels of remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: because they have been able to split between the

Speaker: NA
Text: employer and the employee what would other-

Speaker: NA
Text: wise have been the tax payable. The only people

Speaker: NA
Text: who have had to bear the burden of that are

Speaker: NA
Text: the ordinary men and women-the ordinary tax-

Speaker: NA
Text: payers-of this country who have had to pay for

Speaker: NA
Text: all of the fringe benefits of higher income tax-

Speaker: NA
Text: payers, for whom paying tax was always op-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional under the coalition Government. The

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition Government was never interested in

Speaker: NA
Text: closing tax loopholes; it always left them open

Speaker: NA
Text: like some sort of tax collander for people to fall

Speaker: NA
Text: through. Thus higher income earners have not

Speaker: NA
Text: had to pay their fair share of tax, while every

Speaker: NA
Text: other person has had to pay it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Apparently, the morality of tax law is now to

Speaker: NA
Text: be measured on the basis of how many pages

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government requires business people to read.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the apologia: The reason why we should

Speaker: NA
Text: not move on tax reform is that we ask somebody

Speaker: NA
Text: to read a 100-page booklet about fringe benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: from which he has massively benefited. If that is

Speaker: NA
Text: the standard of coalition morality on tax policy

Speaker: NA
Text: it is no wonder that the coalition is still in

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition. If it keeps to that standard of moral-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity it will stay there.

Speaker: NA
Text: AUSTRALIAN COMMONWEALTH

Speaker: NA
Text: GAMES TEAM

Speaker: Mr STAPLES
Text: Has the attention of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism been

Speaker: NA
Text: drawn to Press reports that the Australian Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Games team is in serious financial

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulty and that Australian athletes may have

Speaker: NA
Text: to miss the Games?

Speaker: Mr JOHN BROWN
Text: I am aware of reports,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly a very florid article on the front

Speaker: NA
Text: page of the Telegraph this morning which is a

Speaker: NA
Text: fairly cheap beat-up. I can assure the House that

Speaker: NA
Text: officers of the Australian Sports Commission have

Speaker: NA
Text: been in touch with the Commonwealth Games

Speaker: NA
Text: Association and are monitoring this matter

Speaker: NA
Text: closely. I think everybody would understand that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth Games Association, given

Speaker: NA
Text: the time scale, has had difficulty in raising the

Speaker: NA
Text: money that it may have required because it is

Speaker: NA
Text: competing with the America's Cup, bicentennial

Speaker: NA
Text: projects and also the 1992 Olympic Games for

Speaker: NA
Text: funding. Thus, it is in a difficult climate for

Speaker: NA
Text: raising funds. However, my advice is that sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port has picked up well. With the campaign it

Speaker: NA
Text: has been running for the sale of $25 bonds

Speaker: NA
Text: through the stock exchanges-with the advan-

Speaker: NA
Text: tage, I might add, of taxation deductibility pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided by the Government, and in particular the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer; it is the first time ever that this

Speaker: NA
Text: efit has been available for either the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Games or the Olympic Games-the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Commonwealth Games team is well

Speaker: NA
Text: on track and there is certainly no question of

Speaker: NA
Text: athletes being left behind.

Speaker: NA
Text: I should also add that the Australian team,

Speaker: NA
Text: which comprises 310 competitors and officials,

Speaker: NA
Text: represents the largest Australian team ever to go

Speaker: NA
Text: to a Commonwealth Games or Olympic Games.

Speaker: NA
Text: Given the extraordinarily successful results we

Speaker: NA
Text: had in Brisbane, we hope to leave Edinburgh

Speaker: NA
Text: with the highest swag of gold medals. I think it

Speaker: NA
Text: is also worth making the point that the taxpay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers of Australia, through the Federal Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, have contributed $900,000 to the funding

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Commonwealth Games team. This is the

Speaker: NA
Text: largest amount ever contributed to such a team;

Speaker: NA
Text: in fact, it was the amount asked of us by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Games Association. We all know

Speaker: NA
Text: that this team will give of its best: I am sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that it will perform in a way that will bring

Speaker: NA
Text: pride to every Australian. I hope that the news-

Speaker: NA
Text: paper article this morning, as florid and as mis-

Speaker: NA
Text: leading as it was, will engender even more

Speaker: NA
Text: support from the commercial and private sector

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia, and in particular from private citi-

Speaker: NA
Text: zens, to see that this team, which promises so

Speaker: NA
Text: much, is at least properly funded.

Speaker: NA
Text: FRINGE BENEFITS TAX

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: I refer the Treasurer to the sit-

Speaker: NA
Text: uation of a wheat farmer who has one employee

Speaker: NA
Text: and whose family lives in rent free accommoda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion on the property. If the value of the employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ee's accommodation is assessed at $60 a week

Speaker: NA
Text: and his use of power, fuel, farm vehicles, et

Speaker: NA
Text: cetera is assessed at a further $60 a week, will

Speaker: NA
Text: the employer's tax liability increase by about

Speaker: NA
Text: $3,000 per year under the fringe benefits tax? In

Speaker: NA
Text: view of the fact that the average wheat farmer

Speaker: NA
Text: is already suffering record losses in income and

Speaker: NA
Text: is paying excessive interest rates on record in-

Speaker: NA
Text: debtedness, is the Treasurer concerned about the

Speaker: NA
Text: consequent increase in unemployment in rural

Speaker: NA
Text: areas and the inability of farmers to continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: employ people?

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: The Government has made

Speaker: NA
Text: the fringe benefits tax arrangements on housing

Speaker: NA
Text: in rural Australia extremely concessionary. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: done so in consultation with the various indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries concerned. It has taken in all cases what

Speaker: NA
Text: could reasonably be believed to be the lowest

Speaker: NA
Text: possible basis of valuation for rental purposes

Speaker: NA
Text: and fringe benefits provided. It is on that basis

Speaker: NA
Text: that we are confident that no liability imposed

Speaker: NA
Text: benon a member of a business providing fringe ben-

Speaker: NA
Text: efits in the accommodation area in this way is

Speaker: NA
Text: unduly harsh. I am not in a position to do the

Speaker: NA
Text: calculations the honourable gentleman requires

Speaker: NA
Text: of me on my feet, except to give him that

Speaker: NA
Text: assurance.

Speaker: NA
Text: COMMONWEALTH TAXATION LAWS:

Speaker: NA
Text: CLAIMS BY QUEENSLAND PREMIER

Speaker: Mr HUMPHREYS
Text: Is the Treasurer aware

Speaker: NA
Text: of claims by the Queensland Premier that he

Speaker: NA
Text: plans to break Commonwealth taxation laws?

Speaker: NA
Text: What is the Government's reaction to these

Speaker: NA
Text: claims?

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: I am aware of the Queens-

Speaker: NA
Text: land Premier's comments. I regard it as a matter

Speaker: NA
Text: of great regret that so senior an Australian pol-

Speaker: NA
Text: itician should be driven to make the remarks he

Speaker: NA
Text: has. It highlights the double standards we have

Speaker: NA
Text: had from the Queensland Premier to find that,

Speaker: NA
Text: in urging people to law and order and to obey

Speaker: NA
Text: the rule of law, the only laws he feels he ought

Speaker: NA
Text: to be obeyed are his laws. I urge honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members to remember his attitude two years ago

Speaker: NA
Text: when the Queensland coal companies tried to

Speaker: NA
Text: reduce the onerous burden of the $200m a year

Speaker: NA
Text: rail freight export taxes and the Premier's reply

Speaker: NA
Text: to them. I remind honourable members of his

Speaker: NA
Text: attitude towards Queensland motorists when hit

Speaker: NA
Text: by increases of up to 400 per cent in compulsory

Speaker: NA
Text: third party insurance. Those motorists were

Speaker: NA
Text: threatened by the Premier, who abused every-

Speaker: NA
Text: body who said that they may not pay the

Speaker: NA
Text: increases.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other thing I found regrettable in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Premier's fulminations this morning was that he

Speaker: NA
Text: did not have the decency to indicate that the

Speaker: NA
Text: earnings of these revenue measures are totally

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue neutral to the Government and are all

Speaker: NA
Text: returned in lower marginal rates of tax. We

Speaker: NA
Text: heard nothing from the Queensland Premier

Speaker: NA
Text: about the reduction in the top marginal tax rate

Speaker: NA
Text: from 60 per cent to 49 per cent. We heard

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing from him about the removal of the

Speaker: NA
Text: double tax on dividends or the provision of the

Speaker: NA
Text: full imputation system for Australian business.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Premier has been fulminating about the cost

Speaker: NA
Text: to business of the fringe benefits tax but has

Speaker: NA
Text: failed to mention the provision of a full impu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation system, the second such system in the

Speaker: NA
Text: world, at a company tax rate of 49 per cent and

Speaker: NA
Text: not 65 per cent, and reductions in the top mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ginal rate from 60 per cent to 49 per cent and,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the other step, 46 per cent and 48 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: to 40 per cent. He did not have the decency to

Speaker: NA
Text: mention that. Of course the reason the Premier

Speaker: NA
Text: is concerned about the consequence of the tax

Speaker: NA
Text: upon the Queensland Public Service is obviously

Speaker: NA
Text: the size and the cost of Public Service fringe

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits in Queensland which State taxpayers are

Speaker: NA
Text: being asked to bear. For instance, his own air-

Speaker: NA
Text: craft, which costs $8m a year--

Speaker: Mr GRIFFITHS
Text: How much?

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: It costs $8m, but does not

Speaker: NA
Text: operate under rules like those applying to Royal

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Air Force aircraft. Secondly, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: known that there is a secret Public Service Board

Speaker: NA
Text: report circulating in Brisbane detailing the mas-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive abuse of fringe benefits in the Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Service. Three-quarters of government ve-

Speaker: NA
Text: hicles in Brisbane are used for no more than

Speaker: NA
Text: transporting public servants to home and back,

Speaker: NA
Text: and of course the recent Australian Bureau of

Speaker: NA
Text: Statistics numbers emphasise the size of his pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lic sector in Queensland, which is running a

Speaker: NA
Text: 1985-86 borrowing requirement of $1.615 billion.

Speaker: NA
Text: When extrapolated to all of Australia, that is

Speaker: NA
Text: the equivalent of a Commonwealth borrowing

Speaker: NA
Text: requirement of a massive $10 billion-which of

Speaker: NA
Text: course is twice what the Commonwealth bor-

Speaker: NA
Text: rows. So that gives us some indication of the

Speaker: NA
Text: size of the public sector in Queensland. Yet this

Speaker: NA
Text: is from a Premier who is always urging everyone

Speaker: NA
Text: else to reduce the size of government. He has

Speaker: NA
Text: this whopping public sector deficit and borrow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing requirement up there and has abused taxpay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers' funds by providing fringe benefits, on which

Speaker: NA
Text: he now has to pay the Commonwealth tax. To

Speaker: NA
Text: find that he is going about the place urging

Speaker: NA
Text: people to break the law when he has for years

Speaker: NA
Text: urged everyone else to accept the rule of law,

Speaker: NA
Text: reserving to himself the right to abuse anyone

Speaker: NA
Text: who dares not pay Queensland taxes, all rings

Speaker: NA
Text: rather hollow. Perhaps this is best summed up

Speaker: NA
Text: by today's leader in the Brisbane Courier-Mail,

Speaker: NA
Text: headed 'Facing the economic Truth', which, in

Speaker: NA
Text: speaking about the Queensland economy, says:

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, there are lies, damned lies and statistics.

Speaker: NA
Text: But the Liberal Party in Queensland has produced a set

Speaker: NA
Text: of economic indicators which suggest, rather forcibly,

Speaker: NA
Text: that the economy is in crisis. Queensland has the highest

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment rate in mainland Australia and the low-

Speaker: NA
Text: est number of tertiary education students. As well, the

Speaker: NA
Text: State has had no increase in full-time employment, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: the only State where juvenile unemployment has in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased, the only State which has experienced a per-

Speaker: NA
Text: centage decrease in new housing starts and the lowest

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in new vehicle registrations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other indicators are equally gloomy: Queensland has

Speaker: NA
Text: experienced the greatest percentage increase in bank-

Speaker: NA
Text: ruptcies, the second worst decrease i!1 private capital

Speaker: NA
Text: investment and the greatest number of days lost through

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial disputes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, the Premier managed to produce his own

Speaker: NA
Text: set of statistics: Queensland has the highest growth rate

Speaker: NA
Text: and the lowest State taxes. More importantly, however,

Speaker: NA
Text: he accused the Liberals of siding with Labor 'to knock

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland'. This is unfortunate, because it demon-

Speaker: NA
Text: strates a reluctance on the part of both the Premier and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Queensland Government to accept the facts before

Speaker: NA
Text: their eyes.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Courier-Mail has been known to be fairly

Speaker: NA
Text: supportive of the Premier in the past. This is a

Speaker: NA
Text: damning indictment of his administration and,

Speaker: NA
Text: coming as it does on the heels of his urging of

Speaker: NA
Text: well people to break the laws of the land, the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth laws, and saying that his own Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment will not pay the tax on the fringe

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits handed out willy-nilly by him and his

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers to their employees, gives the Queens-

Speaker: NA
Text: land public some indication of the kind of lead-

Speaker: NA
Text: ership and the morality of the leadership it is

Speaker: NA
Text: currently getting from the Queensland Premier.

Speaker: Mr SHARP
Text: Does the Minister for Health

Speaker: NA
Text: still hold the belief that he has expressed repeatFebruary.

Speaker: NA
Text: edly over a number of years that it is wrong for

Speaker: NA
Text: marihuana to be outlawed and that people should

Speaker: NA
Text: be allowed to grow marihuana in their own back

Speaker: NA
Text: yards? If the Minister believes in the legalising

Speaker: NA
Text: of marihuana, how does he accommodate this

Speaker: NA
Text: with his position as the Government's Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: in charge of the drug offensive? Does he realise

Speaker: NA
Text: that by allowing people to grow cannabis plants

Speaker: NA
Text: in their own back yards he must be advocating

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislation of such hard drugs as hash and

Speaker: NA
Text: hashish oil which, along with marihuana, are

Speaker: NA
Text: products of the cannabis plant?

Speaker: Dr BLEWETT
Text: In the past I have expressed

Speaker: NA
Text: views about the controversial issue of the decri-

Speaker: NA
Text: minalisation of marihuana. However, as Health

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister of this country and as a member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Cabinet, I am bound to take into consideration

Speaker: NA
Text: the long term effects of marihuana on health.

Speaker: NA
Text: Quite clearly, in the material that has been pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared under my authority in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: national campaign against drug abuse, which the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member has used every opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: to denigrate, we have tried to provide people

Speaker: NA
Text: with factual, realistic information about drugs.

Speaker: NA
Text: We believe that, provided the correct informa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is given throughout the campaign, that in-

Speaker: NA
Text: formation wiII be respected. In the material that

Speaker: NA
Text: has been put out in relation to cannabis, we

Speaker: NA
Text: have pointed out the distinction between canna-

Speaker: NA
Text: bis and some of the hard drugs, but at the same

Speaker: NA
Text: time we have recognised some of the long term

Speaker: NA
Text: effects on people's health of the use of cannabis.

Speaker: NA
Text: HOUSING: OPPOSITION POLICY

Speaker: Mr LEE
Text: My question is addressed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Housing and Construction. What

Speaker: NA
Text: effect would the implementation of the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion's policy on housing and construction, as

Speaker: NA
Text: announced yesterday, have on the housing indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try and on first home buyers?

Speaker: Mr WEST
Text: When the Opposition policy doc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ument came into my hands for the first time last

Speaker: NA
Text: night, I took some convincing that it was a

Speaker: NA
Text: genuine document. The document is so inept and

Speaker: NA
Text: shoddy in its presentation and so shallow in its

Speaker: NA
Text: content that it is hard to believe that a major

Speaker: NA
Text: political party in this country could actually put

Speaker: NA
Text: out such a poor and amateurish presentation

Speaker: NA
Text: with such shallow content. It has absolutely no

Speaker: NA
Text: costing and no figures whatsoever. One can look

Speaker: NA
Text: through the entire length of the document and

Speaker: NA
Text: nowhere is there to be found any consideration

Speaker: NA
Text: of the financial effects of the changes to policy

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Opposition suggests. It has all the hall-

Speaker: NA
Text: DRUGS marks of being put out in great panic. Each page

Speaker: NA
Text: is headed 'Draft Copy No.9' and dated 17

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the policy document that was

Speaker: NA
Text: put around the Press Gallery last night.

Speaker: NA
Text: As we now have the benefit of being able to

Speaker: NA
Text: peruse Draft Copy No.9, dated 17 February,

Speaker: NA
Text: the obvious question that any interested observer

Speaker: NA
Text: would have to ask is: What have the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: and the torpid shadow Minister for Housing and

Speaker: NA
Text: Construction been doing since 17 February? It

Speaker: NA
Text: is pretty obvious that they believe that nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: much has happened in the area of housing since

Speaker: NA
Text: 17 February. There I was, sitting in my office,

Speaker: NA
Text: waiting for the phantom front bench leaker to

Speaker: NA
Text: strike again, when suddenly my Press officer

Speaker: NA
Text: rushed in and said: 'Minister, have a look at this

Speaker: NA
Text: dynamic document. We have an Opposition pol-

Speaker: NA
Text: icy document which is Draft Copy No. 9 and

Speaker: NA
Text: dated 17 February. It has just been released'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us have a look at the document and see

Speaker: NA
Text: what it says. The first thing we see--

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr WEST
Text: As I have said, it has all the

Speaker: NA
Text: hallmarks of being pushed out in panic. Honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members opposite really have some prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lems with leaks. By George, they have some

Speaker: NA
Text: problems with leaks. I hope that they can hunt

Speaker: NA
Text: down the culprit. Let us look at what the docu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment proposes. The first thing the document sets

Speaker: NA
Text: out to do is to abolish the first home owners

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme. Let me explain what the first home

Speaker: NA
Text: owners scheme has achieved. Because it makes

Speaker: NA
Text: available a substantial lump sum and a continu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing interest rate subsidy, that scheme has made

Speaker: NA
Text: it possible for 200,000 low and middle income

Speaker: NA
Text: earners to aspire to their own homes in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. We have paid out-and have a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitment to payout over the next five years-

Speaker: NA
Text: $900m already. Why, even in the electorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Deakin an amount

Speaker: NA
Text: of $2.6m has been committed. In the electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: of Bennelong an amount of $1.5m has been paid

Speaker: NA
Text: out, and-wait for it-we have paid out $6m in

Speaker: NA
Text: the electorate of New England. What has the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Party got to say about this attack on

Speaker: NA
Text: the low income aspirants to a home?

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not want to see Australia's working class

Speaker: NA
Text: home aspirants disadvantaged because of the ab-

Speaker: NA
Text: olition of the first home owners scheme. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, what do the right honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: New England and other members of the Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional Party have to say about the effect of this

Speaker: NA
Text: on the rural poor in their own electorates when,

Speaker: NA
Text: already, an amount of $6m has been allocated

Speaker: NA
Text: to low and middle income earners in the New

Speaker: NA
Text: England electorate as a result of this scheme?

Speaker: NA
Text: Do members of the National Party simply want

Speaker: NA
Text: to abolish the first home owners scheme?

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us look at what the policy document

Speaker: NA
Text: proposes in addition to this sabotage. It also

Speaker: NA
Text: out to eliminate the tied grants under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. Let

Speaker: NA
Text: us look at what the tied grants are. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: five tied grants. The first is the mortgage and

Speaker: NA
Text: rent relief scheme which was first implemented

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Fraser Government back in 1982 during

Speaker: NA
Text: its period of high interest rates. The mortgage

Speaker: NA
Text: and rent relief scheme does what its name im-

Speaker: NA
Text: plies and extends assistance to those who are in

Speaker: NA
Text: trouble in paying out their mortgage and meeting

Speaker: NA
Text: their rent requirement. The second tied program

Speaker: NA
Text: is the crisis accommodation program. Honoura-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble members opposite are going to abolish that

Speaker: NA
Text: program. This program makes short term accom-

Speaker: NA
Text: modation available to the poor and homeless.

Speaker: NA
Text: The third program the Opposition would set out

Speaker: NA
Text: to abolish is the local government and commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity housing program. Let us see what the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Association of Local Government

Speaker: NA
Text: Organisations and all the local government insti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tutions around Australia will have to say about

Speaker: NA
Text: this. Let us see what all the community housing

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations will have to say. The second last

Speaker: NA
Text: program which the Opposition proposes to abol-

Speaker: NA
Text: ish is the Aboriginal rental program. This is the

Speaker: NA
Text: special Aboriginal program for which we have

Speaker: NA
Text: increased funding by 60 per cent since we

Speaker: NA
Text: achieved office.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: Wind up.

Speaker: Mr WEST
Text: The Opposition proposes to

Speaker: NA
Text: abolish the Aboriginal rental program. The fifth

Speaker: NA
Text: program that Opposition members propose to

Speaker: NA
Text: abolish when they abolish the tied grants is the

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners rental program. The Opposition ought

Speaker: NA
Text: to be thoroughly ashamed that it could produce

Speaker: NA
Text: such a vicious document.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: On a point of order, Madam

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker: I draw your attention to a practice that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister, when in opposition, sought to can-

Speaker: NA
Text: vass frequently during the course of Questions

Speaker: NA
Text: without Notice, and that is, if it is necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: a Minister to make a statement time will be

Speaker: NA
Text: provided in the Parliament for that statement to

Speaker: NA
Text: be debated. Questions without Notice are not

Speaker: NA
Text: for the purpose of giving a protracted explana-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of this order. I suggest that it is about time

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Minister drew his answer to a close.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-Order! There is no point

Speaker: NA
Text: of order. I have pointed out to the House re-

Speaker: NA
Text: peatedly that, if honourable members wish to

Speaker: NA
Text: limit the time that a Minister takes to answer a

Speaker: NA
Text: question, they may do so through the House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives Standing Committee on Proce-

Speaker: NA
Text: dure. The Chair has no authority to limit the

Speaker: NA
Text: sets time. The Chair can ask only that the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: be relevant.

Speaker: Mr WEST
Text: The Opposition ought to be

Speaker: NA
Text: ashamed that it has kept its supporters waiting

Speaker: NA
Text: for 18 months and then has come out with a

Speaker: NA
Text: policy that is so poor in its presentation and so

Speaker: NA
Text: shallow in its content. The Opposition requires

Speaker: NA
Text: a really good shakeup to get rid of the current

Speaker: NA
Text: batch of dullards and loafers who make up its

Speaker: NA
Text: front bench, which can produce such an atro-

Speaker: NA
Text: cious, foul and despicable document that it hopes

Speaker: NA
Text: to pass off as a housing policy document.

Speaker: NA
Text: MAINTENANCE PAYMENTS

Speaker: Mr MACKELLAR
Text: I ask the Minister for So-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial Security. Does the Government intend to

Speaker: NA
Text: deduct at source court-directed maintenance

Speaker: NA
Text: payments from the incomes of defaulting non-

Speaker: NA
Text: custodial parents?

Speaker: Mr HOWE
Text: I thank the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for his question because it is an important issue

Speaker: NA
Text: for this Parliament and is certainly relevant, as

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Finance said yesterday, to the

Speaker: NA
Text: care of children of sole parents. Every honoura-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble member will know that the children of pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion beneficiary families, particularly the children

Speaker: NA
Text: of sole parent families, are the poorest children

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Australian community today. One of the

Speaker: NA
Text: disturbing things that have occurred in the dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussion that has taken place around Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: on this issue, particularly on the part-as Sena-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor Walsh said yesterday-of the National Party

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia rednecks, has been the suggestion

Speaker: NA
Text: that somehow the responsibility for this poverty

Speaker: NA
Text: lies very much with the 90 per cent of support-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing parents who are women, with little or no

Speaker: NA
Text: attention being given to the fact that liable par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ents, the vast majority of whom clearly are men,

Speaker: NA
Text: are not taking the responsibility that they ought

Speaker: NA
Text: to take to maintain at a reasonable level the

Speaker: NA
Text: children for whom they have responsibility.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has had this matter under

Speaker: NA
Text: for consideration for a period and hopes to resolve

Speaker: NA
Text: its approach to it in the lead-up to this year's

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget. We are looking at a number of alterna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives, including the national maintenance collec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion agency approach which was the subject of

Speaker: NA
Text: a Government report. We have been looking

Speaker: NA
Text: also at the New Zealand liable parents contri-

Speaker: NA
Text: bution scheme. Last week I was in New Zealand

Speaker: NA
Text: and had discussions with the Minister for Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Welfare and had the opportunity to talk to

Speaker: NA
Text: people in New Zealand about that scheme. We

Speaker: NA
Text: are looking also at some other alternatives which

Speaker: NA
Text: would include that which was implied in the

Speaker: NA
