Text: question; that is, the withdrawal of income at

Speaker: NA
Text: source. Whatever is the outcome of these delib-

Speaker: NA
Text: erations, we have a situation in which there is

Speaker: NA
Text: great poverty. We believe that people ought to

Speaker: NA
Text: be brought to account on the question of indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: vidual responsibility and that the Federal Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment ought to take the lead in this matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: I cannot say any more than that, except that

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe this is a very important issue. I know

Speaker: NA
Text: that there have been some very interesting de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bates in the Senate. I hope that when the Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment is able to bring back a report to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House we will be able to get very broad support,

Speaker: NA
Text: in particular from those outspoken members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the National Party who have suggested that there

Speaker: NA
Text: are matters of individual responsibility in this

Speaker: NA
Text: area. I hope also that all members of parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: will consider the issues when the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has determined its position, because this matter

Speaker: NA
Text: is extremely important to the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: community.

Speaker: NA
Text: SOLOMON ISLANDS

Speaker: Mr MILDREN
Text: I direct the attention of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister representing the Acting Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Foreign Affairs to the appalling loss of life and

Speaker: NA
Text: destruction of property in the Solomon Islands

Speaker: NA
Text: in the wake of Cyclone Namu. Will the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: indicate the most recent information on the sit-

Speaker: NA
Text: uation in the Solomon Islands? Will he also

Speaker: NA
Text: indicate what action the Australian Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has taken to provide emergency relief measures

Speaker: NA
Text: in the devastated areas and what information he

Speaker: NA
Text: has regarding the safety of Australians in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Solomon Islands? Finally, will he indicate

Speaker: NA
Text: whether the Government would be prepared to

Speaker: NA
Text: support community groups should they organise

Speaker: NA
Text: disaster relief appeals for the victims of Cyclone

Speaker: NA
Text: Namu?

Speaker: Mr BARRY JONES
Text: Following an improve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in the weather on 21 May, the Solomon

Speaker: NA
Text: Islands Government began assessing the damage.

Speaker: NA
Text: A further assessment of the situation will take

Speaker: NA
Text: some time. To date, 71 deaths have been re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ported but there is as yet no official confirma-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. The latest information available indicates

Speaker: NA
Text: that the magnitude of devastation is far greater

Speaker: NA
Text: than originally estimated and that at least 90,000

Speaker: NA
Text: people are homeless. The Prime Minister, in his

Speaker: NA
Text: message to the Solomon Islands Prime Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: has given an assurance that Australia will con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinue to do all that it can to assist in this hour

Speaker: NA
Text: of crisis. At the request of the Solomon Islands

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, Australia is providing relief assist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance in the form of helicopters with winches,

Speaker: NA
Text: shelter materials, water containers, first-aid ma-

Speaker: NA
Text: terial, food-particularly rice-a generator and

Speaker: NA
Text: other electrical equipment, blankets and cooking

Speaker: NA
Text: utensils. Three Australian Hercules transport

Speaker: NA
Text: flights have already arrived in Honiara from

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and a fourth and fifth Hercules are on

Speaker: NA
Text: their way to Honiara with additional supplies.

Speaker: NA
Text: An Australian airport engineer has been airlifted

Speaker: NA
Text: to Honiara to assist in assessing airport condi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. A Caribou aircraft left Townsville for

Speaker: NA
Text: Honiara this morning to assist in the distribution

Speaker: NA
Text: of supplies in the outer islands.

Speaker: NA
Text: Early next week additional Royal Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Air Force aircraft will be required, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: defence forces will respond as required. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Royal Australian Navy is preparing to send two

Speaker: NA
Text: vessels-HMAS Flinders, which we hope will

Speaker: NA
Text: arrive shortly after the weekend, and HMAS

Speaker: NA
Text: Stalwart, which will arrive early next week-

Speaker: NA
Text: with a large volume of supplies. The emergency

Speaker: NA
Text: relief assistance to the Solomon Islands is co-

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinated by the Australian Development Assist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance Bureau in collaboration with the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Natural Disasters Organisation. They are in con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stant touch with the Australian High Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioner in Honiara. Until now, all requests of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Government by the Solomon Islands

Speaker: NA
Text: Government have been met, and the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government will respond as required. The High

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner advises that all Australians in

Speaker: NA
Text: Honiara are safe but contact with outer islands

Speaker: NA
Text: is still difficult. I will seek what advice I can

Speaker: NA
Text: about the relationship of private donor organi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sations but, naturally, this is a community re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsibility. It cannot just be a government

Speaker: NA
Text: matter. I am sure that this is something which

Speaker: NA
Text: has the full support of all parties in the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: PETITIONS

Speaker: NA
Text: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for

Speaker: NA
Text: presentation as follows and copies will be re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred to the appropriate Ministers:

Speaker: NA
Text: International Year for Repairing the Earth

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This

Speaker: NA
Text: petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully

Speaker: NA
Text: points out:

Speaker: NA
Text: That, for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ative needs to be established which will work towards

Speaker: NA
Text: mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic

Speaker: NA
Text: well-being for all and full employment. This Initiative

Speaker: NA
Text: will help to ensure a sustainable society conserving

Speaker: NA
Text: natural resources, and revitalising soils essential for

Speaker: NA
Text: growing a plentiful and healthy food supply and tree

Speaker: NA
Text: cover. By achieving these objectives, Australia can set

Speaker: NA
Text: an example for the rest of the world to follow.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable House will:

Speaker: NA
Text: I. Propose to the United Nations General Assembly

Speaker: NA
Text: that 1989 be declared International Year for Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: pairing the Earth.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. Implement action programs leading up to 1989

Speaker: NA
Text: which will include:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) Actively supporting the International Year of

Speaker: NA
Text: Peace in 1986 by reducing our military ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: penditure by at least 10% and allocating this

Speaker: NA
Text: to fund environmental repair programs;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) Implementing national recycling programs to

Speaker: NA
Text: reuse water, and to compost into hygienic

Speaker: NA
Text: humus all presently wasted sewage-sludge and

Speaker: NA
Text: organic garbage mixed with fine ground pow-

Speaker: NA
Text: der from mineral-rich gravels and rocks, to

Speaker: NA
Text: use as a natural fertiliser in revitalising im-

Speaker: NA
Text: poverished soils;

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) Developing national employment programs to

Speaker: NA
Text: give priority to irrigation systems and the

Speaker: NA
Text: planting and growing of forests, food-produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing trees and other crops to assist

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever

Speaker: NA
Text: pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Dubois, Dr Harry Edwards, Ms Mc-

Speaker: NA
Text: Hugh, Mr Staples, Mr Webster and Mr Wilson.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petitions received.

Speaker: NA
Text: International Year for Repairing the Earth

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This

Speaker: NA
Text: petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully

Speaker: NA
Text: points out:

Speaker: NA
Text: That, for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ative needs to be established which will work towards

Speaker: NA
Text: mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic

Speaker: NA
Text: well-being for all, fulfilling employment, a sustainable

Speaker: NA
Text: society conserving natural resources and revitalising soils

Speaker: NA
Text: essential for growing a plentiful and healthy food supply

Speaker: NA
Text: and tree cover. By achieving these objectives, Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: can set an example for the rest of the world to follow.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable House will:

Speaker: NA
Text: I. Create an Australian Ministry for Peace specifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cally devoted to peace-building and the non-vio-

Speaker: NA
Text: lent resolution of conflict;

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. Convene a national Summit for Survival to discuss

Speaker: NA
Text: the issues of world disarmament, security and na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional and international co-operation;

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. Support the United Nations World Disarmament

Speaker: NA
Text: Campaign by allocating the equivalent of at least

Speaker: NA
Text: 10% of our military expenditure to fund peace

Speaker: NA
Text: activities;

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. Actively assist the International Year of Peace in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1986 by initiating programs for peace education,

Speaker: NA
Text: self help development and environmental repair;

Speaker: NA
Text: 5. Develop national employment programs to give

Speaker: NA
Text: priority to the planting and growing of forests,

Speaker: NA
Text: food-producing trees and other crops to assist the

Speaker: NA
Text: greening of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: 6. Implement national recycling programs to reuse

Speaker: NA
Text: water and to compost all presently wasted domes-

Speaker: NA
Text: tic sewage-sludge and organic garbage with min-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral-rich gravel dust, a by-product from rock

Speaker: NA
Text: quarries and mines, into hygienic humus, a natural

Speaker: NA
Text: fertiliser, for use in revitalising impoverished soils.

Speaker: NA
Text: 7. Propose to the United Nations General Assembly

Speaker: NA
Text: that 1989 be declared International Year for Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: pairing the Earth.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever

Speaker: NA
Text: pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Wilson.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Pensions

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

Speaker: NA
Text: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respect-

Speaker: NA
Text: fully showeth that your petitioners are gravely con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned at the failure of the Government to honour its

Speaker: NA
Text: the greening election promises to pensioners.

Speaker: NA
Text: In particular those promises relate to the following

Speaker: NA
Text: commitments:

Speaker: NA
Text: I. That within three years of its election to office, a

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawke Labor Government would raise the level

Speaker: NA
Text: of the standard pension to 25% of average weekly

Speaker: NA
Text: earnings;

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. That the lag time between the announcement of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Consumer Price Index figures and the subse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quent adjustment of pensions would be reduced to

Speaker: NA
Text: one month, and

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. That the disproportionate tax burden borne by

Speaker: NA
Text: low income earners would be lifted.

Speaker: NA
Text: None of these promises has been honoured to date.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners are extremely angry at the failure of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government to live up to its commitments and, as

Speaker: NA
Text: in duty bound, will ever pray that these serious omis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions will be given the attention they deserve.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Katter, Mr Mountford, Mr Nehl, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Ian Robinson, Mr Snow and Mr Webster.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petitions received.

Speaker: NA
Text: International Year for Repairing the Earth

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This

Speaker: NA
Text: petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully

Speaker: NA
Text: points out:

Speaker: NA
Text: That deterioration of the total global environment is

Speaker: NA
Text: continuing at an increasing rate; that important environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental resources vital to human livelihood such as trees,

Speaker: NA
Text: soil and water are decreasing at an alarming rate; that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a need for educating all people to assume a

Speaker: NA
Text: greater responsibility for the conservation, sustainable

Speaker: NA
Text: use and maintenance of vital resources; that dynamic

Speaker: NA
Text: a Government report. We have been looking

Speaker: NA
Text: also at the New Zealand liable parents contri-

Speaker: NA
Text: bution scheme. Last week I was in New Zealand

Speaker: NA
Text: and had discussions with the Minister for Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Welfare and had the opportunity to talk to

Speaker: NA
Text: people in New Zealand about that scheme. We

Speaker: NA
Text: are looking also at some other alternatives which

Speaker: NA
Text: would include that which was implied in the

Speaker: NA
Text: question; that is, the withdrawal of income at

Speaker: NA
Text: source. Whatever is the outcome of these delib-

Speaker: NA
Text: erations, we have a situation in which there is

Speaker: NA
Text: great poverty. We believe that people ought to

Speaker: NA
Text: be brought to account on the question of indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: vidual responsibility and that the Federal Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment ought to take the lead in this matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: I cannot say any more than that, except that

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe this is a very important issue. I know

Speaker: NA
Text: that there have been some very interesting de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bates in the Senate. I hope that when the Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment is able to bring back a report to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House we will be able to get very broad support,

Speaker: NA
Text: in particular from those outspoken members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the National Party who have suggested that there

Speaker: NA
Text: are matters of individual responsibility in this

Speaker: NA
Text: area. I hope also that all members of parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: will consider the issues when the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has determined its position, because this matter

Speaker: NA
Text: is extremely important to the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: community.

Text: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for

Speaker: NA
Text: presentation as follows and copies will be re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred to the appropriate Ministers:

Speaker: NA
Text: International Year for Repairing the Earth

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This

Speaker: NA
Text: petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully

Speaker: NA
Text: points out:

Speaker: NA
Text: That, for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ative needs to be established which will work towards

Speaker: NA
Text: mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic

Speaker: NA
Text: well-being for all and full employment. This Initiative

Speaker: NA
Text: Ensuring no additional cut-backs will be made to

Speaker: NA
Text: the portfolio of Veterans' Affairs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Reviewing the previous cut-backs in such areas as

Speaker: NA
Text: the travel allowances, dental scheme and repatriation

Speaker: NA
Text: pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: Proceeding with abolishing more stringent condi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions applying to the granting of the TPI pension.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Blunt and Mr Reith.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petitions received.

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The

Speaker: NA
Text: petition of the undersigned shows:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Hawke Government should;

Speaker: NA
Text: pass on the full benefit of lower international oil

Speaker: NA
Text: prices on I March 1986;

Speaker: NA
Text: not increase or ex tend fuel taxes; and

Speaker: NA
Text: maintain its tax cut commitments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment honour its commitment to the Import Parity

Speaker: NA
Text: Pricing policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever

Speaker: NA
Text: pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Braithwaite and Mr Fife.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petitions received.

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The

Speaker: NA
Text: petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: That many Australian wage and salary earners and

Speaker: NA
Text: self-employed persons do not enjoy secure retirement

Speaker: NA
Text: incomes provided by superannuation; and

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Government issued in December 1985

Speaker: NA
Text: Guidelines for the implementation of the proposed pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ductivity decision by the Conciliation and Arbitration

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission and draft Operational Standards for Super-

Speaker: NA
Text: annuation schemes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government:

Speaker: NA
Text: I. Guarantees to every employee the right and free-

Speaker: NA
Text: dom to select the superannuation scheme of his/

Speaker: NA
Text: her choice.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. Protects the individual exercising that freedom of

Speaker: NA
Text: choice from any coercion, influence or other pres-

Speaker: NA
Text: sure which may be applied by any employer, as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sociation or trade union.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. Will recognise only those schemes which provide

Speaker: NA
Text: genuine superannuation and reject those schemes

Speaker: NA
Text: which do not provide for-

Speaker: NA
Text: preservation of benefits to retirement

Speaker: NA
Text: vesting of employer contributions on a reasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: sliding scale

Speaker: NA
Text: equal employer and employee Trusteeship control

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure security of investments.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Goodluck and Mr Miles.

Text: Petitions received.

Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

Speaker: NA
Text: This petition of citizens of Australia shows that-

Speaker: NA
Text: Approximately 100,000 Australians live on the verge

Speaker: NA
Text: Fuel Prices of homelessness, dependent on Government resources

Speaker: NA
Text: to survive, or sleep out of doors or in refuges.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over 700,000 households, or in excess of 2 million

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians, are living below the poverty line after

Speaker: NA
Text: paying their rent or mortgage costs.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition, there are thousands of households with

Speaker: NA
Text: special needs, such as the disabled, who are not well

Speaker: NA
Text: catered for in the private sector but who nevertheless

Speaker: NA
Text: require suitable housing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Waiting lists for public housing have almost doubled

Speaker: NA
Text: in the past five years to 146,000 by June 1985. The

Speaker: NA
Text: list is expected to grow to some 250,000 by 1990.

Speaker: NA
Text: We therefore ask that the Australian Government, as

Speaker: NA
Text: a highest priority

Speaker: NA
Text: undertake a campaign to bring the issue of poverty

Speaker: NA
Text: and, in particular, housing-related poverty, to the

Speaker: NA
Text: attention of the Australian public

Speaker: NA
Text: increase expenditure on public housing through the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth State Housing Agreement, by at least

Speaker: NA
Text: 15% annually in real terms

Speaker: NA
Text: Superannuation increase rent relief payments for those on low in-

Speaker: NA
Text: comes in the private rental market

Speaker: NA
Text: use its influence with State and Territory govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments to encourage them to increase their expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: on public housing.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Jenkins and Mr Staples.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petitions received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nuclear Disarmament

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the

Speaker: NA
Text: undersigned citizens of Australia shows that

Speaker: NA
Text: in this International Year of Peace, 1986, the world

Speaker: NA
Text: needs a Nuclear Test Moratorium by the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States, the Soviet Union, France and other nuclear-

Speaker: NA
Text: testing powers

Speaker: NA
Text: that such a moratorium would create a favourable

Speaker: NA
Text: climate and basis for the negotiation of a Comprehen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty

Speaker: NA
Text: that such a Moratorium and Comprehensive Nu-

Speaker: NA
Text: clear Test Ban Treaty would

Speaker: NA
Text: be the first vital step to nuclear disarmament

Speaker: NA
Text: impede the development of new nuclear weapons

Speaker: NA
Text: decrease the reliance upon an unstable nuclear strategy

Speaker: NA
Text: inhibit the spread of nuclear weapons.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore ask that the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government be urged to

Speaker: NA
Text: I. Use its influence with the United States Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to encourage it to join the moratorium on

Speaker: NA
Text: nuclear testing begun by the Soviet Union on 6

Speaker: NA
Text: August 1985.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. Use its influence in all forums to encourage other

Speaker: NA
Text: nuclear nations to join the

Speaker: NA
Text: Moratorium.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. Use its influence in all forums to encourage non-

Speaker: NA
Text: nuclear nations to demand the establishment of a

Speaker: NA
Text: Nuclear Test Moratorium and Comprehensive Nu-

Speaker: NA
Text: clear Test Ban Treaty.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Jenkins and Mr Staples.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petitions received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nuclear Free Zones

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

Speaker: NA
Text: The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows-

Speaker: NA
Text: That the people of New Zealand and the New Zea-

Speaker: NA
Text: land Government have given an example to the world

Speaker: NA
Text: in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific,

Speaker: NA
Text: and such decision being endorsed by the people at a

Speaker: NA
Text: general election.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government support the principled stand taken by the

Speaker: NA
Text: New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any

Speaker: NA
Text: efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or

Speaker: NA
Text: other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their

Speaker: NA
Text: stand on nuclear vessels.

Speaker: NA
Text: We further urge the Australian Government to ur-

Speaker: NA
Text: gently implement its policy to promote the development

Speaker: NA
Text: of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian

Speaker: NA
Text: and Pacific Oceans.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Kent and Mr Staples.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petitions received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Port Arthur Conservation and Development

Speaker: NA
Text: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives Parliament House, Canberra A.C.T.

Speaker: NA
Text: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia respectfully showeth: The future of work at

Speaker: NA
Text: Port Arthur and Tasman Peninsula to conserve historic

Speaker: NA
Text: sites and present them to the public is under grave

Speaker: NA
Text: threat due to the proposed termination of the Port

Speaker: NA
Text: Arthur Conservation and Development Project on June

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Fed-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral Government in acknowledgement of the national

Speaker: NA
Text: significance of the historic remains on Tasman Penin-

Speaker: NA
Text: sula, provide appropriate financial support for the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinuation of the Port Arthur Conservation and

Speaker: NA
Text: Development Project in cooperation with the Tasman-

Speaker: NA
Text: ian State.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Burr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Bill of Rights Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives. The petition of the under-

Speaker: NA
Text: signed respectfully showeth that the Bill of Rights is not

Speaker: NA
Text: supported by the people of Australia, and calls on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Nuclear Test Government to:

Speaker: NA
Text: Delay proclamation of the Bill until all matters of

Speaker: NA
Text: contention are settled by national referenda, and that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (I) Matters of States rights, property rights, rights

Speaker: NA
Text: of the newborn, the right not to belong to unions,

Speaker: NA
Text: among other issues, have not been submitted to

Speaker: NA
Text: the people of Australia to decide, and that;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) No Australian Bill of Rights should depend on

Speaker: NA
Text: any foreign convention for its basis in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: law.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever

Speaker: NA
Text: pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Cadman.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Television Standards and Screening Hours

Speaker: NA
Text: The Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives, of the Parliament of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: assembled:

Speaker: NA
Text: We, the undersigned, plead that Parliament becomes

Speaker: NA
Text: aware that the Public has no legal right to influence the

Speaker: NA
Text: setting of Standards for Television Programming, that

Speaker: NA
Text: we deplore the new Standards which came into force

Speaker: NA
Text: on I February, and that we call on Parliament to amend

Speaker: NA
Text: the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942, section 16 (2),

Speaker: NA
Text: so that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, when de-

Speaker: NA
Text: termining Television Standards, and screening hours,

Speaker: NA
Text: shall consult with the Australian people:

Speaker: NA
Text: because at present the Tribunal is compelled by

Speaker: NA
Text: law to consult only with television stations on these

Speaker: NA
Text: matters,

Speaker: NA
Text: because the new Standards are a result of such

Speaker: NA
Text: consultation, and have already been implemented

Speaker: NA
Text: without public discussion,

Speaker: NA
Text: Project because the new Standards are ambiguous, and

Speaker: NA
Text: without definition,

Speaker: NA
Text: because the new Standards are composed of modi-

Speaker: NA
Text: fying terms which circumvent the proscriptions,

Speaker: NA
Text: because the media is only motivated by aspirations

Speaker: NA
Text: of pecuniary superiority,

Speaker: NA
Text: because, in contrast, the public is only motivated

Speaker: NA
Text: by their wish to exercise pastoral care over the nur-

Speaker: NA
Text: turing home environment of their children,

Speaker: NA
Text: because we believe that the Standards wrongly as-

Speaker: NA
Text: cribe extreme importance to 'the storyline' of a film

Speaker: NA
Text: screened,

Speaker: NA
Text: because we believe that the Standards wrongly as-

Speaker: NA
Text: cribe total unimportance to the effects of viewing,

Speaker: NA
Text: especially violent films, on the young, the impression-

Speaker: NA
Text: able, the immature, the unstable, or the socially

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantaged,

Speaker: NA
Text: because we refuse to accept the media-imposed

Speaker: NA
Text: assessment of community standards,

Speaker: NA
Text: and because we wish to impart our demand to be

Speaker: NA
Text: consulted, our demand to have legal status in deci-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion-making, and the right to counsel those whose

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions so deeply affect our homes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will

Speaker: NA
Text: give this matter your earnest attention.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Ms Fatin.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The

Speaker: NA
Text: humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: respectfully showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: That there has been an alarming increase in crimes

Speaker: NA
Text: of violence in Australia causing fear and distress to the

Speaker: NA
Text: elderly, the weak and the defenceless in our society.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the death

Speaker: NA
Text: penalty be introduced in cases where murder can be

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly proved beyond shadow of doubt.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever

Speaker: NA
Text: pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Goodluck.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Chernobyl Nuclear Disaster

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The

Speaker: NA
Text: petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: That after the nuclear disaster which occurred at

Speaker: NA
Text: Chernobyl, in the Soviet Union, on 26 April 1986,

Speaker: NA
Text: Poland, a neighbouring country, was the most affected

Speaker: NA
Text: by radioactive fallout.

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Soviet Union did not warn the neighbouring

Speaker: NA
Text: countries of radioactive danger until at least 48 hours

Speaker: NA
Text: after the accident, thus delaying any precautions being

Speaker: NA
Text: taken by the populations of those countries.

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Soviet Union Government be held respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible for all health and material damage to the Polish

Speaker: NA
Text: people.

Speaker: NA
Text: That all nuclear reactors in the Soviet Union be

Speaker: NA
Text: subjected to international control.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives in Parliament assembled should do all

Speaker: NA
Text: in its power and authority, through the Government of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, to alleviate the suffering of the Polish people

Speaker: NA
Text: and to ensure that the negligence of the Soviet Union

Speaker: NA
Text: in the operation of nuclear reactors be condemned world

Speaker: NA
Text: wide, and that the Soviet Union Government be held

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible for all damage to health and property of

Speaker: NA
Text: countries affected by the nuclear disaster at Chernobyl.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever

Speaker: NA
Text: pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Hodgman.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Family Allowances

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives in Parliament assembled.

Speaker: NA
Text: We the undersigned are deeply concerned that any

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal by the Government to adopt a flat rate family

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance scheme would cause considerable hardship to

Speaker: NA
Text: low income families.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore humbly request that the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government to give due consideration to the effects

Speaker: NA
Text: of such a proposal on Australian families.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Humphreys.

Speaker: NA
Text: Death Penalty Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Television Services: Brisbane

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

Speaker: NA
Text: We the undersigned believe that the quality of recep-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the Brisbane SBS UHF television station is of a

Speaker: NA
Text: very poor quality in many of the Brisbane suburbs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives in Parliament assembled urge the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government to erect a translator capable of providing

Speaker: NA
Text: a service comparable to that of the major cities in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Humphreys.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Identity Cards

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The

Speaker: NA
Text: petition of the undersigned shows:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the proposed introduction of compulsory iden-

Speaker: NA
Text: tification (ID) cards should be reconsidered and rejected

Speaker: NA
Text: because the system:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) is not a cost-effective method of reducing tax

Speaker: NA
Text: evasion and social security fraud and, to the

Speaker: NA
Text: contrary, in the form proposed will facilitate such

Speaker: NA
Text: evasion and fraud;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) will constitute an unwarranted infringement of

Speaker: NA
Text: individual privacy by the aggregation of a wide

Speaker: NA
Text: variety of personal information of a private

Speaker: NA
Text: nature;

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) will cause a further large and costly growth in

Speaker: NA
Text: the bureaucracy and burden on the taxpayer; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (d) cannot be guaranteed against misuse for pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: poses other than for which their introduction is

Speaker: NA
Text: stated to be intended and in fact will provide the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity for blackmail and other forms of

Speaker: NA
Text: misuse.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners humbly pray that the problems

Speaker: NA
Text: which identification cards are intended to reduce should

Speaker: NA
Text: be attacked by other, more effective and less obnoxious

Speaker: NA
Text: methods.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever

Speaker: NA
Text: pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Kent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposed Medicare Office: Wyong, New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives assembled in Parliament: The

Speaker: NA
Text: petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the atten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the House to the fact that the lack of a Medicare

Speaker: NA
Text: Office in Wyong is seriously inconveniencing the resi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dents of Wyong Shire.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore request that a Medicare

Speaker: NA
Text: Office is established in Wyong as soon as possible.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Lee.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Discrimination against Women

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The

Speaker: NA
Text: humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: respectfully showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: That numerous provisions exist in industrial legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and awards which purport to provide special pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: tection to women workers but which have been shown

Speaker: NA
Text: to be detrimental to their achievement of equality in

Speaker: NA
Text: employment. Noting the relevant provision in Article II

Speaker: NA
Text: of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination

Speaker: NA
Text: of All Forms of Discrimination against Women to which

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is a party your petitioners request that urgent

Speaker: NA
Text: action be taken to ensure that these legal barriers to

Speaker: NA
Text: equality be removed.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, wiIl ever

Speaker: NA
Text: pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Ms MCHugh.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Radioactive Substances

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The

Speaker: NA
Text: petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradia-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive

Speaker: NA
Text: substance.

Speaker: NA
Text: We oppose the introduction of regulations that will

Speaker: NA
Text: facilitate the food irradiation process by State Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to

Speaker: NA
Text: extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure

Speaker: NA
Text: of workers to radiation.

Speaker: NA
Text: We call on the Government to immediately ban the

Speaker: NA
Text: importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive substances and to immediately disallow the regula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions that permit the irradiation

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Milton.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Bill of Rights Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

Speaker: NA
Text: The humble petition of certain electors of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: respectfully sheweth:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill of Rights BiIl, the Human Rights and

Speaker: NA
Text: Equal Opportunity Commission Bill, the Human Rights

Speaker: NA
Text: and Equal Opportunity Commission Amendment Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission (Transitional Provisions and Consequential

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendments) Bill, if passed by the Parliament, will

Speaker: NA
Text: undermine human and civil rights in Australia; will

Speaker: NA
Text: attack the institution of the family in our country, and

Speaker: NA
Text: will destroy States Rights and the federal nature of our

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners humbly pray that: The Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: rejects these Bills; abolishes the Human Rights and

Speaker: NA
Text: Equal Opportunity Commission and moves to withdraw

Speaker: NA
Text: ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and

Speaker: NA
Text: Political Rights.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever

Speaker: NA
Text: pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Nehl.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Prescription Drugs to Pensioners

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The

Speaker: NA
Text: humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: respectfully showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: (I) That we the undersigned are totally opposed to

Speaker: NA
Text: the introduction of a $2.00 fee on prescription drugs for

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) That the impact of such a fee will be particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: felt by the chronically ill elderly who will be faced with

Speaker: NA
Text: a $2.00 burden with the purchase of each Pharmaceut-

Speaker: NA
Text: ical Benefit Scheme drug;

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore urge the House of Repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives and the Government of the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure that prescription drugs continue to be pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided to the pensioner population without the $2.00 fee

Speaker: NA
Text: on each prescription.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever

Speaker: NA
Text: pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Reith.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Horticultural Industry

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

Speaker: NA
Text: We, the undersigned, are deeply concerned that Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia's important horticultural industry is being severely

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantaged by unnecessarily rising production costs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many Federal and State Government regulations, ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: of food here in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: cessive taxes and charges are damaging the ability of

Speaker: NA
Text: horticultural growers to maintain supplies of food and

Speaker: NA
Text: plant products to Australian families at a realistic cost.

Speaker: NA
Text: Widespread unemployment will result if horticultural

Speaker: NA
Text: producers are further depressed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The undersigned humbly petition the Parliaments of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, its States and Territories, to take all measures

Speaker: NA
Text: within their powers to reduce the burden of imposed

Speaker: NA
Text: costs and regulation, allowing Australian horticultural

Speaker: NA
Text: growers to develop production potential so the nation,

Speaker: NA
Text: as a whole, can share the benefits of the resulting

Speaker: NA
Text: growth and prosperity.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever

Speaker: NA
Text: pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Slipper.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Family Allowances

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The

Speaker: NA
Text: petition of the undersigned citizens of the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: That in the light of the Labor Government's proposal

Speaker: NA
Text: to bring about a reduction in the amount payable under

Speaker: NA
Text: the present Family Allowance Scheme, that the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives assembled oppose such a move, on

Speaker: NA
Text: the evidence of its impact upon the family unit.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives in Parliament assembled should imme-

Speaker: NA
Text: diately seek to restore payments to the former level.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever

Speaker: NA
Text: pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Slipper.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

Speaker: NA
Text: This petition of Australian residents shows that we

Speaker: NA
Text: strongly oppose the introduction of the "Australia Card"

Speaker: NA
Text: or any form of compulsory identity cards. We believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that the introduction of identity cards will erode civil

Speaker: NA
Text: liberties; will create an increased risk of invasion of

Speaker: NA
Text: privacy; and will not result in any significant increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: Government revenue.

Speaker: NA
Text: We call on the Parliament to immediately reject any

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals for the introduction of compulsory identity

Speaker: NA
Text: cards.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever

Speaker: NA
Text: pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Staples.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The

Speaker: NA
Text: petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their

Speaker: NA
Text: desire to have the wild horses of Queensland and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Northern Territory declared a protected species.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable House set aside a National Park for these

Speaker: NA
Text: horses and ensure that killing of feral animals be under-

Speaker: NA
Text: taken in a humane manner with proper legislation and

Speaker: NA
Text: enforcement.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners in duty bound ever pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Staples.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Family Allowances

Speaker: NA
Text: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives assembled in Parliament: The peti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of certain citizens of Australia draws to the atten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the House that we strongly object to family

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance being reduced to a flat rate per child or

Speaker: NA
Text: altered in any way that would reduce its value.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore pray that the family allow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance be left in its present form and value.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mrs Sullivan.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nuclear Weapons Tests

Speaker: NA
Text: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives in Parliament assembled; And, to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: This petition of concerned Australian citizens respect-

Speaker: NA
Text: fully points out that a comprehensive ban on all nuclear

Speaker: NA
Text: weapon tests in all environments for all time would be

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Text: by Mr Slipper.

Text: Your Petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its
