Text: wisdom will take no action to change the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: National Flag.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever

Speaker: NA
Text: pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: trade unions be recogby Dr Watson.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: TAXATION

Speaker: NA
Text: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Leo Mc-

Speaker: NA
Text: Leay)-Madam Speaker has received a letter

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ard) proposing that a definite matter of public

Speaker: NA
Text: importance be submitted to the House for dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussion, namely:

Speaker: NA
Text: The destructive impact of the Government's capital

Speaker: NA
Text: gains and fringe benefits tax proposals on the productive

Speaker: NA
Text: sector of the Australian economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: State I call upon those members who approve of the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed discussion to rise in their places.

Speaker: NA
Text: More than the number of members required

Speaker: NA
Text: the unby the Standing Orders having risen in their

Speaker: NA
Text: places-

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Text: I raise a point of order, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Speaker. I refer you to standing order

Speaker: NA
Text: House 82, which specifies that no member may antici-

Speaker: NA
Text: pate the discussion of any subject which appears

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Notice Paper. In fact, we have on the

Speaker: NA
Text: pray. Notice Paper the capital gains tax Bills. The fact

Speaker: NA
Text: is that they will be discussed and debated. One

Speaker: NA
Text: speech has already been made on those Bills. It

Speaker: NA
Text: would seem to me that this is precisely the kind

Speaker: NA
Text: of point which was intended when the standing

Speaker: NA
Text: order was formulated, that is, the question of

Speaker: NA
Text: whether--

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: It is a frivolous point of order.

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Text: It is not frivolous at all, it

Speaker: NA
Text: is an important point. Capital gains tax will be

Speaker: NA
Text: debated next week. Therefore I ask you, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Speaker, to rule that this discussion,

Speaker: NA
Text: especially the aspect on capital gains tax, is out

Speaker: NA
Text: of order.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Leo Mc-

Speaker: NA
Text: pray. Leay)-It has been the practice of the House to

Speaker: NA
Text: allow debate on the matter of public importance

Speaker: NA
Text: because that has been determined to be a discus-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion rather than a debate. Standing order 82,

Speaker: NA
Text: however, does say that no member may antici-

Speaker: NA
Text: National Flag pate the discussion of any subject which appears

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Notice Paper.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: It would be impossible to antic-

Speaker: NA
Text: ipate what you said, Andrew.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: The Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition might listen to the Chair. However,

Speaker: NA
Text: the standing order goes on "to say that regard

Speaker: NA
Text: shall be had by the Speaker to the probability

Speaker: NA
Text: of the matter anticipated being brought before

Speaker: NA
Text: the House within a reasonable time. My recol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lection last night, when the Treasurer ( Mr Keat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing) introduced these Bills, was that he said they

Speaker: NA
Text: would be debated next week. Notwithstanding

Speaker: NA
Text: that, it has been the practice of the House to

Speaker: NA
Text: allow discussions on matters of public impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance. There may be some relevance in the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable member's point of order and I will draw

Speaker: NA
Text: the substance of it to the attention of Madam

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, but I will allow the debate to continue.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr SincIair-I raise two points of order, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Speaker. First, I draw your attention to

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that perhaps the time might start for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition as of the time he

Speaker: NA
Text: commences speaking. Secondly, I suggest to you

Speaker: NA
Text: that any matter that is accepted by Madam

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker as a matter of public importance has in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact been ruled on at the time of that

Speaker: NA
Text: determination.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: There is no point

Speaker: NA
Text: of order, as the Leader of the National Party

Speaker: NA
Text: knows full well. If the Leader of the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Party had been listening he would have heard

Speaker: NA
Text: that I called the honourable member for Cal well

Speaker: NA
Text: before I called the Leader of the Opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition's time shall start

Speaker: NA
Text: from when I call him. If he rises I will probably

Speaker: NA
Text: call him now.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: Bennelong-Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition) (3.00)-Well, one never knows when

Speaker: NA
Text: one's luck is in. However, Mr Deputy Speaker,

Speaker: NA
Text: I think it is fair to say that the whole political

Speaker: NA
Text: and economic debate in this country was dra-

Speaker: NA
Text: matically changed last week when the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Keating) made his now famous statement

Speaker: NA
Text: about this country becoming a banana republic,

Speaker: NA
Text: a statement that will in time become not a

Speaker: NA
Text: famous or memorable statement but one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: more infamous statements that have been made

Speaker: NA
Text: by a senior Minister in a government in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now that we are at the end of the first week

Speaker: NA
Text: that Parliament has sat since that statement was

Speaker: NA
Text: made, I think it is a matter of regret to record

Speaker: NA
Text: that in the four days we have sat that no serious

Speaker: NA
Text: attempt has been made by the Treasurer or any

Speaker: NA
Text: other member of the Government to take the

Speaker: NA
Text: state of the Australian economy seriously. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer has not sought leave to make a state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment about the condition of the Australian econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omy; to tell the people of Australia why he

Speaker: NA
Text: believes we might be becoming a banana repub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lic; and to tell the Australian people why he

Speaker: NA
Text: thought it necessary to use words of panic and

Speaker: NA
Text: alarm that had a damaging effect on this coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try's international economic reputation and

Speaker: NA
Text: caused serious financial loss to the holders of

Speaker: NA
Text: assets of Australian currency. He has made no

Speaker: NA
Text: attempt at all to come into this Parliament and

Speaker: NA
Text: do that in the four days that we have sat. We

Speaker: NA
Text: would have facilitated a full-scale debate on the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Rather than do that, the Treasurer has re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sorted to cheap abuse, cheap jibes, trivial re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponses and a totally inadequate and

Speaker: NA
Text: inconsequential treatment of the economic prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lems of this country. I charge that the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: of this country is not taking our current eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic problems seriously; he is not taking the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament seriously; he is not taking his duties

Speaker: NA
Text: as Treasurer seriously; and he is certainly not

Speaker: NA
Text: taking seriously the consequences of the policies

Speaker: NA
Text: that his Government is visiting upon the Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian people and different sections of the Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian community.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is manifest, and has been manifest for a

Speaker: NA
Text: long time, that this country does have serious

Speaker: NA
Text: economic difficulties. I honestly believed that,

Speaker: NA
Text: inept though his words were, when the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: made his statement 10 days ago he was about to

Speaker: NA
Text: address himself seriously to the problems that

Speaker: NA
Text: we have. I fully expected that he would make a

Speaker: NA
Text: full statement when the Parliament resumed,

Speaker: NA
Text: that he would tell the Australian public where

Speaker: NA
Text: he stood, that he would tell the public what he

Speaker: NA
Text: had in mind for it, and that we would have an

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to debate this matter. But the reality

Speaker: NA
Text: is that, having sounded the alarm, he has done

Speaker: NA
Text: absolutely nothing about it. The reason he has

Speaker: NA
Text: done nothing about it is that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot make up its mind as to what it is going

Speaker: NA
Text: to do.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have had a classic example of such behav-

Speaker: NA
Text: iour this week. One could almost say that over

Speaker: NA
Text: the last week the Australian ship of state has hit

Speaker: NA
Text: economic rocks and is taking in quite a lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: water. The captain abandoned ship. He flew

Speaker: NA
Text: north and he blamed his officers. The Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: ran around the deck causing panic and then

Speaker: NA
Text: decided to have a summit to see whether anyone

Speaker: NA
Text: knew where the lifejackets were stowed. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Acting Prime Minister, the Attorney-General ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Lionel Bowen), pulled the cap over his eyes and

Speaker: NA
Text: told the passengers that the poopdeck summit

Speaker: NA
Text: was merely to check the charts. Senator Button

Speaker: NA
Text: said that the ship had been badly holed and

Speaker: NA
Text: would hit more rocks on the way to the bottom.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, of course, we had temper tantrums and

Speaker: NA
Text: a threat from the north from the Telecom tyrant

Speaker: NA
Text: as the captain started to get interested in some

Speaker: NA
Text: salvage rights. But the Acting Prime Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: ever dependable, came running in and said that

Speaker: NA
Text: the telephone hook-up was just a pleasant dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussion as the captain had just called to say: 'I

Speaker: NA
Text: love you all'. There has not been the serious

Speaker: NA
Text: addressing of the country's economic problems

Speaker: NA
Text: that we might have expected from this Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: or from the Acting Prime Minister. Rather, we

Speaker: NA
Text: have had a low grade farce. We have been given

Speaker: NA
Text: a totally inadequate response. The Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has no coherent plan. It has no idea and it has

Speaker: NA
Text: no coherent recognition of what is now needed

Speaker: NA
Text: seriously to address the economic problems of

Speaker: NA
Text: this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reality is that all of the warnings made

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Opposition about the Government's poli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cies over the last two years have come true, one

Speaker: NA
Text: by one. It is like the old story of nine green

Speaker: NA
Text: bottles hanging on the wall-one by one they all

Speaker: NA
Text: fall. One by one the warnings of the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion-the warnings that people could not believe

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government-have certainly come true. We

Speaker: NA
Text: all remember the ringing promises: There will be

Speaker: NA
Text: no capital gains tax. Is it not prophetic that the

Speaker: NA
Text: week the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) is cud-

Speaker: NA
Text: dling pandas in the provinces of China, his

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer introduces a Bill which breaks the

Speaker: NA
Text: most solemn and ringing promise made by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister in the 1983 election campaign.

Speaker: NA
Text: This apology for a Treasurer will come in here

Speaker: NA
Text: and talk about people having no shame. Mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers on the Government front bench can have

Speaker: NA
Text: no shame, given the number of promises they

Speaker: NA
Text: have broken. Not only was our warning that

Speaker: NA
Text: people could not believe the Government vindi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cated; when the Australian dollar was floated in

Speaker: NA
Text: December 1983, on behalf of the Opposition I

Speaker: NA
Text: said that the floating of the dollar was a very

Speaker: NA
Text: sensible move-I have never resiled from my

Speaker: NA
Text: praise for the Government's decision to float the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian dollar-but warned:

Speaker: NA
Text: Now that the dollar has, quite properly, been floated,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government can no longer "fudge" the exchange

Speaker: NA
Text: rate in order to protect it from the consequences of

Speaker: NA
Text: inappropriate and irresponsible domestic fiscal, mone-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary and wages policies.

Speaker: NA
Text: The dollar float imposes a new discipline on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course that is a discipline which it has been

Speaker: NA
Text: manifestly unable to meet. That is not the end

Speaker: NA
Text: of the matter. We warned the Government about

Speaker: NA
Text: the balance of payments problem. Month after

Speaker: NA
Text: month as the J-curve failed to arrive Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: spokesmen said that the theory was wrong and

Speaker: NA
Text: that ultimately the Government would have to

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledge that. Month after month the Treas-

Speaker: NA
Text: urer said: 'No, everything is just around the

Speaker: NA
Text: corner. Just have faith for another month. Be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve me for another month and everything will

Speaker: NA
Text: come right'. All of that came to grief last week

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Treasurer finally had to admit it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The greatest demonstration of the way in

Speaker: NA
Text: which this man has misled the Australian public,

Speaker: NA
Text: the way in which he has deceived the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: public, about the condition of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: economy is his pathetic attempt to say that our

Speaker: NA
Text: real problem is that we have lousy terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: trade. That has been as plain as a pikestaff for

Speaker: NA
Text: at least eight or nine months, perhaps longer.

Speaker: NA
Text: He admitted in the House yesterday that the

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of trade had dramatically deteriorated from

Speaker: NA
Text: October 1985. Yet do we find any reference at

Speaker: NA
Text: all to our terms of trade in the 600 pages of

Speaker: NA
Text: submission to the Australian Conciliation and

Speaker: NA
Text: Arbitration Commission at the current produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tivity hearing? In other words, the most grievous

Speaker: NA
Text: problem with our economy is considered to be

Speaker: NA
Text: so irrelevant, so inconsequential and so unwor-

Speaker: NA
Text: thy of mention that there is absolutely no serious

Speaker: NA
Text: reference to it in the submission. It was only

Speaker: NA
Text: after the Treasurer was flushed out by the Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position earlier this week that he weakly came

Speaker: NA
Text: into the House yesterday and said: 'We have

Speaker: NA
Text: presented some new material to the Arbitration

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission, not last October, not three weeks

Speaker: NA
Text: ago but today, so please forgive us. Don't, for

Speaker: NA
Text: heaven's sake, hold us to account'. The Treas-

Speaker: NA
Text: urer misled the Arbitration Commission and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian public. If the terms of trade have

Speaker: Mr HODGMAN
Text: Mr Cheating.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: Mr Cheating should have

Speaker: NA
Text: gone to the Arbitration Commission when he

Speaker: NA
Text: first made his submission. No wonder he is earn-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the very dubious title of being a very decep-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive Treasurer.

Speaker: NA
Text: The list goes on. We warned about the need

Speaker: NA
Text: for wage flexibility. Month after month the Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment said that we did not need that. We

Speaker: NA
Text: warned about the need for full discounting and

Speaker: NA
Text: about the unaffordability of the productivity case.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bit by bit the Government is being dragged

Speaker: NA
Text: screaming to a realisation that we cannot afford

Speaker: NA
Text: that productivity case this year if we are to

Speaker: NA
Text: restore our international competitiveness. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, in the face of all of this, the most impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant thing for this Parliament and the country

Speaker: NA
Text: to recognise is that we do have major economic

Speaker: NA
Text: problems and that those economic problems will

Speaker: NA
Text: not be solved unless the productive sector of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian economy is given a fairer go. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: the point of our charge today: The new capital

Speaker: NA
Text: gain!\. tax and the fringe benefits tax are a direct

Speaker: NA
Text: attack on the productive sectors of the Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian community. It is, therefore, no wonder that

Speaker: NA
Text: a bush fire of resentment is spreading throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: the business community as a result of the intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction of the fringe benefits tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Treasurer can rant and rave as much as

Speaker: NA
Text: he likes about tax avoidance. The old excuse for

Speaker: NA
Text: the introduction of any kind of bullheaded, blunt

Speaker: NA
Text: instrument by the Australian Labor Party is to

Speaker: NA
Text: scream 'tax avoidance!'. The reality is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: introduction of the fringe benefits tax will give

Speaker: NA
Text: to this country the most un competitive corporate

Speaker: NA
Text: tax structure in the Western world. Not only do

Speaker: NA
Text: we now have a very uncompetitive tax structure

Speaker: NA
Text: but also this Treasurer, this man who talks un-

Speaker: NA
Text: endingly about profits, will make it much worse.

Speaker: NA
Text: This country will have a tax structure which will

Speaker: NA
Text: make it much harder for our sorely pressed

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing industry to compete with imports.

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Text: Rubbish!

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr HOWARDI am delighted that my friend

Speaker: NA
Text: has come in and said 'Rubbish'. Let me read

Speaker: NA
Text: him some of the tax rates. After this year, when

Speaker: NA
Text: we take into account the fringe benefits tax,

Speaker: NA
Text: many corporations in this country will be paying

Speaker: NA
Text: an effective tax rate of 54 or 55 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Rocher-How much?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: They will be paying 54 or

Speaker: NA
Text: 55 per cent. That is what Australian companies

Speaker: NA
Text: will have to pay. Let us consider the rates with

Speaker: NA
Text: which they have to compete: In Malaysia, 40

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent; Singapore, 40 per cent; the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom, 35 per cent; the United States of

Speaker: NA
Text: America, currently 46 per cent, but proposed to

Speaker: NA
Text: go down to 43 per cent; Japan, 43 per cent; and

Speaker: NA
Text: Canada, 30 per cent for manufacturing or proc-

Speaker: NA
Text: essing and 36 per cent for other sectors of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian economy. And this character talks

Speaker: NA
Text: about the profit share! I remind him that the

Speaker: NA
Text: profit share is the operating surplus of a corpo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ration before we take into account taxation and

Speaker: NA
Text: interest charges. When we take into account

Speaker: NA
Text: taxation and interest charges in this country, any

Speaker: NA
Text: reference to the profit share as a decent measure

Speaker: NA
Text: of how the Australian economy is performing is

Speaker: NA
Text: an absolute nonsense. The real sting in what the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is doing is illustrated by the ludi-

Speaker: NA
Text: crous examples that are emerging day by day as

Speaker: NA
Text: people read the fringe benefits tax information

Speaker: NA
Text: booklet. I think one can fairly say that the fringe

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits tax guide could well prove to be the

Speaker: NA
Text: political epitaph of this Treasurer. I can tell the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer that that booklet will do more politi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal damage to him than any other booklet that

Speaker: NA
Text: any Australian Treasurer has ever authorised.

Speaker: NA
Text: All I can say is that the more of these booklets

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer can distribute the better because

Speaker: NA
Text: the more people who understand what he is

Speaker: NA
Text: about and how niggardly, how stupid, how in-

Speaker: NA
Text: sensitive and how commercially unreal the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed fringe benefits tax is, the better.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us go through the list of examples. Hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable members should listen to this one: A

Speaker: NA
Text: farm worker chops down wood for heating his

Speaker: NA
Text: family in their farm cottage, using a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: dead trees on the farmer's property. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: caught by the fringe benefits tax. Do honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members know what else is caught? When a

Speaker: NA
Text: farm worker uses a farm vehicle to drive his

Speaker: NA
Text: children to the school bus stop, that is caught. I

Speaker: NA
Text: interjected on the Treasurer the other day and

Speaker: NA
Text: talked about a clergyman owning a car. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Religious bodies are exempt. That is not caught'.

Speaker: NA
Text: But they are not exempt so far as private use is

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned-not at all. The attitude of those

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite is that they have to get them. I suppose

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer will get up and say that that is

Speaker: NA
Text: some kind of tax avoidance.

Speaker: NA
Text: Do honourable members know that under the

Speaker: NA
Text: capital gains tax legislation, despite all the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: testations of the Treasurer, one finds a form of

Speaker: NA
Text: death duty? If somebody leaves some assets to a

Speaker: NA
Text: tax exempt body, normally a religious body or a

Speaker: NA
Text: charity, do honourable members know who will

Speaker: NA
Text: bear the tax on that? It will be the estate of the

Speaker: NA
Text: deceased person. Yet the Treasurer will have the

Speaker: NA
Text: audacity to say that the legislation does not

Speaker: NA
Text: really contain any kind of death duty. The real-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity is that day after day, as the knowledge of

Speaker: NA
Text: the fringe benefits tax spreads throughout the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian community, as we realise how com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mercially insensitive and unreal the tax is, what

Speaker: NA
Text: an enormous burden it will be on the still over-

Speaker: NA
Text: burdened corporate sector in this country, and

Speaker: NA
Text: that at a time when Australian industry is

Speaker: NA
Text: screaming for competitiveness it has a Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: who is destined to make it more uncompetitive,

Speaker: NA
Text: I can say only that in reality the fringe benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: tax booklet will become the great political epi-

Speaker: NA
Text: taph of the present Treasurer of Australia.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: BlaxlandTreasurer)

Speaker: NA
Text: (3.20)- Mr Deputy Speaker, the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition ( Mr Howard) will need something

Speaker: NA
Text: to help him because if he cannot lay a glove on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government this week he never will. The

Speaker: NA
Text: fact is he could not beat time and we all know

Speaker: NA
Text: it, including those behind him. He will need lots

Speaker: NA
Text: of books to help him because the fact of the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter is he is politically helpless and hopeless.

Speaker: NA
Text: The faces of his supporters show full well that

Speaker: NA
Text: that is exactly right. He will not be around for

Speaker: NA
Text: long. We heard about the little cabal of the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: up in the--

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: You are a spiv, Paul. You are

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing but a spiv.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Order! The hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable member for Mitchell will cease walking

Speaker: NA
Text: around the chamber interjecting. He will resume

Speaker: NA
Text: his seat and will listen in silence.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: I ask that the remark be

Speaker: NA
Text: withdrawn.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: You couldn't get a job in a

Speaker: NA
Text: gravel pit.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member will not defy the Chair. He will cease

Speaker: NA
Text: interjecting.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: I am responding to his remarks.

Speaker: NA
Text: He couldn't get a job in a gravel pit.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: I ask that the remark be

Speaker: NA
Text: withdrawn.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Did the honoura-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble member for Mitchell make an unparliamen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary remark?

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: He did.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: The Chair did not

Speaker: NA
Text: hear the remark, but the Treasurer has asked

Speaker: NA
Text: that it be withdrawn.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: I said that the Treasurer could

Speaker: NA
Text: not get a job in a gravel pit. The fact is he

Speaker: NA
Text: sacked from one.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: As I understand

Speaker: NA
Text: it, the honourable member for Mitchell, when

Speaker: NA
Text: walking across the chamber, called the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: a spiv. That is unparliamentary. I do not think

Speaker: NA
Text: that saying the Treasurer could not get a job in

Speaker: NA
Text: a gravel pit is unparliamentary. If the honoura-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble member did use those words which I thought

Speaker: NA
Text: I heard him use, he will withdraw.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: I suggest that on all of these

Speaker: NA
Text: occasions you refer to the Clerks when your

Speaker: NA
Text: hearing fails you.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: I am asking you

Speaker: NA
Text: to withdraw.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: I withdraw.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: I will get to the point of this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of public importance. It was supposed to

Speaker: NA
Text: be about capital gains taxation but it was a

Speaker: NA
Text: diatribe on the economy. The fact of the matter

Speaker: NA
Text: is, after going through this range of so-called

Speaker: NA
Text: economic points, the Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: ended up saying that he has always supported

Speaker: NA
Text: the float and gave the Government due credit

Speaker: NA
Text: for it but in his speech to the National Press

Speaker: NA
Text: Club he said that the greatest policy failure of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government was that the depreciation of

Speaker: NA
Text: the dollar had reduced living standards. If the

Speaker: NA
Text: float was not going to provide depreciation, what

Speaker: NA
Text: was it there for? This is the sort of stuff we get

Speaker: NA
Text: every day from the Leader of the Opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact is that on a national accounts basis

Speaker: NA
Text: we know that the profitability of Australian cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: porations, the gross operating surplus of trading

Speaker: NA
Text: companies, has risen by $8t billion, or 48 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, in the last two years. In the last two years

Speaker: NA
Text: of the administration of the Leader of the Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position it rose by $1 billion-$1 billion com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared to $8t billion. He cried crocodile tears

Speaker: NA
Text: about the state of Australian business taxation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The coalition had a 7 per cent growth in profits

Speaker: NA
Text: with 24 per cent inflation and over the same

Speaker: NA
Text: period with 14 per cent inflation we have had a

Speaker: NA
Text: 48 per cent growth in profits. So he should not

Speaker: NA
Text: make stupid speeches about companies and prof-

Speaker: NA
Text: its because every company in Australia knows

Speaker: NA
Text: that those in the Opposition were as incompe-

Speaker: NA
Text: tent as a government as they are as an opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: Against this enormous increase in profits the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition talked about a few

Speaker: NA
Text: hundred million in the fringe benefits tax as if

Speaker: NA
Text: on the one hand the Government's policies can

Speaker: NA
Text: provide $8t billion but on the other hand a

Speaker: NA
Text: couple of hundred million going the other way

Speaker: NA
Text: is a national calamity. Of course he forgot to

Speaker: NA
Text: was mention the 5:3 depreciation which this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has provided business and which is costing

Speaker: NA
Text: $2 billion a year in accelerated depreciation. He

Speaker: NA
Text: forgot to mention the group loss provisions which

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government introduced for business. He

Speaker: NA
Text: forgot to mention the 150 per cent tax deduction

Speaker: NA
Text: for research and development that is likely to

Speaker: NA
Text: cost over $100m a year. He forgot to mention

Speaker: NA
Text: the major corporate reform of full imputation,

Speaker: NA
Text: the removal of the double tax on dividends, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the abolition of Division 7 tax that will cost

Speaker: NA
Text: $250m. All of that was forgotten in the one-

Speaker: NA
Text: eyed, one-sided presentation we heard just a few

Speaker: NA
Text: minutes ago from the Leader of the Opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition spoke of the

Speaker: NA
Text: couple of hundred million dollars in fringe ben-

Speaker: NA
Text: efits tax, but he ignored the $8.5 billion increase

Speaker: NA
Text: in profits, the full imputation system, the 5:3

Speaker: NA
Text: depreciation, group losses, and the faster write-

Speaker: NA
Text: off for investment in research and development.

Speaker: NA
Text: He focused on just one thing. Who does the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition think will be fooled by

Speaker: NA
Text: that? He ignored the total deregulation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: financial system, the steel plan, the motor vehi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cle plan and the rural package. He ignored the

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance to other industries. As if that sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: hollow attempt to try to make some pathetic

Speaker: NA
Text: case out of a fringe benefits tax which should

Speaker: NA
Text: have been applied 20 years ago under a coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: government to stop people from paying less than

Speaker: NA
Text: their fair share of taxation would cut any ice.

Speaker: NA
Text: After seven years in office, after seven years of

Speaker: NA
Text: tax disgrace on an international scale brought to

Speaker: NA
Text: the head of the coalition Government, honoura-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble members opposite now talk about the im-

Speaker: NA
Text: morality of a fringe benefits tax whose modest

Speaker: NA
Text: objective is to make people pay their fair share

Speaker: NA
Text: of tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact is that business in this country is

Speaker: NA
Text: massively better off under the Labor Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's policies, and everyone knows it. Honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members should not take my word for it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The best guide to how the market thinks the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's policies are going is the all ordi-

Speaker: NA
Text: naries index. The market is obviously not getting

Speaker: NA
Text: a boost from the rest of the world, because the

Speaker: NA
Text: rest of the world has given us a massive current

Speaker: NA
Text: account deficit. It has dropped prices on us, so

Speaker: NA
Text: there is no boost there. Where does the all

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinaries index stand? It stands at 1,100. Where

Speaker: NA
Text: was it in 1983 under the Leader of the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion? It stood at 500. The all ordinaries index of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian stock exchanges is twice as strong

Speaker: NA
Text: as a result of the domestic policies of the Hawke

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Government. That is the judgment of the

Speaker: NA
Text: level of corporate support for this Government,

Speaker: NA
Text: not some phoney speech manufactured by a failed

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer and by a group of people who could

Speaker: NA
Text: not possibly decipher what a decent policy is.

Speaker: NA
Text: The judgment is made where people vote with

Speaker: NA
Text: their feet-in the market and in the stock ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: changes, which have given the thumbs down to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition policies and the thumbs up to

Speaker: NA
Text: the policies of the Labor Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact is that this Government has more

Speaker: NA
Text: than doubled the value of the Australian stock

Speaker: NA
Text: exchanges. It has more than doubled the value

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian assets in those exchanges. It

Speaker: NA
Text: has lifted the profitability of Australian business

Speaker: NA
Text: by a massive $8.5 billion. The Opposition is

Speaker: NA
Text: shedding crocodile tears because we will stop

Speaker: NA
Text: people having free lunches at the expense of

Speaker: NA
Text: other taxpayers or we will stop people driving

Speaker: NA
Text: cars for their private use at the expense of other

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayers. In some way it sees that as a tax

Speaker: NA
Text: atrocity. That is the level of the moral bank-

Speaker: NA
Text: ruptcy of the present Opposition. That gives one

Speaker: NA
Text: some idea of the sorts of standards that would

Speaker: NA
Text: apply if honourable members opposite were to

Speaker: NA
Text: govern again from the treasury bench. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: why the public is quite smart. It will leave

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members opposite right where they

Speaker: NA
Text: are, in opposition, cackling away at Question

Speaker: NA
Text: Time and guffawing to themselves, happily in

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition, with no responsibility, no sense, and

Speaker: NA
Text: no place to go.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition in the last three

Speaker: NA
Text: minutes of his speech got on to capital gains

Speaker: NA
Text: taxation, which was supposedly the point of the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of public importance. I make the obvious

Speaker: NA
Text: point that a capital gains tax in this country is

Speaker: NA
Text: long, long overdue. Every other comparable

Speaker: NA
Text: country has a capital gains tax. In a country

Speaker: NA
Text: where capital is scarce, it has been an atrocity

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have seen the wasted allocation of scarce

Speaker: NA
Text: capital in non-productive areas of the economy

Speaker: NA
Text: with people chasing capital gains. The fact is

Speaker: NA
Text: that a capital gains tax assists the allocative

Speaker: NA
Text: efficiency of the economy. It does the right thing

Speaker: NA
Text: and puts the money in the right place-in the

Speaker: NA
Text: most productive areas. It is very interesting, is it

Speaker: NA
Text: not, to see the United States Government's tax

Speaker: NA
Text: reform proposals. The United States Congress is

Speaker: NA
Text: now seeking to increase the United States capital

Speaker: NA
Text: gains tax rate to the same level as that of the

Speaker: NA
Text: income tax. Why would that Government seek

Speaker: NA
Text: to increase the level of its capital gains tax rate

Speaker: NA
Text: to the same level as that of the income tax rate?

Speaker: NA
Text: It is because that Government knows that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: open to avoidance and that it distorts the level

Speaker: NA
Text: of allocative efficiency in the economy. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: why we have launched our policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Instead of that fact penetrating the minds of

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members opposite, they are back to

Speaker: NA
Text: the quick rort and the quick quid-the consid-

Speaker: NA
Text: eration that some of their mates might, if they

Speaker: NA
Text: chuck a couple of blocks of fiats up and pull a

Speaker: NA
Text: capital gain out of that, have to pay tax, or that

Speaker: NA
Text: someone will drive a new car for private use

Speaker: NA
Text: and will not be able to write it off. It is all

Speaker: NA
Text: about letting their mob skate through without

Speaker: NA
Text: paying their fair share of tax. One would never

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that in this day and age a modern parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary party such as the Liberal Party of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia or the National Party of Australia would

Speaker: NA
Text: proffer this sort of stuff as an issue in public

Speaker: NA
Text: policy. One would not believe that honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite, after copping it in the neck

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1983 and being thrown into opposition, would

Speaker: NA
Text: still return to this sort of sham argument about

Speaker: NA
Text: the tax system. The fact is that there are no

Speaker: NA
Text: principles in their policy approach. Therefore,·

Speaker: NA
Text: there are no tax principles; there are no fiscal

Speaker: NA
Text: principles; there are no principles in social pol-

Speaker: NA
Text: icy; and there are no principles in economic

Speaker: NA
Text: policy-because it is catch as catch can. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are pushed and shov-d by all the pressure groups.

Speaker: NA
Text: They make policy on the run just as it suits

Speaker: NA
Text: them. That is precisely the problem. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: where they are.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact is that the capital gains tax will be a

Speaker: NA
Text: great advance in tax policy in this country. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: totally prospective. Every property owned up to

Speaker: NA
Text: 19 September 1985 will be exempt. All farms

Speaker: NA
Text: owned on 19 September 1985 will be exempt.

Speaker: NA
Text: All properties owned on 19 September 1985 will

Speaker: NA
Text: be exempt. The fact of the matter is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: roulette of section 25A of the Income Tax As-

Speaker: NA
Text: sessment Act which meant that one was never

Speaker: NA
Text: sure whether one would be capital gains taxed

Speaker: NA
Text: finally has been abandoned. We have thrown

Speaker: NA
Text: section 25A out. We now have a full capital

Speaker: NA
Text: gains tax where there is total certainty and no

Speaker: NA
Text: more roulette about whether one might be or

Speaker: NA
Text: might not be taxed at the full rate not on the

Speaker: NA
Text: real gain, not on the inflation washed gain, but

Speaker: NA
Text: on the gain plus inflation-which was the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sequence of tax under section 25A.

Speaker: NA
Text: After listening to the pathetic arguments of

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members opposite on the range and

Speaker: NA
Text: ramifications of the Government's tax reform

Speaker: NA
Text: process over the last 18 months and seeing the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bills finally presented, I say to the Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: and to the public who are listening that all they

Speaker: NA
Text: should do is regard the Opposition as a party of

Speaker: NA
Text: individuals with no corporate plan, no corporate

Speaker: NA
Text: approach to tax, no corporate approach to eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic policy and no corporate approach to so-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial policy. If they want some fairness, decency

Speaker: NA
Text: and equity in tax policy, in tax principles and in

Speaker: NA
Text: economic and social policies, they will have to

Speaker: NA
Text: look to where they have always looked-the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Labor Party. They will get it from

Speaker: NA
Text: nowhere else. At least the Australian Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: has had the courage to get in there and clean

Speaker: NA
Text: up the tax system, to clean the ramps and rorts

Speaker: NA
Text: out of it in an effort to make the tax system

Speaker: NA
Text: more decent and fairer for the honest taxpaying

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians who have been asked to carry the

Speaker: NA
Text: burden of public policy in this country for too

Speaker: NA
Text: long.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore, we reject out of hand the dishonest

Speaker: NA
Text: proposition which is part and parcel of this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of public importance today. We reject

Speaker: NA
Text: absolutely the view of the Opposition that there

Speaker: NA
Text: is indeed any validity in any of the charge pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed against the Government's tay. policy. We

Speaker: NA
Text: are prepared to let the public make a judgment

Speaker: NA
Text: at any time about where the decency and cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: rectness of public policy is in this country. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: confident that the judgment will always come

Speaker: NA
Text: down on the side of the Australian Labor Party-

Speaker: NA
Text: the great party of social change in this country;

Speaker: NA
Text: the great party which has given people a fair go

Speaker: NA
Text: and decent standard of living; the only party

Speaker: NA
Text: which will give Australians a fairer society.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Leo Mc-

Speaker: NA
Text: Leay)- Order! The time for the discussion has

Speaker: NA
Text: concluded.

Speaker: NA
Text: JOINT COMMITTEE OF PUBLIC

Speaker: NA
Text: ACCOUNTS

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr Young)-by leave-agreed to:

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and that in his

Speaker: NA
Text: place Mr Downer be appointed as a member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: DAIRY PRODUCE BILL 1986

Speaker: NA
Text: [COGNATE BILLS:

Speaker: NA
Text: DAIRY PRODUCE LEVY (No.1) BILL 1986

Speaker: NA
Text: DAIRY PRODUCE LEVY (No.2) BILL 1986

Speaker: NA
Text: DAIRYING INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND

Speaker: NA
Text: PROMOTION LEVY (TERMINATION OF

Speaker: NA
Text: LEVY) BILL 1986

Speaker: NA
Text: DAIRY INDUSTRY STABILIZATION

Speaker: NA
Text: LEVY (TERMINATION OF LEVY) BILL

Speaker: NA
Text: DAIRY LEGISLATION (TRANSITIONAL

Speaker: NA
Text: PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL

Speaker: NA
Text: AMENDMENTS) BILL 1986]

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed.

Speaker: Dr HARRY EDWARDS
Text: Berowra) (3.31)-

Speaker: NA
Text: I thought to address the House briefly on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Dairy Produce Levy (No.1) Bill, the Dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: Produce Levy (No.2) Bill, the Dairying Indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try Research and Promotion Levy (Termination

Speaker: NA
Text: of Levy) Bill, the Dairy Industry Stabilization

Speaker: NA
Text: Levy (Termination of Levy) Bill and the Dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: Legislation (Transitional Provisions and Conse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quential Amendments) Bill because this is an

Speaker: NA
Text: historic occasion of a sort. The scheme of ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rangements for the industry proposed in the Bills

Speaker: NA
Text: replaces arrangements which have been in place

Speaker: NA
Text: in one form or another for over 50 years-since

Speaker: NA
Text: April 1934 to be precise. Arrangements that

Speaker: NA
Text: have persisted for that length of time must have

Speaker: NA
Text: something going for them. It needs to be recog-

Speaker: NA
Text: nised that there has been a very significant,

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed massive, rationalisation of the industry,

Speaker: NA
Text: from 49,000 farms to 19,000 farms, over those

Speaker: NA
Text: years. Certainly it is an indictment of the Hawke

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Government and indicative of its lack of

Speaker: NA
Text: genuine concern for the rural sector that last

Speaker: NA
Text: year it did its darndest to get through this Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament the then Kerin plan, which represented

Speaker: NA
Text: a substantial cutback in support to producers in

Speaker: NA
Text: this industry, which would have precipitated a

Speaker: NA
Text: wholesale crisis in the industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: I intended to rehearse, by way of gaining some

Speaker: NA
Text: perspective, a bit of history on this matter. I

Speaker: NA
Text: refreshed my memory for that purpose by con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sulting the 1961 study, The Australian Dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry by Drane and Edwards, of which I was

Speaker: NA
Text: a co-author. I was going to look at the Paterson

Speaker: NA
Text: plan which was implemented from 1926 to 1934,

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately preceding the arrangements which

Speaker: NA
Text: we are putting to bed, so to speak, with this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation. That was an interesting situation be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause it was based on almost the same principle

Speaker: NA
Text: as the current proposed arrangements. There

Speaker: NA
Text: was to be a levy on all butter to pay a bounty

Speaker: NA
Text: on exports, with the effect of raising the home

Speaker: NA
Text: price by the amount of the bounty. When that

Speaker: NA
Text: was introduced it led initially to an uplift of

Speaker: NA
Text: some 18 per cent in the Australian price. Then,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Depression years, from 1930 to 1934, the

Speaker: NA
Text: uplift over the export return was 40 per cent. It

Speaker: NA
Text: shows how there could be variation in this ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rangement, though under the proposed arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments in these Bills there is to be ultimately an

Speaker: NA
Text: uplift of 30 per cent and that rate fixed,

Speaker: NA
Text: unchanging.

Speaker: NA
Text: Subsequently the equalisation arrangements as

Speaker: NA
Text: we have known them in recent years were im-

Speaker: NA
Text: plemented. I note that 1959-60, predating the

Speaker: NA
Text: European Economic Community, was another

Speaker: NA
Text: period, like the Depression period, of bad export

Speaker: NA
Text: prices. Bad export prices have been characteris-

Speaker: NA
Text: tic of this industry. If at that time one included

Speaker: NA
Text: the dairy industry subsidy, the uplift of the ef-

Speaker: NA
Text: fective Australian market price for butter was

Speaker: NA
Text: of the order of 100 per cent. It was in the light

Speaker: NA
Text: of that that the 1961 study concluded that some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing drastic had to be done just as the Treas-

Speaker: NA
Text: urer ( Mr Keating), now becoming aware of the

Speaker: NA
Text: yawning gap in the balance of payments and the

Speaker: NA
Text: state of the Australian economy, realises that

Speaker: NA
Text: something drastic has to be done. He should

Speaker: NA
Text: have become aware of it a long while ago. That

Speaker: NA
Text: study then proposed a two-price scheme for but-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter and from that time the idea of a multiple

Speaker: NA
Text: price scheme has always had some currency in

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry. The proposal was that there be one

Speaker: NA
Text: price, the high home market price, for a quota

Speaker: NA
Text: of sales to the home market, and a different

Speaker: NA
Text: price, the frequently much lower export price,

Speaker: NA
Text: for the balance of a farmer's production.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: Does that work like multiple

Speaker: NA
Text: taxes?

Speaker: Dr HARRY EDWARDS
Text: Well, it is rather

Speaker: NA
Text: akin to the arrangements which now prevail in

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia, which has a three-tier ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rangement as outlined by my colleague the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable member for Forrest ( Mr Drummond)

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier today. It was recognised when it was

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed that that proposal was less than eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomically ideal. It was stated explicitly that it

Speaker: NA
Text: was proposed as a deliberate strong corrective to

Speaker: NA
Text: the then overexpansion of the industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Miles-Overproduction.

Speaker: Dr HARRY EDWARDS
Text: As I said; in this

Speaker: NA
Text: industry nothing much changes. More economi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cally ideal-to the extent that the export value

Speaker: NA
Text: is meaningful-was and is an arrangement to

Speaker: NA
Text: have one price, reasonably lifted above a too

Speaker: NA
Text: low export price. There is a question mark about

Speaker: NA
Text: that-just as there was about the two-price

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme, with its bureaucratic difficulties and so

Speaker: NA
Text: on. The question mark over the one-price scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: is precisely over the meaningfulness, or lack of

Speaker: NA
Text: it, of the export price in terms of the cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: efficient production, which it rarely reflects, es-

Speaker: NA
Text: pecially with a fixed uplift factor for export

Speaker: NA
Text: prices, proposed in this legislation to be 30 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, in a context of low-we could call it cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: rupt-and fluctuating export returns. We can

Speaker: NA
Text: witness right now the impact that the EEC

Speaker: NA
Text: decision on sales of cheese to Japan will have

Speaker: NA
Text: on the export price of cheddar cheese.

Speaker: Mr HODGMAN
Text: Is it the right measuring stick?

Speaker: Dr HARRY EDWARDS
Text: As to the long

Speaker: NA
Text: term, that is very hard to say. The industry

Speaker: NA
Text: might get into considerable difficulties. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: no such thing as the perfect solution for an

Speaker: NA
Text: industry with such a long and troubled history

Speaker: NA
Text: as this one has. Owing largely to this Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion's holding operation, which has given breath-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing space to the industry and has resulted in

Speaker: NA
Text: important transition concessions-we tried as best

Speaker: NA
Text: we could last year but we could not wring them

Speaker: NA
Text: out of the Government-we now have a meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ure before the House to which the industry,

Speaker: NA
Text: albeit reluctantly, is prepared to give a go. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, no-one should underestimate the difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: times ahead for the industry in terms of further

Speaker: NA
Text: rationalisation, at a potentially great cost in hu-

Speaker: NA
Text: man terms, the very real equity problem for the

Speaker: NA
Text: small and disciplined Western Australian sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor-which was referred to by my colleague, the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Forrest-and even, in-

Speaker: NA
Text: deed, the danger of breakouts from the

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Miles-Quite right.

Speaker: Dr HARRY EDWARDS
Text: As my colleague

Speaker: NA
Text: says, that is most important. The danger of

Speaker: NA
Text: breakouts from the arrangements would bring

Speaker: NA
Text: into play the so-called 'comfort' or safety clause

Speaker: NA
Text: and result in a wholesale crisis in the industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the honourable member for Gwydir ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Hunt) said, the proposals promise some benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: and predictability to the industry and have built

Speaker: NA
Text: in some important new incentives. To that ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tent the Opposition supports the Bills. But the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry and the Hawke Labor Government can

Speaker: NA
Text: rest assured that the Opposition will closely

Speaker: NA
Text: monitor the progress of these new arrangements.

Speaker: Mr HAWKER
Text: Wannon) (3.40)-1 would

Speaker: NA
Text: like to endorse some of the words of my col-

Speaker: NA
Text: league the honourable member for Berowra (Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: Harry Edwards). In beginning, I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: just remind honourable members that today we

Speaker: NA
Text: are talking about some very important Bills

Speaker: NA
Text: which, in fact, have taken years in gestation-

Speaker: NA
Text: something like two years, which an elephant

Speaker: NA
Text: would know all about. Yet the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House ( Mr Young) has decided to guillotine this

Speaker: NA
Text: debate. I think it is outrageous and just unbelievister

Speaker: NA
Text: able that this Government can treat the dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: industry with such contempt.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Cadmao-There is not a single member

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Labor Party here.

Speaker: Mr HAWKER
Text: There is not one back

Speaker: NA
Text: bencher of the Australian Labor Party over there.

Speaker: NA
Text: Worse still, the Minister for Primary Industry

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Kerin) has not been here for one second

Speaker: NA
Text: today of this debate. I think that is utterly

Speaker: NA
Text: disgraceful. In fact, when we talk about the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Primary Industry it is interesting to

Speaker: NA
Text: think that part of his portfolio covers bananas.

Speaker: NA
Text: I suppose he is the one who will give the Treas-

Speaker: NA
Text: urer ( Mr Keating) advice on how to run the

Speaker: NA
Text: banana republic.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Leo Mc-

Speaker: NA
Text: Leay)- Order! The honourable member should

Speaker: NA
Text: make his comments relevant to the Bills.

Speaker: Mr HAWKER
Text: The history of the Dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: Produce Bill 1986, the Dairy Produce Levy (No.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1) Bill 1986, the Dairy Produce Levy (No.2)

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill 1986, the Dairying Industry Research and

Speaker: NA
Text: Promotion Levy (Termination of Levy) Bill 1986,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Dairy Industry Stabilisation Levy (Termina-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of Levy) Bill 1986 and the Dairy Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: (Transitional Provisions and Consequential

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendments) Bill 1986 is one of bungling, as is

Speaker: NA
Text: the treatment of the dairying industry by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr HAWKER
Text: It is a scandal, as my friend

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Barker has pointed

Speaker: NA
Text: out.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Barker should cease interjecting on

Speaker: NA
Text: his way through the chamber.

Speaker: Mr HAWKER
Text: If ever a Minister deserved a

Speaker: NA
Text: ride on the slow boat to China I suggest it is the

Speaker: NA
Text: present Minister for Primary Industry. He ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tually announced back on 8 August 1984 that

Speaker: NA
Text: he would do something about the dairy industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: He demanded in a Press release that the industry

Speaker: NA
Text: respond within one month. What happened? We

Speaker: NA
Text: saw delay after delay. The Minister failed to

Speaker: NA
Text: consult properly with the industry. The Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: then blamed the industry. The Minister then

Speaker: NA
Text: blamed the Agricultural Council, but the fact is

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Minister failed to explain and to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: vince people in the dairy industry of the merits

Speaker: NA
Text: of his original plan.

Speaker: NA
Text: In short, the Minister failed to get support for

Speaker: NA
Text: what he was doing. Why did he fail? The Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: failed because he would not allow the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry time to adjust. He wanted his new dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: plan and he wanted it right now. All that the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry and the Opposition kept saying to him

Speaker: NA
Text: was: 'Just give the dairy industry a bit of time

Speaker: NA
Text: to adjust'. However, the Minister would not

Speaker: NA
Text: listen. All the industry and the Opposition was

Speaker: NA
Text: saying was: 'We want a bit of time to phase out

Speaker: NA
Text: the old arrangements'. One cannot say that is

Speaker: NA
Text: unreasonable when one considers that some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the old marketing arrangements have been in

Speaker: NA
Text: place for up to 50 years and when one also

Speaker: NA
Text: considers the time to restructure the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: was proposing to give the industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: When one compares the time to restructure

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government has given the dairy industry

Speaker: NA
Text: with the time it has given the steel industry,

Speaker: NA
Text: Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and the car

Speaker: NA
Text: industry one can see that it obviously was not

Speaker: NA
Text: an unreasonable request. But the Minister said:

Speaker: NA
Text: 'No, here is my marvellous plan and I want it

Speaker: NA
Text: in place without time for the industry to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: adjust'. Because of his obstinate behaviour and

Speaker: NA
Text: because he carried on like a spoilt child there

Speaker: NA
Text: was an uproar in the dairy industry. There were

Speaker: NA
Text: blockades. We then saw this Minister for Pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: mary Industry sink to the depths of political

Speaker: NA
Text: grime. When the Victorian election came up in

Speaker: NA
Text: March last year the Minister suddenly agreed to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Dairy Industry Conference plan

Speaker: NA
Text: just two days before the Victoria election. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister and the Premier of Victorian, Mr Cain,

Speaker: NA
Text: did the shabbiest political deal of the year. Both

Speaker: NA
Text: this Minister and the Victorian Premier should

Speaker: NA
Text: be utterly ashamed of what they did. The Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne Age put it very succinctly in an editorial

Speaker: NA
Text: on 29 March this year when it said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Federal Minister for Primary Industry, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: was kind enough to let Mr Cain win his election before

Speaker: NA
Text: pulling the rug from under his feet.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that spells out exactly the sort of tactics

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister was prepared to stoop to. It con-

Speaker: NA
Text: firms that it was a very shabby deal. Following

Speaker: NA
Text: this, the Minister then tried to ram his first

Speaker: NA
Text: attempt at the legislation through the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Obviously he could get it through this place but

Speaker: NA
Text: when he went to the Senate, the Senate told

Speaker: NA
Text: him what he had been told all along: 'Just give

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry a bit of time to adjust'. The Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter was not happy with that. He was prepared

Speaker: NA
Text: to force this legislation on to the industry less

Speaker: NA
Text: than two months from the time it would come

Speaker: NA
Text: into effect. Like a spoilt child, when the Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: would not accept the Minister's legislation, he

Speaker: NA
Text: took his bat and his ball home and he withdrew

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislation. So here we are again, a year later,

Speaker: NA
Text: with a similar Bill to put through the provisions

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister wanted to introduce before. Ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: viously time has gone on. As preceding speakers

Speaker: NA
Text: on this side of the chamber have pointed out,

Speaker: NA
Text: all the industry was asking from the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: was a bit of time. This is the way the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: has let it happen because he would not listen to

Speaker: NA
Text: the advice he was getting from the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: and from the industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: One thing that should be pointed out is that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a myth that the Government has tried

Speaker: NA
Text: to peddle over the last few years that milk prices

Speaker: NA
Text: are too high, especially fresh milk prices. When

Speaker: NA
Text: one looks at the figures presented by the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable member for Gwydir ( Mr Hunt) one sees

Speaker: NA
Text: that milk has not kept pace with the consumer

Speaker: NA
Text: price index over the last 15 years. In fact, rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tively, it is much cheaper for consumers now

Speaker: NA
Text: than it was in 1970. It is interesting to look at

Speaker: NA
Text: the Press release put out by the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Primary Industry on 22 March 1985 when he

Speaker: NA
Text: announced his first big attempt to bring in this

Speaker: NA
Text: new dairy legislation. At the bottom of page 2

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Press release there is an interesting little

Speaker: NA
Text: quotation.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: Hey, look at this!

Speaker: Mr HAWKER
Text: Well, the Minister has ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rived. I will read the quotation to him. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The consumer and the nation's economy will bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: fit--

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: The first time today.

Speaker: Mr HAWKER
Text: It is great to see him here.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the Minister said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The consumer and the nation's economy will benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: through lower prices.

Speaker: NA
Text: That really says what this Minister is trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: do with his dairy legislation and what is in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Kerin, back of the mind of this Government. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: determined to get milk and milk product prices

Speaker: NA
Text: down. That is really what they are trying to do.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I have said, we are on a tight schedule,

Speaker: NA
Text: but there are a couple of points I want to bring

Speaker: NA
Text: up with the Minister now that he has been so

Speaker: NA
Text: good as to come into this chamber for the de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bate. Clause 6 of the Dairy Produce Levy Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: (No.1) covers the situation where there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: dispute about interstate milk trade and it is

Speaker: NA
Text: decided to suspend the levy. I understand why

Speaker: NA
Text: that clause is there, but I would like the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: to tell us today what he will do should that

Speaker: NA
Text: clause ever be enacted. It is likely that there

Speaker: NA
Text: would be a complete collapse of the fresh milk

Speaker: NA
Text: marketing system. I wonder what the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: would offer to the industry if that happened.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another point has been mentioned by preceding

Speaker: NA
Text: speakers but I will not go into it in detail. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister should be considering at some time in

Speaker: NA
Text: the future the question of the collection of the

Speaker: NA
Text: levy on butterfat only. As has been pointed out,

Speaker: NA
Text: this could discriminate against producers with

Speaker: NA
Text: certain types of cattle. There is a proposal that,

Speaker: NA
Text: if the dairy factories move towards a system of

Speaker: NA
Text: payment on butterfat and protein, the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment should collect the levy in the same way.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is another point I want to raise with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister. He suggested that there is a need

Speaker: NA
Text: for ministerial approval in writing for virtually

Speaker: NA
Text: all operations of Asia Dairy Industries (Hong

Speaker: NA
Text: Kong) Ltd. Will the Minister explain either to-

Speaker: NA
Text: day or when he gets time-I know he is on a

Speaker: NA
Text: tight schedule-how he proposes to use this pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vision in the legislation. As has already been

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned by preceding speakers in the House,

Speaker: NA
Text: there is quite a concern about the choice of a

Speaker: NA
Text: chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think the Minister should at least agree to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sult the industry before he appoints a chairman.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think he should also give very serious thought

Speaker: NA
Text: to the request of the dairy industry that there

Speaker: NA
Text: be a producer chairman.

Speaker: NA
Text: In conclusion, the way this legislation has fi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nally arrived is an example of bungling and

Speaker: NA
Text: incompetence. We have seen delay after delay,

Speaker: NA
Text: and at times, worst of all, downright deliberate

Speaker: NA
Text: deception by this Minister to try to help his

Speaker: NA
Text: colleague Mr Cain. The industry has been going

Speaker: NA
Text: through very difficult times over the last three

Speaker: NA
Text: years. Some of these difficulties have been exac-

Speaker: NA
Text: erbated by the actions and the inactions of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister. Nonetheless, the legislation provides

Speaker: NA
Text: some opportunity for the industry to restructure.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, as I pointed out, there are pitfalls that

Speaker: NA
Text: may arise in the future. The challenge will be

Speaker: NA
Text: whether the Minister will show his concern for

Speaker: NA
Text: the future of dairy farmers, or, if the problem

Speaker: NA
Text: arises, will be more interested in trying to exploit

Speaker: NA
Text: a potential breakdown of the marketing arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment for the benefit of consumers.

Speaker: NA
Text: derstand that the time allotted for debate on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Dairy Produce Bill will expire in about 30 sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: onds. I will content myself with saying that I am

Speaker: NA
Text: delighted that the industry has been able to

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiate to the extent it has in terms of this

Speaker: NA
Text: very complex measure. Government speakers in

Speaker: NA
Text: this debate have suggested that the whole scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: is merely a carry-on of what had been proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: last year as the Kerin scheme. Nothing could be

Speaker: NA
Text: further from the truth. Fortunately there is to-

Speaker: NA
Text: day a degree of agreement between sections of

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry. In view of the long history of this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter, it is to be hoped that this will be the

Speaker: NA
Text: starting point of a revised management of the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many elements of the scheme concern the

Speaker: NA
Text: State governments and it is for those govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments and the dairy authorities within the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: spective States to give serious attention to such

Speaker: NA
Text: matters as payments being made on a basis which

Speaker: NA
Text: is satisfactory to all sections of the industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Composite payments should take into account

Speaker: NA
Text: quality. In that respect, I believe the levy ulti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mately must recognise the importance of that

Speaker: NA
Text: factor. Whilst the decision to base the levy on

Speaker: NA
Text: butter-fat content has been justified, some very

Speaker: NA
Text: pertinent issues still remain for some producers.

Speaker: NA
Text: I give an example of what that means. A pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducer with 3,500 litres of milk at 5.2 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: butter-fat test will be charged the same as a

Speaker: NA
Text: producer who has a yield of 5,000 litres of milk

Speaker: NA
Text: at a 3.6 per cent butter-fat content. A number

Speaker: NA
Text: of problems will have to be resolved, and I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that there will be co-operation between the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: spective sections of the industry to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: that is done.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, it is unfortunate that more recognition

Speaker: NA
Text: was not given by the Government side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of the actions that have been taken by

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry itself. I instance, for example, the

Speaker: NA
Text: last annual report of the Australian Dairy Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: search Committee, which shows that for over a

Speaker: NA
Text: decade excellent work has been done to encour-

Speaker: NA
Text: age the development of new standards and new

Speaker: NA
Text: techniques. This is occurring to the advantage of

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry. Therefore, it is wrong for the Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment to take credit for what in fact has been

Speaker: NA
Text: done by the industry itself. I hope that this

Speaker: NA
Text: measure will be a first step towards improving a

Speaker: NA
Text: most critical situation in one of the industries of

Speaker: NA
Text: this country which has been beleaguered for a

Speaker: NA
Text: very long time.

Speaker: Mr KERIN
Text: Werriwa-Minister for Primary

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry) (3.53)-in reply-I thank the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members who have made a contribution to

Speaker: NA
Text: this debate. It is a pity that many of them

Speaker: NA
Text: wasted some time by engaging in abuse. As we

Speaker: NA
Text: all well know, this matter has been well dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussed in the Parliament. I will reply in detail

Speaker: NA
Text: and at some length to the various points, alle-

Speaker: NA
Text: gations and abuse raised by honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite.

Speaker: NA
Text: The central theme of the reforms contained

Speaker: NA
Text: in the package is the reorientation of the indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try to the requirements of the market rather

Speaker: NA
Text: than production. The Government and Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment are providing a revised framework to ena-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble the industry to improve its competitiveness

Speaker: NA
Text: in both the domestic and overseas markets. In

Speaker: NA
Text: addition to the range of measures contained in

Speaker: NA
Text: the package, special funds are being made avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able-$25m over five years for marketing inno-

Speaker: NA
Text: vation of rural products, on which the dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: industry should be able to draw; up to $40m of

Speaker: NA
Text: part B rural adjustment scheme borrowing, in

Speaker: NA
Text: conjunction with the States, especially for the

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy industry. Moneys are being disbursed now

Speaker: NA
Text: and it is up to each State to choose the best

Speaker: NA
Text: form of assistance through part A or part B of

Speaker: NA
Text: the rural adjustment scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to correct a misunderstanding

Speaker: NA
Text: that the honourable member for Gwydir ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Hunt) has about the new underwriting arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. The old system involved underwriting 90

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of three years' export returns. The new

Speaker: NA
Text: system will involve 85 per cent of a long term

Speaker: NA
Text: trend value based on eight years of export re-

Speaker: NA
Text: turns rather than 85 per cent of three years'

Speaker: NA
Text: export returns. The new method is expected to

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit the industry in the current international

Speaker: NA
Text: situation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Everyone raised the question that the dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: industry itself is running with. Of course, most

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers are paid on milk fat delivered. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: desirable, therefore, to align collections of levies

Speaker: NA
Text: to milk fat rather than whole milk. Also, expe-

Speaker: NA
Text: rience in Europe of levy based on milk suggests

Speaker: NA
Text: that problems could arise due to milk being

Speaker: NA
Text: dehydrated. In the future the industry may move

Speaker: NA
Text: to a compositional system of payments wherein

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers may be paid on milk fat and protein

Speaker: NA
Text: content or their milk solids non-fat product.

Speaker: NA
Text: When that occurs the Government will consider

Speaker: NA
Text: basing levies on a compositional basis. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: no objection to that.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reform of the Australian Dairy Corpora-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion follows the policy with respect to the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: form of all statutory marketing authorities; it

Speaker: NA
Text: provides for a corporate board chosen by an

Speaker: NA
Text: independent selection committee. The legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: provides for areas of expertise for board mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers and includes milk production. The Chair-

Speaker: NA
Text: man of the Corporation is selected and appointed

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Minister on essentially corporate leader-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship grounds. The best person for the job is

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed on merit rather than having a partic-

Speaker: NA
Text: ular background. It is true that I have not con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sulted the industry before contacting a person

Speaker: NA
Text: who is eminently suitable, but I have privately

Speaker: NA
Text: conveyed that name to the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Gwydir. The Australian Dairy Industry

Speaker: NA
Text: Council, the Australian Dairy Farmers Federa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and the United Dairyfarmers of Victoria all

Speaker: NA
Text: understand why I acted as quickly as I did: It is

Speaker: NA
Text: due to the eminence of the person. Of course

Speaker: NA
Text: there will be consultations in the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is absolute nonsense to say that there has

Speaker: NA
Text: been no consultation. I have just taken out some

Speaker: NA
Text: figures. The major industry meetings that I have

Speaker: NA
Text: had on this whole issue are as follows: I had 20

Speaker: NA
Text: meetings with the industry's leadership, five

Speaker: NA
Text: meetings with industry groups at a State level

Speaker: NA
Text: and six meetings with State Ministers, there were

Speaker: NA
Text: six meetings of the Australian Agricultural

Speaker: NA
Text: Council, the matter was considered in Cabinet

Speaker: NA
Text: on 17 occasions, I have met with the industry

Speaker: NA
Text: 55 times since I January 1985, the matter has

Speaker: NA
Text: been before the primary industry sub-committee

Speaker: NA
Text: 13 times. Anyone who says that there has been

Speaker: NA
Text: no consultation on this issue or that I have

Speaker: NA
Text: treated the industry with contempt is really hav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing himself on.

Speaker: NA
Text: The final point I would like to make is that

Speaker: NA
Text: this legislation is, by and large, the same as the

Speaker: NA
Text: package of legislation I put up about a year ago,

Speaker: NA
Text: when the industry chose not to understand it. I

Speaker: NA
Text: was certainly prepared to allow the ADIC to

Speaker: NA
Text: again try to get a rolling entitlement scheme up,

Speaker: NA
Text: but it ran into the same snag that I ran into;

Speaker: NA
Text: that is, that it is very difficult to

Speaker: NA
Text: governments to agree on this industry. I accept

Speaker: NA
Text: what the honourable member for Brand (Ms

Speaker: NA
Text: Fatin) and the honourable member for Forrest

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Drummond) have said about the situation

Speaker: NA
Text: in Western Australia. I praise the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Brand for the assiduous way she has

Speaker: NA
Text: pursued the interests of the Western Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy farmers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Message from the Governor-General recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mending appropriation announced.

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted for third reading to be moved

Speaker: NA
Text: forthwith.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill (on motion by Mr Kerin) read a third

Speaker: NA
Text: time.

Speaker: NA
Text: DAIRY PRODUCE LEVY (NO.1) BILL

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 7 May, on motion by

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Kerin:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr HAWKER
Text: Wannon) (3.59)-1 wish to

Speaker: NA
Text: take up a point with the Minister for Primary

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry ( Mr Kerin). I think what the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: said a minute ago was quite offensive. He praised

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Brand (Ms Fatin)

Speaker: NA
Text: yet he ignored the honourable member for For-

Speaker: NA
Text: rest ( Mr Drummond). The honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Forrest has worked very hard for his dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers. He has brought up the concern of dairy

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers in Western Australia with the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion rural committee and in the Opposition party

Speaker: NA
Text: room. He has spoken to all members who have

Speaker: NA
Text: any interest whatsoever in the dairy industry

Speaker: NA
Text: about the concern of the dairy farmers in West-

Speaker: NA
Text: ern Australia and has done so in a very eloquent

Speaker: NA
Text: and persuasive manner. I think that the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: was quite uncharitable in his comments when he

Speaker: NA
Text: ignored the efforts of the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Forrest.

Speaker: Mr KERIN
Text: Werriwa-Minister for Primary

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry) (3.59)-in reply-All I can say is that

Speaker: NA
Text: I acknowledge the efforts of the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Forrest ( Mr Drummond). I linked

Speaker: NA
Text: the two members together. Of course as a mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of the Australian Labor Party I am far more

Speaker: NA
Text: aware of the efforts of the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Brand (Ms Fatin) because she has been in

Speaker: NA
Text: the primary industry sub-committee which, as I

Speaker: NA
Text: said, discussed this matter 13 times. Of course I

Speaker: NA
Text: get six State am more aware of her efforts.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a second time.
