Text: Third Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted for third reading to be moved

Speaker: NA
Text: forthwith.

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr Kerin) proposed:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a third time.

Speaker: Mr ANDREW
Text: Wakefield) (4.01)-Aware of

Speaker: NA
Text: the time constraints the House is acting under, I

Speaker: NA
Text: remind the people who are listening, both in this

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber and on the airwaves, to this debate on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Dairy Produce Bill 1986, the Dairy Produce

Speaker: NA
Text: Levy (No.1) Bill 1986, the Dairy Produce Levy

Speaker: NA
Text: (No.2) Bill 1986, the Dairying Industry Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: search and Promotion Levy (Termination of

Speaker: NA
Text: Levy) Bill 1986, the Dairy Industry Stabilization

Speaker: NA
Text: Levy (Termination of Levy) Bill 1986 and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Dairy Legislation (Transitional Provisions and

Speaker: NA
Text: Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986, that the

Speaker: NA
Text: problem currently facing Australia with these

Speaker: NA
Text: Bills is that they are being guillotined through

Speaker: NA
Text: the House, so preventing a number of honoura-

Speaker: NA
Text: ble members from participating in the debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the House ( Mr Young) moved

Speaker: NA
Text: the guillotine in the House this morning, indicat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to the House that the guillotine was neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary because, he alleged, the Senate had put a

Speaker: NA
Text: particular restraint on the time it would make

Speaker: NA
Text: available to consider the Bills it received from

Speaker: NA
Text: the House of Representatives.

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Text: That is true; you know this.

Speaker: Mr ANDREW
Text: One moment, if the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: would not mind. For this reason, the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House said, it was necessary to guillotine

Speaker: NA
Text: these Bills, and Bills to be dealt with next week,

Speaker: NA
Text: through the House. He not only alleged, but

Speaker: NA
Text: stated, that the guillotine was solely the result

Speaker: NA
Text: of actions by the Australian Democrats and, he

Speaker: NA
Text: implied, by the National Party of Australia and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Liberal Party of Australia. Those who were

Speaker: NA
Text: listening to the moving of the guillotine would

Speaker: NA
Text: have presumed, therefore, that members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Labor Party had been offended by

Speaker: NA
Text: this course of action.

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Text: We are.

Speaker: Mr ANDREW
Text: I am delighted that the Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister is interjecting, because the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House went on to imply that there were shades

Speaker: NA
Text: of 1975 and something unconstitutional in the

Speaker: NA
Text: action of the Senate. I will have the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal Affairs ( Mr Holding) know that there

Speaker: NA
Text: may well be honourable members on this side of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House who agree that this is a most unusual

Speaker: NA
Text: course of action. I was surprised and, I must

Speaker: NA
Text: confess, rather delighted to pick up the .Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: Hansard record of those events and discover

Speaker: NA
Text: that there was no division. Not one ALP senator

Speaker: NA
Text: voted against the position in which the House

Speaker: NA
Text: currently finds itself.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hawker-Are you sure?

Speaker: Mr ANDREW
Text: Allow me to quote what was

Speaker: NA
Text: said by Senator Grimes, the Manager of Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment Business in the Senate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-Order! I point out to the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member that we are on the third

Speaker: NA
Text: reading of the Dairy Produce Lev- (No. -) Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: I ask him to be relevant to the Bill that IS now

Speaker: NA
Text: before the House.

Speaker: Mr ANDREW
Text: I respect your point, Madam

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker. I merely reiterate that we are being

Speaker: NA
Text: forced, because of the action that has been taken,

Speaker: NA
Text: to deal with this legislation in less time than we

Speaker: NA
Text: would choose. The action was more bipartisan

Speaker: NA
Text: than the Leader of the House would have us

Speaker: NA
Text: believe.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-The honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber has made his point.

Speaker: Mr ANDREW
Text: I pick up the point made by

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Wan non ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawker) and the honourable member for For-

Speaker: NA
Text: rest ( Mr Drummond). The dairy indu.stry d?es

Speaker: NA
Text: not deceive itself into supposing that thiS hurned

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation will meet all of its needs. I represent

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy farmers who are disadvantaged by the ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion being taken in the House today-disadvan-

Speaker: NA
Text: taged because they themselves have controlled

Speaker: NA
Text: their market and made it their business to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide incentives to encourage dairy farmers to

Speaker: NA
Text: produce during the off season to the point at

Speaker: NA
Text: which the northern milk suppliers in South Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia whom I represent have farmers whose

Speaker: NA
Text: spring:autumn production ratio is 1.15:1 com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared with the Adelaide suppliers' ratio .of 2.5:1.

Speaker: NA
Text: They have exercised the sort of responsible con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trol and reward for being prudent that would

Speaker: NA
Text: make this legislation unnecessary across Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. They are being penalised for having taken

Speaker: NA
Text: that action. I regret that I have to hurry to say

Speaker: NA
Text: those words. I regret, too, that this legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: has been guillotined through the House, when

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Grimes was prepared to say that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government would not oppose and certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: would not divide on the amendment that Sena-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor Chaney was proposing, forcing the Senate to

Speaker: NA
Text: consider these Bills in such a short space of time.

Speaker: NA
Text: for There has been bipartisan Senate acceptance,

Speaker: NA
Text: not opposition from the Liberal and National

Speaker: NA
Text: Parties.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a third time.

Speaker: Mr DRUMMOND
Text: Forrest) (4.05)-1 wish

Speaker: NA
Text: to make one point regarding the Dairy Produce

Speaker: NA
Text: Levy (No.2) Bill which I did not have time

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier in the day to make. Other governments

Speaker: NA
Text: have legislation to protect their farmers from

Speaker: NA
Text: corrupt world prices. I tried to illustrate that

Speaker: NA
Text: this Bill is about world traded prices, but

Speaker: NA
Text: they are corrupt prices. It is not a genuine ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: port commodity measure such as every nation

Speaker: NA
Text: has. I refer, for example, to the United States

Speaker: NA
Text: and its farm Bill. This legislation will expose

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian farmers to those corrupt prices. I

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest that the Government is swimming against

Speaker: NA
Text: the tide by proceeding in this way. The prices

Speaker: NA
Text: that come back, because there is no umbrella of

Speaker: NA
Text: any description underneath this export price,

Speaker: NA
Text: will not really signal to the farmers what that

Speaker: NA
Text: last litre of milk is worth.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Harry Edwards-What is it worth?

Speaker: Mr DRUMMOND
Text: The last litre of milk is

Speaker: NA
Text: worth between 5c and lOco We must remember

Speaker: NA
Text: that the end of our export market tends towards

Speaker: NA
Text: stock feeds. It is a very low value commodity.

Speaker: NA
Text: So, as I say, every country has some sort of net

Speaker: NA
Text: under individual companies that find it difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: to find a market. The New Zealand Dairy Board

Speaker: NA
Text: purchases and acts as sole seller. The European

Speaker: NA
Text: Economic Community provides restitution sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidies. They were well described by the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Gwydir ( Mr Hunt) earlier today

Speaker: NA
Text: in regard to the effect it is having on the cheese

Speaker: NA
Text: market into Japan. Those restitution subsidies

Speaker: NA
Text: are now flexible and secret. The United States

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has export enhancement programs.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is what Australian producers will be up

Speaker: NA
Text: against as time goes by. So if our individual

Speaker: NA
Text: companies do not have operating in the inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: national market a real umbrella of any descrip-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion-such as pooling, which exists under the

Speaker: NA
Text: present system-they will find it difficult to

Speaker: NA
Text: ticipate under the closer economic relations ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rangement with New Zealand in third markets,

Speaker: NA
Text: as CER directs; and they will find it increasingly

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult to meet the General Agreement on Tar-

Speaker: NA
Text: iffs and Trade requirements. As I say, my fear

Speaker: NA
Text: is that they will turn more and more back to

Speaker: NA
Text: the domestic market and will undercut the do-

Speaker: NA
Text: mestic price through supermarket chains. I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not quite see how the system will not fall into

Speaker: NA
Text: disrepute.

Speaker: Mr KERIN
Text: Werriwa-Minister for Primary

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry) (4.08)-in reply-Obviously the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable member for Forrest ( Mr Drummond)

Speaker: NA
Text: does not understand what is being done or the

Speaker: NA
Text: present situation in the dairy industry. Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian farmers are already exposed to the corrupt

Speaker: NA
Text: price on the international market. If the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member is suggesting that we get into the

Speaker: NA
Text: business of competitive subsidisation, I am

Speaker: NA
Text: amazed that his Party's policy document did not

Speaker: NA
Text: say that this week. If we wanted to get into

Speaker: NA
Text: competitive subsidies against the European Eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: in fact nomic Community and the United States, we

Speaker: NA
Text: would be looking at, for all commodities, at least

Speaker: NA
Text: $5 billion or $6 billion worth of subsidies in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. We really cannot afford that. The ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: isting system does not pass any market signal

Speaker: NA
Text: back to an individual producer, nor does it re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ward a manufacturer for any particular sales

Speaker: NA
Text: choice he takes.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is nonsense to say that the industry has no

Speaker: NA
Text: umbrella because the underwriting will trigger if

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a dramatic price collapse. The system of

Speaker: NA
Text: underwriting will be a far better mechanism

Speaker: NA
Text: because under the present system we could have

Speaker: NA
Text: a pay-out in a year that is good and no pay-out

Speaker: NA
Text: in a year that is bad. That is a technical defi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciency, and that is why we have moved to an 8-

Speaker: NA
Text: year average.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is nonsense to say there is no underpinning

Speaker: NA
Text: of the industry. Quite apart from the money we

Speaker: NA
Text: are putting in with respect to restructuring the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry we are starting off with a level of price

Speaker: NA
Text: support by domestic consumers and by product

Speaker: NA
Text: levies that amounts to 46 per cent above the

Speaker: NA
Text: export price at this time. We are letting that

Speaker: NA
Text: down gradually over six or seven years in an

Speaker: NA
Text: effort to get more efficiency. If we can get effi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciency in the industry we will get greater returns

Speaker: NA
Text: for all people, and they will be more equitable

Speaker: NA
Text: returns.

Speaker: NA
Text: The big problem for the industry really centres

Speaker: NA
Text: around Victoria because of the farm cash oper-

Speaker: NA
Text: ating surpluses at present of about $41,000 in

Speaker: NA
Text: par- Western Australia, going down to about $13,000

Speaker: NA
Text: in Victoria. That is because Victoria carries vir-

Speaker: NA
Text: tually all the load of exports. If the industry

Speaker: NA
Text: wants to go back to operating within its own

Speaker: NA
Text: little States, we will have a collapse of the whole

Speaker: NA
Text: industry once an interstate breakout occurs. This

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation is really the industry's last chance to

Speaker: NA
Text: try to head down the path of having a national

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-Order! The time aIlotted

Speaker: NA
Text: for the remaining stages of the BiIl has expired.

Speaker: NA
Text: ADJOURNMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: Rural Australia: Financial Crisis-Sri Lankan

Speaker: NA
Text: High Commissioner-Immunisation

Speaker: NA
Text: Programs-Fringe Benefits Tax

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr Kerin) proposed:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House do now adjourn.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: presented a submission to the Minister for Pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: mary Industry ( Mr Kerin) outlining the eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomic and social tragedy taking place in the

Speaker: NA
Text: central MaIlee area of my electorate. In that

Speaker: NA
Text: submission I largely concentrated on the extreme

Speaker: NA
Text: financial difficulties being faced by primary pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducers and the stresses being faced by the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munities concerned. As a result of those

Speaker: NA
Text: representations certain actions in the financial

Speaker: NA
Text: and social area took place that have been of

Speaker: NA
Text: significant help.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, I now wish to bring before this

Speaker: NA
Text: 1986 Parliament the need for a similar type of assist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance to be provided to smaIl business operators

Speaker: NA
Text: in the same region. It is now becoming apparent

Speaker: NA
Text: that many smaIl businesses are finding it difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: to survive, as a direct consequence of the down-

Speaker: NA
Text: turn in primary industry. Of course, many of

Speaker: NA
Text: these businesses have suffered setbacks because

Speaker: NA
Text: of a sudden faIl in farm spending and the inabil-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity of many smaIl business operators to recover

Speaker: NA
Text: outstanding debts incurred by farmers. Their

Speaker: NA
Text: problem has been further exacerbated by the

Speaker: NA
Text: drift in population away from smaIl towns due

Speaker: NA
Text: to government services being withdrawn, young

Speaker: NA
Text: people seeking employment in provincial and

Speaker: NA
Text: capital cities, and second and third generation

Speaker: NA
Text: farming families leaving the district to seek em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment elsewhere simply because farm in-

Speaker: NA
Text: comes cannot support them.

Speaker: NA
Text: A recent survey carried out by Bruce Mc-

Speaker: NA
Text: Kenzie, associate head of the social science fac-

Speaker: NA
Text: ulty at the Warrnambool Institute of Advanced

Speaker: NA
Text: Education, has shown that one in four families

Speaker: NA
Text: in the MaIlee and Sunraysia districts now live

Speaker: NA
Text: below the poverty line, which paints a very grim

Speaker: NA
Text: picture for operators of smaIl business hoping

Speaker: NA
Text: for an immediate improvement in trade. It is felt

Speaker: NA
Text: that even with the prospect of good harvests by

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers this season, that will only marginaIly

Speaker: NA
Text: assist smaIl business. It is estimated that at least

Speaker: NA
Text: 95 per cent of farms in the area now have debts

Speaker: NA
Text: to such a level that it will take a series of good

Speaker: NA
Text: seasons to restore them to a viable situation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The very close contact I have had with small

Speaker: NA
Text: business operators in my electorate leads me to

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that urgent assistance must become avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able to them almost immediately or they will be

Speaker: NA
Text: forced to close or go into bankruptcy. As an

Speaker: NA
Text: indication of the types of debts owned by pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: mary producers to small businesses the following

Speaker: NA
Text: information should be known to the House. For

Speaker: NA
Text: example, an agricultural service business

Speaker: NA
Text: ently owed some $8,500 for chemicals supplied

Speaker: NA
Text: to a farmer for the 1985 crop; another farmer

Speaker: NA
Text: owes approximately $48,000 for fertiliser; an-

Speaker: NA
Text: other small business operator is owed some

Speaker: NA
Text: $12,500 for superphosphate. Of course, these

Speaker: NA
Text: instances could be repeated over and over again

Speaker: NA
Text: and, in almost every community, with amounts

Speaker: NA
Text: owed varying from what some may consider to

Speaker: NA
Text: be small to those larger than those I have cited

Speaker: NA
Text: here.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, small business operators find that

Speaker: NA
Text: in the present depressed economic climate it is

Speaker: NA
Text: simply not possible to recover these debts be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause the equity many farmers hold in their land

Speaker: NA
Text: is low and their assets are unsaleable. One busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness operator has advised me that if he is forced

Speaker: NA
Text: to carry the debts of farmers for, say, the next

Speaker: NA
Text: 12 months, he may well be out of business as

Speaker: NA
Text: the interest he is paying on his money is more

Speaker: NA
Text: than he can earn in the foreseeable future. It

Speaker: NA
Text: has been suggested by a financial institution, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, that suppliers to small business may see

Speaker: NA
Text: their way clear to, in some way, acknowledge

Speaker: NA
Text: their special situation as many such suppliers are

Speaker: NA
Text: diverse and financially strong.

Speaker: NA
Text: to suggest that one arm of business should act

Speaker: NA
Text: as a banker for another? I believe not.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the submission that I am to put before the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Primary Industry, the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Button), the Treasurer ( Mr Keating) and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) next week,

Speaker: NA
Text: I have suggested three possible sources of finan-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial support that could be provided. Firstly, I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that funding will be necessary to allow

Speaker: NA
Text: operators of small business to meet a short-fall

Speaker: NA
Text: in their basic living requirements. Secondly,

Speaker: NA
Text: obvious that funds are required for carry-on

Speaker: NA
Text: finance. Thirdly, it is obvious that loan restruc-

Speaker: NA
Text: turing must take place and that interest rate

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidies also must become available to the small

Speaker: NA
Text: business sector, as they have been made avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able to the farming sector.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is recognised that the administration of

Speaker: NA
Text: funds is a State responsibility. However, I re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quest the relevant Commonwealth Ministers to

Speaker: NA
Text: consult their Victorian State Government col-

Speaker: NA
Text: leagues to develop appropriate programs and to

Speaker: NA
Text: meet any request for funds which may be made

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Victorian Government. It could be said

Speaker: NA
Text: that increased spending by farming families would

Speaker: NA
Text: also assist the viability of small businesses. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, there is little hope in the next two or three

Speaker: NA
Text: years and it will be virtually impossible if gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment assistance is not available to reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: is pres- overhead expenses any further.

Speaker: Mr HOLLIS
Text: Throsby) (4.l8)-1t seems that

Speaker: NA
Text: this is the week for leaks! Today I received into

Speaker: NA
Text: my hand a letter sent from the office of the High

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner for Sri Lanka to Sinhalese in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. That letter, on headed paper and signed

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Commissioner, gives Sinhalese in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia the correct line to follow in response to

Speaker: NA
Text: recent events in Sri Lanka. However, the letter

Speaker: NA
Text: ends up by saying that the matters are best left

Speaker: NA
Text: to the judgment of the recipients of the letter

Speaker: NA
Text: and to the resources that they can harness. Let

Speaker: NA
Text: us look at the suggestions made by this diplomat

Speaker: NA
Text: accredited to Australia. He suggests writing let-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters giving facts of incidents, together with paper

Speaker: NA
Text: cuttings to members of parliament, especially to

Speaker: NA
Text: members who have been anti-Sri Lanka on this

Speaker: NA
Text: issue-for example, the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Hotham ( Mr Kent), Senator Chipp, myself and

Speaker: NA
Text: others. As a member of parliament, I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: object to this. We get many such letters. I make

Speaker: NA
Text: the point that I am not anti-Sri Lanka. What I

Speaker: NA
Text: am anti are the genocidal policies culminating in

Speaker: NA
Text: the military action now taking place by the

Speaker: NA
Text: current layawardene Government. The letter

Speaker: NA
Text: However, is it fair goes on to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: Give facts about the battle being waged between the

Speaker: NA
Text: rival terrorist groups.

Speaker: NA
Text: A lot of corroborative propaganda was enclosed

Speaker: NA
Text: for this purpose. He goes on to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: Write letters and send material to church organisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions-Unirng Church, human rights and Amnesty In-

Speaker: NA
Text: ternational bodies in Australia, who have been one-sided

Speaker: NA
Text: on this issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: What he does not say, of course, is that these

Speaker: NA
Text: people have not swallowed the lies put out by

Speaker: NA
Text: it is the Sri Lankan High Commissioner in Canberra.

Speaker: NA
Text: He says:

Speaker: NA
Text: Write letters and send material to editors of major

Speaker: NA
Text: newspapers and radio and TV stations and also, if

Speaker: NA
Text: possible, give interviews which they can carry.

Speaker: NA
Text: The one I really find unacceptable is the follow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, which I quote in full because it is very

Speaker: NA
Text: such important. The letter from the High Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioner for Sri Lanka said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Arrange for demonstrations if possible in front of

Speaker: NA
Text: Indian trade/consular offices and in front of Indian

Speaker: NA
Text: Airlines/ Air India offices with appropriate placards and

Speaker: NA
Text: slogans.

Speaker: NA
Text: I find it totally unacceptable that a diplomat in

Speaker: NA
Text: this country should use or abuse his position to

Speaker: NA
Text: incite Australian citizens-many of the Sinhalese

Speaker: NA
Text: in this country are naturalised Australian citi-

Speaker: NA
Text: zens-to get involved in activities against a

Speaker: NA
Text: friendly nation, that is, India, in an attempt to

Speaker: NA
Text: disrupt the activities of its official organisations,

Speaker: NA
Text: thus causing unwarranted problems in the rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionship between Australia and India and caus-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing unnecessary embarrassment to Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The current High Commissioner for Sri Lanka

Speaker: NA
Text: has recently taken up his post, but one should

Speaker: NA
Text: bear in mind that this gentleman, prior to his

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment, was Secretary of the ministry es-

Speaker: NA
Text: tablished to produce and propagate incorrect

Speaker: NA
Text: information and blatant lies to achieve the goals

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Sri Lankan Government; that is, wiping

Speaker: NA
Text: out the entire Tamil community in Sri Lanka.

Speaker: NA
Text: Perhaps it is time, at the commencement of his

Speaker: NA
Text: tour of duty, that the High Commissioner be

Speaker: NA
Text: reminded of the behaviour expected of a diplo-

Speaker: NA
Text: mat in this country and that it is totally unac-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceptable that people should be encouraged to

Speaker: NA
Text: disrupt the legitimate activities of a third friendly

Speaker: NA
Text: nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Madam SPEAKER-I remind the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member of standing order 74, which states:

Speaker: NA
Text: No Member may use the name of Her Majesty, her

Speaker: NA
Text: representative in the Commonwealth, or her represent-

Speaker: NA
Text: ative in a State, disrespectfully in debate, nor for the

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose of influencing the House in its deliberations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sri Lanka is a country with which Australia has

Speaker: NA
Text: friendly relations. I draw that to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's attention for future reference.

Speaker: Mrs KELLY
Text: Canberra) (4.23)-Last night

Speaker: NA
Text: in the adjournment debate I was interrupted

Speaker: NA
Text: when I was discussing the proposal by the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations Children's Fund to immunise the world's

Speaker: NA
Text: children by 1990. I was talking of the value of

Speaker: NA
Text: that campaign and indicating my hope that Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia could contribute to that in some way and

Speaker: NA
Text: also link our Government's campaign for a mea-

Speaker: NA
Text: sle-free Bicentennial, because it is important that

Speaker: NA
Text: we give recognition to the fact that vaccine

Speaker: NA
Text: preventable diseases kill a total of over three

Speaker: NA
Text: million children a year in the developing world,

Speaker: NA
Text: with a similar number crippled and handi-

Speaker: NA
Text: capped. Last night I gave a breakdown of the

Speaker: NA
Text: deaths of young children caused by not having

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate vaccines; for example, 58 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: or over two million, of these deaths are caused

Speaker: NA
Text: by measles alone, over 800,000 deaths are caused

Speaker: NA
Text: by tetanus and a further 606,000 deaths are

Speaker: NA
Text: caused by whooping cough. Obviously action has

Speaker: NA
Text: to be taken to assist many of the countries in

Speaker: NA
Text: the developing world to move towards this

Speaker: NA
Text: UNICEF goal.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Secretary-General of the United Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: has taken the unprecedented step of writing to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Presidents or Prime Ministers of all 159

Speaker: NA
Text: member states, drawing to their attention this

Speaker: NA
Text: potential and asking for their personal support

Speaker: NA
Text: for the goal of immunising all of the world's

Speaker: NA
Text: children by 1990. The Prime Minister ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawke) has reacted very favourably to the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quest of the Secretary-General of the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations and has passed the letter on to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) and the Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister for Foreign Affairs ( Mr Hayden). I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that our Government will co-operate in this

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign.

Speaker: NA
Text: The cost of protection against six vaccine pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ventable diseases is approximately $5 per child,

Speaker: NA
Text: which does not seem very much to save the lives

Speaker: NA
Text: of children. This estimate covers everything in-

Speaker: NA
Text: cluding the cost of vaccines, needles, syringes

Speaker: NA
Text: and cottons as well as the cost of equipment,

Speaker: NA
Text: staff salaries, training, transport and petrol. The

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of immunising all children and saving more

Speaker: NA
Text: than three million children from dying in this

Speaker: NA
Text: way is approximately $500m a year, slightly less

Speaker: NA
Text: than the cost of three advanced fighter planes. I

Speaker: NA
Text: support the campaign and hope that the Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment and all the members of this Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: will also give their support in whatever way

Speaker: NA
Text: possible to this very worthwhile aim.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: Mitchell) (4.26)-1 would like

Speaker: NA
Text: to make a few remarks about the fringe benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: tax. I do not think the full ramifications of it

Speaker: NA
Text: have broken through to members of the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity. Only now are they beginning to under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand what it is about. The remarks of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer ( Mr Keating) in the urgency debate

Speaker: NA
Text: today really demonstrated his isolation from

Speaker: NA
Text: reality. It is fine for him to have big waterside

Speaker: NA
Text: residences, cars and antiques, but his lifestyle is

Speaker: NA
Text: quite different from that of a farm worker on

Speaker: NA
Text: whom a fringe benefits tax will now be imposed

Speaker: NA
Text: when he goes out into the paddock, cuts some

Speaker: NA
Text: firewood and brings it home to use in the fuel

Speaker: NA
Text: stove or the open fire. It is quite different for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer to grow his own vegetables, as

Speaker: NA
Text: most farm workers do, and bring them home.

Speaker: NA
Text: He and his wife grow them after working hours.

Speaker: NA
Text: They take advantage of where they live to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide a benefit for themselves and their families.

Speaker: NA
Text: This process can be extended to the way this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government will apply the fringe benefits tax to

Speaker: NA
Text: other things. Dedicated volunteers and workers

Speaker: NA
Text: work for minimal funds for voluntary organisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. They have written to me and to the Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment. The Government seems to think that

Speaker: NA
Text: the St Vincent de Paul Society, the Sydney City

Speaker: NA
Text: Mission and other charitable organisations are

Speaker: NA
Text: somehow tax dodgers. Those are the words that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer consistently used. He calls them

Speaker: NA
Text: rip-off merchants and rorters. That is why we

Speaker: NA
Text: are to have a fringe benefits tax-to stop the

Speaker: NA
Text: rorters and the people in the rip-off system. I

Speaker: NA
Text: not regard those charitable and hospitable organ-

Speaker: NA
Text: isations as rip-off merchants. I regard them as

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the better parts of our society. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: a double whammy in store for those groups

Speaker: NA
Text: because if someone should bequeath property to

Speaker: NA
Text: those organisations, capital gains tax will have

Speaker: NA
Text: to be paid by the estate of the person making

Speaker: NA
Text: the donation.

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Text: That is right.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: The Minister for Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs confirms it. Those who undertake all the

Speaker: NA
Text: voluntary and good things in our society-where

Speaker: NA
Text: people help each other and show their commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to and belief in an organisation that is

Speaker: NA
Text: doing good work-will be penalised. What will

Speaker: NA
Text: happen if someone should leave a property to

Speaker: NA
Text: an organisation of the type that I have men-

Speaker: NA
Text: tioned and no money is left in the estate, if it

Speaker: NA
Text: comprises only property? Who will pay? The

Speaker: NA
Text: organisation that is the beneficiary will be

Speaker: NA
Text: charged. Either somebody has to pay the capital

Speaker: NA
Text: gains tax or the estate will go into debt. Do we

Speaker: NA
Text: have to get into the pockets of the children, the

Speaker: NA
Text: beneficiaries of the estate, and say: 'Mortgage

Speaker: NA
Text: your house to pay the capital gains tax'? The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister shakes his head. I guarantee that he

Speaker: NA
Text: does not know, and that Cabinet has not even

Speaker: NA
Text: considered this, because the Treasurer is so iso-

Speaker: NA
Text: lated and remote from the realities of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn to another stupidity in the fringe bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: fits tax. If a person has a motor car which is

Speaker: NA
Text: used for work and has accessories on that motor

Speaker: NA
Text: car, those accessories by definition must be work-

Speaker: NA
Text: related accessories or they will be valued as part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the value of the car. How crazy can that be?

Speaker: NA
Text: Is a two-way radio an accessory for work? I

Speaker: NA
Text: guess that it is, so it will not be valued with the

Speaker: NA
Text: car. What about a cassette player? It would

Speaker: NA
Text: probably not be included unless one happened

Speaker: NA
Text: do to work in radio when a special case would have

Speaker: NA
Text: to be presented as to why a cassette player in

Speaker: NA
Text: the car should not be counted for the fringe

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits tax. A car phone is something that might

Speaker: NA
Text: have to be considered. What about special lights

Speaker: NA
Text: for country drivers or travelling salesmen, or

Speaker: NA
Text: special mirrors on work vehicles, needed for

Speaker: NA
Text: safety purposes? Those opposite should see how

Speaker: NA
Text: stupid and crazy this is.

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Text: You're stupid.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: I am not. The Minister should

Speaker: NA
Text: read the book. It is in the book. He has not read

Speaker: NA
Text: the tombstone of this Government. He has not

Speaker: NA
Text: read the book that has gone out to small busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nesses. The matter of work-related accessories is

Speaker: NA
Text: spelt out chapter and verse. The example given,

Speaker: NA
Text: as a matter of fact, is a two-way radio. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister has not even read it. The Minister is

Speaker: NA
Text: remote but his responsibility is not the Treasur-

Speaker: NA
Text: er's. The Treasurer should know these things. In

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, he does not. He regards charitable and

Speaker: NA
Text: hospitable organisations as rip-off merchants, and

Speaker: NA
Text: he regards farm workers as people who also need

Speaker: NA
Text: to be punished by a fringe benefits tax. He is

Speaker: NA
Text: remote and isolated. He lives in his big mansion

Speaker: NA
Text: by Sydney Harbour.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! It being 4.30 p.m., the

Speaker: NA
Text: House stands adjourned until Monday, 26 May

Speaker: NA
Text: House adjourned at 4.30 p.m.

Speaker: NA
Text: The following answers to questions were circulated:

Speaker: NA
Text: Attorney-General's Department: Payments to

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 2047)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Blunt asked the Attorney-General, upon

Speaker: NA
Text: notice, on 9 October 1985:

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Adams and Mr Rod Cameron, their companies, or prin-

Speaker: NA
Text: cipals of their companies, for services rendered to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's Department or authorities under the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter's control and for what purposes in each case.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) What amounts have been paid to each of these

Speaker: NA
Text: people or companies for (a) travel allowance, (b) air

Speaker: NA
Text: fares, (c) accommodation costs, (d) hire car expenses

Speaker: NA
Text: and (e) any other expenses incurred.

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Text: The answer to the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: I have been informed by the Human Rights Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion that the advertising agency Monahan Dayman Ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: ams was selected to conduct the information and pUblicity

Speaker: NA
Text: program associated with the proclamation of the Sex

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: that agency.

Speaker: NA
Text: No money, travel allowance, air fares, accommoda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion costs, hire car expenses or any other expenses was

Speaker: NA
Text: paid to Mr Adams personally.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Commission paid the advertising agency $175,123.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of this $123,688 was disbursed to cover items such as

Speaker: NA
Text: printing, display and direct mail costs as well as distripractice

Speaker: NA
Text: bution and marketing costs. The remaining $51,435 was

Speaker: NA
Text: retained by the agency to cover the creative work,

Speaker: NA
Text: consultation and production costs. The amounts speci-

Speaker: NA
Text: fied in the second part of the question were part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: expenses incurred by the agency and are included in the

Speaker: NA
Text: $51,435 mentioned earlier.

Speaker: NA
Text: No payments have been made to Mr Cameron, nor,

Speaker: NA
Text: as far as the Commission is aware, to any company with

Speaker: NA
Text: which Mr Cameron is associated.

Speaker: NA
Text: Taxation: Evasion and Avoidance

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 2217)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Jacobi asked the Attorney-General, upon

Speaker: NA
Text: notice, on 16 October 1985:

Speaker: NA
Text: (I) Will he take steps, including consultations with

Speaker: NA
Text: the States, to restructure the provisions of the Bank-

Speaker: NA
Text: ruptcy Act and its administration to close off existing

Speaker: NA
Text: loop-holes that are being exploited by individuals to

Speaker: NA
Text: evade or avoid payment of their liabilities to creditors

Speaker: NA
Text: and their obligations in regard to commercial morality.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Will he take steps to arrange for

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Companies Code and its administration by the

Speaker: NA
Text: various States to close off existing loop-holes that are

Speaker: NA
Text: being exploited by companies and their directors to

Speaker: NA
Text: avoid the payment of liabilities and their obligations to

Speaker: NA
Text: the commercial public in general.

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Text: The answer to the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

Speaker: NA
Text: (I) On 20 November 1983 my predecessor as

Speaker: NA
Text: Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, Q.C., re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quested the Australian Law Reform Commission to

Speaker: NA
Text: undertake a major review of the law and practice of

Speaker: NA
Text: insolvency, both personal and corporate. Mr R. W.

Speaker: NA
Text: Harmer is the Commissioner in charge of the reference.

Speaker: NA
Text: Because corporate or company insolvency is the subject

Speaker: NA
Text: of State and Territorial legislation, the inquiry by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission will necessarily involve extensive consulta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion with the States and the Northern Territory. The

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of reference relating to the inquiry expressly re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quire the Commission to consult with the States and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Northern Territory.

Speaker: NA
Text: The inquiry by the Commission will be necessarily a

Speaker: NA
Text: long one. Pending the completion of that inquiry and

Speaker: NA
Text: the tabling of the report, the Government will consider

Speaker: NA
Text: amending the Bankruptcy Act where this is necessary.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is likely that amendments to the Bankruptcy Act will

Speaker: NA
Text: be introduced into the Parliament in the Budget Sitting.

Speaker: NA
Text: An announcement providing more details of the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed amendments will be made at a later time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Concerning the administration of the Bankruptcy Act,

Speaker: NA
Text: my Department is presently addressing the question of

Speaker: NA
Text: a major review of the structure, organisation and meth-

Speaker: NA
Text: ods of Bankruptcy Branch of my Department. The

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of reference of the proposed review will be suffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciently wide so that all major issues of an administrative

Speaker: NA
Text: nature may be addressed.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) As mentioned above, the Australian Law Reform

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission is considering the question of the law and

Speaker: NA
Text: of insolvency, both personal and corporate. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am unable to anticipate the Commission's findings by

Speaker: NA
Text: suggesting that the Commission will or will not recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mend a restructuring of the Companies Code and its

Speaker: NA
Text: administration. However, the Commission's inquiry is

Speaker: NA
Text: expected to address all the major issues relating to the

Speaker: NA
Text: law and practice of corporate insolvency.

Speaker: NA
Text: A number of amendments to the Companies Act and

Speaker: NA
Text: Codes which came into operation on 31 March 1986

Speaker: NA
Text: address the issue that you have raised. In particular I

Speaker: NA
Text: draw your attention to section 562A of the Companies

Speaker: NA
Text: Act and Codes which was inserted by section 123 of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendments) Act 1985. This provision enables the

Speaker: NA
Text: NCSC to prohibit persons involved in the management

Speaker: NA
Text: of failed companies from taking part in the management

Speaker: NA
Text: of a corporation without their having obtained the leave

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Supreme Court.

Speaker: NA
Text: Brisbane International Airport

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 3404)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Jull asked the Minister for Aviation, upon

Speaker: NA
Text: the restructuring notice, on 14 March 1986:

Speaker: NA
Text: (I) What is the projected opening date of the new

Speaker: NA
Text: Brisbane International Airport.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Will the new airport operate without a curfew; if

Speaker: NA
Text: not, why not.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Is consideration being given to a memorial to the

Speaker: NA
Text: late Honourable K. M. Cairns, former Member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Lilley, for his promotion of the new Brisbane Interna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional Airport.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Would the naming of the new terminal building

Speaker: NA
Text: after Mr Cairns constitute an appropriate form of

Speaker: NA
Text: memorial.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: ( I) The target date for commissioning the new airport

Speaker: NA
Text: is September 1987.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) The new airport will be curfew free.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) I have received a number of representations on

Speaker: NA
Text: this subject. Consideration will be given to commemo-

Speaker: NA
Text: rating the late Hon. K. M. Cairns, former Member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Lilley, when the question of naming features associated

Speaker: NA
Text: with the new Brisbane airport is addressed.

Speaker: NA
Text: ( 4) It is practice not to name airports or terminal

Speaker: NA
Text: buildings after individuals, but to name them according

Speaker: NA
Text: to the major city that they serve.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tourism Overseas Promotion Scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 3669)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr White asked the Minister for Sport, Rec-

Speaker: NA
Text: reation and Tourism, upon notice, on 8 April

Speaker: NA
Text: (I) How many applications have been (a) received

Speaker: NA
Text: and (b) approved for assistance under the Tourism

Speaker: NA
Text: Overseas Promotion Scheme.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Guidelines. (b) $4,810,965.

Speaker: NA
